description:
I am a burrito snob.

I ordered the Super Burrito with Carne Asada and Refried Beans.

I have never had a burrito that was better. 

Period.

Only drawback -- it's sort of a grocery store + taqueria. This means that I don't think they had free chips and salsa, and the only seating they had were a few tables outside. Not enough for me to demerit any stars, however.

I don't go to San Francisco often (yuck I hate places where parking is a pain), but I would definitely go back if I was in the area.

The burrito was on par with any of the legendary burrito spots in the Mission, if not better.

Biggest compliment I can give -- the meat was perfect. Not overcooked, but most importantly, no gristle or fat in any bites.

Bravo!
author: Benny L.

description:
I got the super burrito, it was whatever. I wouldn't come back again. They didn't have a bathroom either so that was no bueno. 

I also for the strawberry horcata, no bueno also.

Maybe it just didn't my taste buds
author: Jimmy P.

description:
THE BEST CHICHARRON IN TOWN! 
They are always busy but that's because their food and groceries option are amazing! 

Order -- There were 4 pieces of chicharrones in the bags, which came out to be $3.45. They accept visa card with no minimum. Needless to say, I ate them all in one setting. The chicharrones were warm, crunchy, meaty, well seasoned, and just felt like love in every bite. 

Space -- We sat outside beside the restaurant. They have shades and seatings available which added a very nice touch because there's no seating inside the shop.
author: Yuan Z.

description: This store has become a staple for me when making tacos at home. The handmade corn tortilla is sooo gooood!! They come in different sizes and no added preservatives. The chips and guacamole sauce are a must too.
author: Tracy V.

description:
BEST PUPUSA I'VE EVER HAD EVER

Located on the bustling part of 24th, this deli is easy to get to by public transit but may take some time to find parking. The locals go here so you know it's good!

The inside is part mercantile and part taqueria. The also have some bar tables right out front, and often a covered dining area outside and down Florida street. 

I ordered a jalapeño and cheese tamale and a bean an cheese pupusa. I didn't care for the tamale, seemed dry and unloved but the pupusa was the best I've ever had! I could tell they prepared it 'a la plancha' and the corn exterior was so fresh and delicious. The sauce they paired it with was also top notch and authentic. I paired my meal with a Guava Jarritos, which I've never seen before, and I was on cloud nine !! I sat there on their patio with a grin for a bit; it was seriously that good.
author: Navila H.

description: Disappointed. I had been craving a burrito from this place because they're normally amazing. The burrito was cold. COLD. The girl working by the door was inattentive and I don't know who made the burritos today... but uggh so sad. Hoping the owners take a look at what's going. This is normally a high quality place, too.
author: E V.

description:
So glad to have tried food from La Palma. Friends brought us some food over since we just had a baby and not cooking much. 

We sampled their tortillas, rice, black beans, pork salsa verde (I think) and guac and salsa. We made soft tacos out of all this and it was delicious. Food is really good and tasty! Would love to try some more from their menu :)
author: Heliana M.

description: Asked for 'un poco de lechuga', easy on the lettuce and this is what I got. Not the first time this happens either :/ Wtf! If I want that much lettuce, id go find a salad spot.
author: Hector M.

description:
La Palma is a busy busy venue. 

I don't like the layout of the place particularly just because when it gets busy it's hard to maneuver.  

It's a grocery store that also sells tamales, masa and lots of other stuff you can't get at just any local supermarket. 

The ranking below is simply for the tacos which are  just "ok" and middle of the pack for me. Especially given that people go here for "other" stuff it's not a place that I go out of my way for tacos flacos. 

The world needs a San Francisco Taco ranking...so I'm here to provide my humble list/rankings. 

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top) is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. 

When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. If you're curious, I have rankings for Boba, Bakeries and Ramen , Chicken and Waffles as well (random right?)  Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews.  I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places.  

Rod's SF Taco Rankings:

1 El Gallo Giro Taco truck
2 Garajito
3 Belmar La Gallinita Meat Market
4 La Corneta
5 Chisme
6 El Norteno Taco Truck
7 Taqueria Los Mayas 
8 Garaje
9 Taqueria Vallarta
10 Little Taqueria
11 La Taqueria
12 Taqueria Castillo
13 El Farolito
14 Pancho Villa Taqueria 
15 Taqueria el Buen Sabor
16 Panuchos
17 Taqueria Gudalajara
18 La Palma Mexicatessen
19 El Tonayense
20 Tropisueno
21 La Espiga de Oro
22 Papito Hayes
23 Tacos San Buena
24 Los Compadres Taco Truck
25 Cochinita Mayan Cuisine
26 El Taco Loco
27 Gordo Taqueria
28 Nick's Crispy Tacos

Below is my top 10 for the Bay Area in case you were curious.
1 El Gallo Giro Taco truck
2 El Jaliciense
3 Taqueria Sinaloa
4 Garajito
5 Belmar La Gallinita Meat Market
6 Belly
7 La Corneta
8 Chisme
9 El Norteno Taco Truck
10 Taqueria Los Mayas
author: Rod M.

description: I have fond memories in half grocery store half restaurant type places as a kid (shout out to Savoy in Houston). I had a feeling this place was good because everything coming out here in peoples hands looked fresh. We stayed in an Air BnB nearby so this colorful place caught out eye. We split the chicken burrito supreme. So many different kinds of meat and tortilla to get. The burrito was so good, just look at it. A cheap delicious meal in mission.
author: Anoosha A.

description:
Solid veggie burrito in the Mission near the 24th St BART station. Veggie burrito came w/ heaps of veggies including broccoli, zucchini, & bell peppers. Guacamole isn't charged extra so instead if you are looking to get it vegan you have to order it "super" w/ guacamole, cheese, & sour cream yet request no cheese & no sour cream. Chips & salsa cost extra.

I was given two small containers of salsa for my burrito after I requested salsa. 

The main caveat w/ La Palma is that seating is solely outdoors so in the colder months this might not be a great option.
author: Shane S.

description:
Ordered the Chillaquiles plate with huevos (they also asked if I wanted chicken instead of eggs) and half Chile Roja/verde.

Everything was so FRESH AND DELICIOUS!!! I was super impressed because a lot of restaurants use tostadas or tortilla chips and just place salsa and toppings on it.

La Palma made their chillaquiles more authetically with fresh tortillas and it made me so happy! Plate was only $10 and came with rice and beans.

Theres no sitting inside but few seats outside so prepare to bundle up if you're planning to dine in.
author: Noorafi A.

description: Must go! The best and authentic Mexican in Mission. Tamales are amazing and a must have!!! Hand made corn tortillas and worth taking a dozen with you. No seating inside., but tables available outside.  Very small inside with a market inside so can make it a bit awkward if you've never been there.
author: Daisy H.

description: The prices here have gone up.  It seems, it's not that quaint, hidden, off the beaten path kind of place, like it was 15 years or so ago.  I like their outdoor sidewalk seating.  I was disappointed, with the carnitas burrito.  It didn't seem fresh.  It was mildly warm and the carnitas filling seemed, like old, dry, left over meat.  Mex delicatessen food should strive to always be fresh, like how they make tortillas in the back.  Will still go there, until what they serve up is just regularly bad.  Rating: 3 1/2 stars.
author: Zeoki A.

description:
I was on the hunt for some chicharron and the search led me to La Palma.  As others have mentioned this is part grocery store part taqueria.  The best part is that some of grocery items are freshly made - tortillas, gorditas, huaraches, chicharron, masa, etc.

Upon entry I made a bee line for the fresh tortillas on the counter in the back.  I picked up a pack of the chicken huaraches, beads of condensation still present on the inside of the bag and warm to the touch.  I also picked up a bag of their tortillas.  

On my way to the cashier up front to pay I passed by the display of chicharron and stared at the jewels of pork meat and skin inside.  They were not labeled so I asked the cashier what was available and she told me they had meat with fat, meat and meat with skin.  I asked for a half pound ($9.99/lb) of the meat with skin but wish now I had purchased one pound.  They were quite good and did not contain chunks of fat, but just relatively moist meat and crispy skin.   I've had super dry and stale pork skin before that made me cough and choke when swallowing them and these were NOT anything like that.  They were delicious!  They were almost like Chinese roast pig but the chicharron had different seasoning and were deep fried.  I would definitely come back for these.  For leftovers, they were easy to heat up and softened up a bit (skin was crispy but not rock hard) after 10 minutes in the toaster oven.

I tried the tortilla as soon as I returned home and it was thick, chewy and flavorful.  I ate it with some pork chile verde and liked how the tortilla held up pretty well to the wet filling.

During my visit to La Palmas the store was relatively empty with a only couple of other patrons there.  The cashier was friendly.   A few tables are available outside for those that wish to dine there.  Parking was generally pretty easy during my visit at noon on a weekday.
author: Melissa L.

description:
This place deserves a Michelin star. As the Mission evolves and changes, one place that has stayed true to their roots and flavor is La Palma. I do question the choice of music lately. They used to have Mexican music playing, but now they have oldies? 

My review is about the food. The food is delicious! Warm tortillas and chicharrones. The ladies making the delicious pupusas and tortillas, deserve respect for what they do. To be in that heat, is no joke. They put their love. The food is so delicious. I have tried many plates. 

I did have a question- last time I went in I wanted xtra spicy salsa on the side but the cashier said they could not give me any spicy salsa on the side? I was confused. She said my "boss" has told me we can't give salsa on the side or spicy salsa's on the side because it might be too spicy.  I was slightly perplexed, how can it be Mexican food without the spicy salsa. I hope they change their policy.
author: Jayden R.

description:
I went here to get some Chicharron because I've been wanting to compare it with my favorite place "Belmar".
so I did, I bought a pound of Chicharron con Grasita e Carne (Mix).
but also while I was there, I might as well trying their food.
and I did.
I bought a Quesadilla Suiza con Carnitas.
the Chicharrones were good (still not as good as Belmar's), but the Quesadilla Suiza was disappointing.
luckily the weather was nice and as I sat outside at the side patio, I met two incredibly friendly gentlemen Hector & Andres.
we had such interesting conversation about Mexican Regional Cuisines (Puebla, Hidalgo, Morelia, Distrito Federal, Oaxaca, Yucatan, and El Chilango).
so, it was great even though the Quesadilla wasn't.
author: Rudy H.

description: I really wanted to enjoy this place. I felt that it was an overpriced taqueria. For the same good and half the fuss, I could have gone to the Mission. Not a bad place at all, just underwhelming considering the wait and all.
author: LAIKA K.

description:
So glad I found this place! Cool small Mexican market with to go food as well. 

We got a chorizo breakfast burrito and a carne asada burrito. Both delicious! We also got tortillas to take home and I love that you can see they're made with lard (the good stuff). I'll be back!
author: Daniela J.

description:
Got 9 pounds of masa for us and 3 for a friend. We purchased the kind without lard or shortening added so we could add our preferred kind. We tried both the non-GMO white corn and the organic blue corn. They were both great though the blue was a bit gummy in texture. 

Looking forward to making many more batches. 

They are also great for other products.
author: Marco M.

description:
The food here is so good, that sometimes I think the employees get very tired working on a place that is super hot that they throw their anger on the food, lol is not bad thing but one time I got beans from here they were so gross I couldn't eat them. Wasn't sure if they need it flavor or whoever made them were not in the mood Lol ! 


But anyways the food here is good , sometimes the employees are just talking in spanish (chismes) and is very annoying because they don't help out they just talk and talk.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
The best chicharron and tortillas ever! My entire family have been long time customers here. I remember walking to La Palma as a small child after getting out of school at St. Peter's right across the street.  And even though I live in San Jose now I still make at least two trips a month for my comfort food! 

And as soon as the holidays come around it is just about a weekly trip to get masa for tamales!  

It is so nice to see that the clientele has grown so much! I recently found a group listening to an audio tour on an app called 'detour' guided/narrated by a local.  Who would have thought our neighborhood mexicatessen would be part of a tour available on a smart phone!!! Glad that more people will know of this gem!!! Good food! I hope my daughter and nephews will continue the family tradition of eating here and bringing friends!
author: Veronica F.

description:
Pretty awesome. I've come here since I was young, and the food is just so good. 

It's basically a take-out restaurant with some pre-made foods to purchase grocery-style. If you want to "dine in" there's about three tables outside to stand and eat at. But generally, it's not a place to go in and eat.

My favorite is their chicharrón. But pretty much everything I've ever gotten there is delicious.
author: Lily W.

description: Ordered a breakfast burrito and chilaquiles. There was no eggs in either. Who makes a breakfast burrito without eggs. The burrito was soggy.
author: J G.

description:
The best and only Mexicatessen I have ever been to. I had heard La Palma recommended, and headed there soon after arriving in San Francisco, which turned out to be the best idea ever. The food here is absolutely phenomenal. They make their tortillas and huaraches on site, and you can buy a lot of stuff to take home, or grab a quick meal there. 
It's not the kind of place where you would sit and hang out for a long time, but amazing and very reasonable for a quick meal- I went back the next day to try more stuff as it was bloody delicious!
author: Frankie J.

description: This place is everything, authentico, delicioso, real, affordable, outdoor seating, lovely. New favorite!
author: Ave L.

description:
Decided on this place instead of El Farolito based on Yelp reviews.   Great vibe from walking through the door.  Fairly tight quarters but the staff are really proactive and helpful.

I ordered also based on some reviews.  Never had a papusa before so I gave it a try filled with everything (revuelta).  It was tasty alone though a bit salty but married with the cabbage and sauce made it awesome.  

I use tacos as my barometer so I asked for a chicken taco.  Opted for chicken with sauce instead of grilled.  Was really tasty as well.

Finished up with hot horchata which was not the greatest I've ever had but did the trick.

Don't let the mom&pop facade fool you, they are a well-oiled machine.  After ordering in back, you pay up front with the receipt your given and then pick up your order by the door. 
 
The prices can't be beat (a grand total of $9.38).  Definitely will be back.
author: Edward L.

description:
Tried: carne asada super burrito, carne asada and carnitas taco, revueltas pupusas

Perhaps we ordered the wrong items, but I can't see why La Palma is rated so highly. The carne asada and carnitas were both extremely dry (especially in the tacos), and the burrito was pretty flavorless and oversalted.

2 stars because the pupusas were decent, although I've definitely had a lot better in the Mission.
author: Hannah H.

description: In town with teenagers in tow on a limited budget, we thought tacos would be a cheap and filling choice for lunch. Omg. This was the best Mexican food, fresh, hot, lots!! Friendly staff a plus. Yummmmm. Enjoy the vibrant colorful urban energy of the Mission and stop here!!!!
author: Margaret C.

description: Their food is ok. Too pricey and very very bad customer service. They sold me a sour masa. Their guacamole is awful too.
author: Hazel C.

description: I've given La Palma so many chances.  It's just not good at all.  There are so many better options on 24th street.  La Palma makes good tortillas... And that's about it.  Everything's over priced and all of the meats are just plain bad.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
Small is the right word for this Mexican grocery store but a better word would be miniscule. But we came in to try the burrito Sunday afternoon. I thought the lines were confusing. I didn't want to get ahead of someone but there was no order.

 That was the least of my problem.  I wanted goat meat,hence the Sunday visit but they were out. But I did not learn that for a while because most of the people taking the order do not speak English and my Spanish is limited to "gracias". I tried to say what I thought was goat...birria or something like that. Nope wasn't working. I felt like I was talking to customer service at Century Link, an internet provider back in Ohio. Communication after "super" and "burrito" ceased. All I wanted was goat and no cilantro and put on what everyone else gets. Finally someone else steps up and says goat was sold out. This place is a 45 min trek on 2 busses.  I have to get something and it sure won't be tripe or brains! Al Pastore...I remember that is some sort of pork.  That's it. Ordered and took the slip to the register to pay. One person ahead of me with very little. That won't take long...wrong. Must have been at the register for 10-12 min. But when I paid, the burrito was ready.
The burrito itself was nice size and hubby and I split it. Filled us up and we could keep our healthy BMI. I liked the taste but both of us remarked that there wasn't much Al Pastor unless Al Pastor means rice and beans. Would I return or stick to La Taqueria where they understand me but there is no goat but the burritos are filled with meat? I might return, the taste was really good and maybe I might try other stuff.  But I don't speak Spanish and communication is difficult.  But just in case, I am saving my order slip so I can show that instead of talking. They did get the no cilantro right!
author: Vickie B.

description: Ordered 2 dozen pork tamales for Cinco de Mayo party. They were great. I got them to heat up at home. My guests loved them. Especially with the fresh salsa picante to go with them, although I prefer mine with some enchilada sauce. So many delicious things to get here to eat outside on the tables or take out. And you can masa, husks, etc. to make your own tamales. Love this place.
author: Stephen P.

description: A solid Mexican joint located in the Mission District of SF. Came after having friends recommend that I obtain a Mission Burrito (see what I did there? heh) & try one before leaving so this visit is exactly what I ended up doing. As I was on a time crunch (flight was not too far later that same day - afternoon), I ordered a Super Burrito to go - a nice combo of 2 meats, rice, beans, guacamole, sour cream, cheese, lettuce, and salsa fresca ... essentially the things you can come to expect in a burrito. My first impressions of it? Quite good & yummy. Meat along with ingredients used are fresh, the burrito shell held up quite nicely despite all the wet ingredients used, and overall, it was worth coming out of my way of (since I was a tourist). Overall, this place has some great tasting tacos, burritos, specials, enchilidas, and the like (Mexican cuisine) and I would definitely recommend a trip to this place if you're in the area & craving some Mexican food!
author: Jack M.

description: Parking is bad.. but come early .. everything so tasty n yummy .. tamales to tortas.. tortillas.. roast whole chickens and Fried pork bites... different cheeses.. on n on n on... lol...
author: Crisy G.

description: The pollo al horno was unbelievably good. Rice, beans, tortillas also fantastic. Good prices.
author: Owen M.

description:
This place is LEGIT. It can get a bit crowded so I suggest ordering ahead through Yelp. Not much seating either but you can eat at the park or somewhere else nearby. 

Highly recommend the sopes. I got the chicharon sopes and it had chunks of crispy pork, some hot sauce, taco sauce, a little cheese and lettuce. At first I ate it with a fork but then decided to just pick it up and go for it. Such an amazing mix of flavors, this is awesome. Definitely order this.  

Pupusa: I tried the pupusa revuelta which has pork, cheese, and beans. They serve this on a disposable plate with a bag of slaw like stuff and some hot sauce. I definitely liked the sope more as it had much more flavor but after dipping the pupusa in the sauce, I found it to be good also. I think if you eat this the "authentic" way- hot and topped with the vinegar and cabbage slaw this would be better. It was still pretty good, not the best I've had but enjoyable. I'd order two sopes in the future though instead of one of those and one pupusa. 

Burritos: The burritos are alright though definitely not the best I've had in the Mission. If you really want a burrito and nothing else, I would go somewhere else. They aren't bad by any means though so if you come here to get other stuff and want a burrito, it is a convenient option.  

It's also a store and they sell masa you can make pupusas and sopes and what not at home. You can even buy the meat and other ingredients here and just assemble everything together at home. 

Prices are awesome, you can get a lot of food for not a lot of money. The food isn't super spicy which I like but if you do like more spice you may want to bring your own hot sauce. Also note it's not really a restaurant so don't expect a lot of seating or anything. On a nice day, you can take your food and walk around the neighborhood or eat at the park. 

I'd probably give them five stars for the sopes alone and four stars for everything else. Come here and try the sopes though, they are truly outstanding.
author: Seema U.

description:
Solid mexican food joint. There's basically a taqueria in the back of a small mexi mart. (Fridges of homemade guac and salsa and tortillas!)

Carnitas super burrito was superb. Fresh tortilla, juicy meat, wondrous flavors. And the salsa! *drool*
author: Kelly G.

description:
Best vegan burrito of my life! 

Best black beans, guacamole and rice - so fresh, full of flavor and just enough spicy. The wrap is very tasty and delicate. And it's $9 only. 

I shopped some beans and other groceries  to cook later inside the deli as well. Love the place.
author: Liza B.

description: This is a cool little bodega with food but honestly, the food here is just ok. Got a couple different tacos, a sopa and a burrito. Also ordered some chicharron. It's all just ok except for the burrito which was really good because their guacamole is pretty stellar. I went back and got a thing of guac and a bag of chips to bring back with me. The guac is super overpriced though which is disappointing. Oh well. Again, just ok.
author: Dang N.

description: Probably my favorite burrito in the city. This place makes its own tortilla and chips in house from scratch. Everything is fresh. Service is great. And it's CLEAN! One of few places I can eat a whole burrito and not feel like garbage later on.
author: Justin E.

description:
Blown away
So good
Coming back every day until I try the entire menu
How did I'm miss this place all the years I've lived here?!
Gotta make up for lost time!
author: Trevor M.

description:
I took my girlfriend here for lunch, she complained the burrito had too much meat in it....
I went home alone and never saw her again.
author: BuddhaPaul T.

description: This place is a hidden gem located in a small grocery store.  I ordered three tacos and they were all delicious.  I also ordered a small order of chicharones and wowza!  Fatty and delicious.  There's limited seating but we were still able to stand at a tall table.  They make their own tortillas and they have a wide selection of salsas you can buy.  I bought their habanero salsa and it had a kick!
author: Julia W.

description: This place has delicious burritos. Why can't they open up a spot in NYC so I can eat there all of the time? Life just isn't fair. I went with the chicken in red sauce burrito and some day I'll be back to do it again!
author: Steven C.

description:
I'm surprised this place has good reviews.
I got a regular al pastor burrito and pineapple aguas frescas. They had two types of aguas frescas - pineapple and horchata. The pineapple was pretty good. My coworker got the horchata and it looked sooo thick like a milkshake. He couldn't finish it and ended up tossing most of it in the trash. 
The al pastor meat wasn't that good, it was really mushy. Al pastor is usually cooked with pineapple juice but it was really strange when I got a whole chunk of pineapple in my burrito! Overall, the burrito was mediocre and really dry. 
My coworker got a vegetarian burrito and it had broccoli and carrots in it?! The menu says the vegetarian burrito is the same as the super burrito without meat. Not even close, it lacked guac and sour cream and he definitely was not expecting there to be broccoli and carrots in his burrito. Another coworker got a regular burrito and asked to add sour cream and salsa in it. When he got his burrito, it didn't have either so he went in to ask for sour cream and salsa on the side. The employee states that the regular burrito doesn't come with sour cream and salsa and claims my coworker never asked for it, but ended up reluctantly giving it to him.
There are so many other great options in the area for Mexican food, I'll pass on coming here next time.
author: Emily L.

description:
Disappointed in my breakfast burrito experience. 

I came here around 10AM hoping to grab a bite of breakfast goodness. Eggs, potatoes, bacon or sausage. I get to the counter say my order and the first response is what type of beans. At first I was like hmm, might be a little different. I wasn't even asked for type of meat, so I was thinking may be they have a standard set of meat in the burrito?

I get my order, ask for some salsa and hot sauce, take my first bite and realize my mouth is sad. The burrito only contained spanish rice, beans, and potatoes. And for $8? Don't go here if you're expecting a classic diner style breakfast burrito.
author: Geronimo Carlo R.

description:
I have catered twice from La Palma, and each time the food has been a hit! I ordered the Taco Bar for 35 people and everyone loved it. I especially loved the fresh strawberry agua fresca - it is delicious and not too sweet. La Palma does a nice job packing the catered food to go. Everything came wrapped in tin foil containers so it was easily transportable. 

The only feedback I'd give is the process it took to place the order. Terry was extremely helpful but not super responsive to email. It wasn't always convenient to call during the work day. We played phone tag a few times and when we finally spoke some minor follow up items were not fully confirmed, so I had to call again. I understand they are super busy. I'd definitely use La Palma again for my catering needs!
author: Claudia H.

description: Love their organic blue corn and non-gmo nixtamal.  Made lots of tamales this x-mas and the masa was very delicious.  They also had a very efficient system for accommodating dozens of customers in an effective manner.  A neighborhood jewel.
author: Hadas R.

description:
This is a straight up deli/market with a taqueria in the back. Visiting some friends who live in the Mission, they told us that this was their go to spot for cheap, authentic, filling Mexican eats. Sign me up.

Seating is first come first serve on a few tables outside. You order inside, wait and hope a table outside will be open. I went with the suggested roast chicken burrito with spicy beans and guac. This is what dreams are made of. This is why I moved to California. The burrito was oh so smooth with a delicious homemade tortilla, tender roast chicken and creamy beans and rice. Yes! Everything about this was fresh and just so damn good. Room for improvement? Always. I wish it was a bit more spicy and that goes with the burrito overall. However, this was my first and only time visiting, so I need to revisit often to check out other menu items.

The man loved his roast chicken tacos, which in hindsight I think I'd get next time for a less heavy meal and one that focus on that roast chicken. Home made chicharonnes and other Mexican delights make this spot a must visit when on the search for authentic eats. 

A few other things: 
Looking for hot sauce? You have to buy the whole bottle if you want to sprinkle it on your burrito. Boo.
Looking to host your own taco party? You can buy everything by the pound. Carnitas meat to go, a lb of that guac or roast chicken, or a pint of beans. Buy it and bring it home and eat at your leisure.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Why LA PALMA Rocks:

1) Comfy, clean, shaded outdoor seating with lots of mural eye candy.

2) No frills breakfast burrito that killed the craving. The chorizo wasn't spicy (good for me, maybe not for you) but I didn't see much in the way of eggs. Good flavor though and I liked the guac ($9). 

3) Messiest chicken torta ever. Probably not fun to eat but fun to watch someone try to eat ($9).

4) Homemade tortillas, guac and salsas. If I was having a party, I'd definitely come back for these goodies. (A party of one anyone?)

5) Conveniently located near La Victoria's sugary goodness.
author: Amy C.

description:
Super delicious food in the mission! HELL YEAH!

I recently had a falling out with El Farolito and La Guadalajara, feeling like they weren't as good as they used to be! I was in search of a better place for some delicious mexican food!

La Palma is awesome! Their food is super delicious, and usually fast. The customer service is okay, but honestly their prices and food is what keeps me coming back. 
- The flauta plate was delicious, their quesadilla suiza was okay, it was a little too greasy for me. 
- The breakfast sandwich is tasty and will keep you full forever.
- The huaraches are very good and are freshly made in the morning! I like buying a pack of that and salsa and eat it with over easy eggs and lettuce and call it a day!

Here are a few tips:
- It is a really tiny spot and inside is all retail, there is seating for eating outside around the corner, as well as standing tables right upfront. So don't plan on dining fancy while you're here. 
- If you can take public transportation or just walk. It's in the mission, on 24th, near Potrero, so finding parking is nearly impossible during day time. 
- La Palma is a grocery store as well, so it can get hectic and crazy busy at times. 
- They have 3 counters which can get a little confusing, but the one all the way in the back on the right is where you place your order, the counter closer to the door, where they sell various chicharron is where you pick up your order. 
- They accept cards!
- If you know what you want, call ahead! The food is usually ready in 10-15 minutes and all you have to do is go to the first counter on your right and pick up and pay!
author: Jade C.

description: A little more than a month ago I hit this spot up on my San Francisco trip towards the end wanted to get another chance to have California Mexican food again, and since everything here in the Bay was so damn good I had to try it. My waiter at The Progress restaurant suggested it to us so I looked it up and saw a lot of positive reviews and man it didn't disappoint. In Chicago the best places for Mexican food are little hole in the wall mom and pop places some have been there for many many years. This spot seemed like that had the same feel, located in the mission district an old part of town it seemed, me and the wife hit it up early first meal of the day, good thing because this place gets packed and we got there before it did. No tables inside just about 4 outside 1 of them a stand up one, man this food was so legit! Homemade tortillas out of the tortilla maker, they even sell them there. Little grocery store inside, I ordered the mission style burrito ( they put rice and pinto beans inside in Chicago no rice and the beans refried ) delicious the steak inside was full of flavor, my wife ordered deep fried tacos with beef served with cabbage cheese and a chipotle style salsa, with some chicarron on the side too we shared. Food was so good I went back inside and ordered two more steak tacos to try on their homemade tortillas and those were bomb! Very memorable experience food wise, had a atole too ( Mexican hot  chocolate ) this was ok have had better. Saw the menudo and Pozole, and the guisados cant wait to visit again and eat here so I could try those next. Chicago has some of the best Mexican food on earth and I've eaten at so many good places here that's not including the home, this spot ranks pretty high on my list of spots I love.
author: Thomas R.

description: Every time I pass by this place it's busy, and I know why, their food is so goooood. If it's your first time there, I recommend a pupusa and a taco with chips and salsa.
author: Mina S.

description: La Palma rocked it! I recently ordered food for a work holiday party of 35 people. Terry was fantastic every step of the way. She helped me determine if I had the right amount of food since I had more than the 25-person pachanga trays, but less than for the large trays. We went with the Pachanga E, grilled veggies, agua fresca, and chocoflan. The food was excellent, lots of compliments, and the rice was authentic, none of that bland Americanized Mexican rice! We had a good amount of leftovers too! The food was ready on time, hot, packaged securely, and pickup was super easy. She had us drive up to the loading door, and her team helped carry everything to the car. I would absolutely order from them again!
author: Vanessa J.

description: It gets crowded but the food is fantastic. Your order is served fresh and hot. They have fresh chips and various salsas to go. The service is wonderful too.
author: Daniella D.

description:
If you're looking for good Mexican food, this is the place to go. I first encountered this place when I did a food tour of the Mission, and I had to come back to buy more of their huarache, which is made of masa. It's similar to a corn tortilla but stuffed with various things. I really like the blue corn based huarache, and some of my favorite stuffings are the spinach and cheese, and the beans and cheese. They come out fresh and hot, and you order your favorites at the counter.

If you're looking for Mexican food to take home, this is definitely the place to go.
author: Andrea G.

description:
The food is so good here! The prices are great! They have fresh made tortillas and salsas. 

I love the chicharrón, and the chile relleno daré to die for!!! 


My only complaint... they close so early!!! 

I need them to be open for my late night Mexican food cravings!!
author: desiree c.

description: Good place. Few places sell so many varieties of meats, cheese and salsas as La Palma. Your order is served fresh and hot and eating outside is like having a picnic.
author: Elijah P.

description: This was the perfect spot to end my night after a long day of standing around in heels trying to be cool at events that were not as great as my bed is. I got the shrimp burrito. Legit good burrito. I also got the Flan which was also on point. I will take this place over most of the fancy Mexican spots in the city any day.
author: Cynthia G.

description: Stopped by here for some yummy Mexican food and it did not disappoint. I got an asada taco plate and also some bean and cheese pupusas. The tortillas here are incredibly fresh and I've never had tastier pupusas. The woman who took our order was also very patient and helpful with us. The only thing that would've made my experience better would've been if they had tried to make the orders come altogether. My order came out first and then it was cold by the time everything else got there, which was a while later. So maybe skip if you're in a rush, or order ahead if you can. But definitely worth the visit!
author: Mary H.

description: Nice selection of groceries for making them yourself. The tortillas are amazing and the pupusas are very good also. It gets crowded sometimes.
author: Alexia C.

description: They have fresh chips and various salsas to go, and of course the tortilla are amazing. Great place to grab a dinner for a small party.
author: Hanna D.

description: Love this place! Wish it was closer to my house but that would be dangerous! Love the people making the tortillas and can never pass up getting a bag of warm tortillas!
author: Legend R.

description: Clean, fast service and tasty food. I had the enchilada plate and an horchata. The food was great however I didn't care for the horchata it was served without ice and tasted bland. Also, this place was packed when we went so there was limited seating available, unfortunately we had to stand and eat at the two front tables.
author: Anna G.

description: Great food and nice ppl. Very generous portions as well. Had a breakfast burrito and a torta and we were happy with both. It is nice that they make the chips and tortillas in house
author: Dan K.

description: 10-09-2017 01:43 pm place an Oder over the phone for 2 pupusas cashier ARACELLI said  ten minutes got there  and waited extra twenty minutes when I ask ARACELLI  the cashier how much more time she got upset and requested to cancel my order for that they deserve no star but no choice
author: Art R.

description: Good place to get lunch or a snack to go if you crave Mexican food.From carnitas to full plates a good spot to eat.
author: Cecilia N.

description:
Y'all know what a delicatessen is?  It's a term meaning "delicacies" or "fine foods, or specially prepared food. La Palma is just like that but the Mexican equivalent.  It's a Mexicatessen, so much good looking baked goods, ready-made meats like chicharron, fresh made tortillas, and all the foodie eye candy I could handle.  

While I wanted to buy half the stuff in La Palma I chose to just order a burrito.

Chicharron Super Burrito:  it was decent in size. The ingredients were mixed together nicely.  As every yelper mentions about this place, the tortillas are nice, chewy, and fresh.  A nice touch.  The flavors were great.  The only complaint was the burrito had a ton of orange grease.  It was a little unsettling but hey, it tasted fine.

The Mexicatessan is packed with employees helping customers.  Also busy making those fresh tortillas they are so famous for.  Overall 4 stars worthy as a great place for Mexican ingredients, and 3 star worthy spot for a average but decent burrito.
author: Michael L.

description:
Stepping into this Mexicatessen, I felt the homely taqueria shop that this place offered!

They offer freshly made tortillas as well as having a side mini grocery section that has stacked up pre-packaged tortillas, compelling fresh guacamole and salsas to purchase!

I loved their Pupusas, Tamales and Tacos! They have Chicharrons and Quesadillas as well! There is dining outdoors.  

I love me some La Palma Mexicatessen!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Great spot to get fresh tortillas! Also tried the chicharrones...crispy and nicely flavored.
author: Cindy N.

description:
My food experience was good. Ladies behind the counter can be a little harsh, but hell, they are fucking busy. Did you see that line?
So,, long story short, I ordered my chicharrone burrito and a small package or flour tortillas for later. Tortillas were killer, btw.
Burrito was awesome. Great flavor.
The problem was my boyfriend's burrito. It was all bone and gristle. Seriously. It was bizarre. 
They sell all their sauces and tortillas so you can take them with you. Everything but the tortillas was pretty pricey, but if the place was good, I would have definitely come back to buy some.
Will never come back because of my fella's experience, Bones in your burrito. Seriously?
author: Kat R.

description:
The "restaurant" is inside a small deli so there is no sit down area. Just grab and go.

Inside, they sell individually packaged ingredients so that you can make the burritos/tacos/etc. at home.  If you're like me though and lack DIY burrito skills, head straight to the back for their menu and to order. After you order, return to the front of the store, pay, and wait for your delicious meal.

The super burrito I had was delicious. Special shout out to the flour tortilla. A-maz-ing.
author: Yanni L.

description:
Went back again to this place since the last time i visited the bay area 5 months ago, and nothing has changed. Still the sketchy Mission, Still the cashier mumbling, still the same Delicious ass Burito from months earlier.

Seriously, this place is money. I had a burrito at like 8am, which is 5am on my usual hawaii time and i aint even mad about it. 

I ate maybe 3/4 of it because its so freaking big and perfect in every sense of the word. I'm flying up again in December and im finishing a veggie La Palma burrito, for sure.
author: Ella A.

description: I ordered to be picked up. Had the carnitas tacos since I love their handmade tortillas. I have to say I was disappointed. The place next door is 1928386477737 times better. The carnitas were so dry. And the flautas I ordered were so gross. Not my favorite place anymore
author: Ramiro P.

description:
You know what? This is it.
Cheap good Mexican food. That is it.
Nothing more nothing less.
Love their huarache with chile verde.... Nothing beats this.
author: Minkoo K.

description: This place is rocking every minute they are open.  I ordered from the catering menu.  Pick up was so smooth, I could have skated.  Terri and group are friendly and pay close attention to detail.  They called with questions to confirm the order.  The food....OUT OF THIS WORLD.  Serioulsy $300 and fed a group of 30 with leftovers.  Packaging was perfect too.
author: Mo C.

description: La Palma used to be great.  In recent history, it has really gone down hill.
author: Katie J.

description: Morning tortas are the best! Excellent meal for those of us hungry at 11am. They sell complete meals as well as cooked rice, fried/grilled meat and guacamole by pounds. They have Mexican cheese too. I recall menu said that they serve tilapia on the weekends
author: Ilmia N.

description:
My favorite Mexican comfort food establishment in SF. Definitely the best Chilequiles I've had anywhere ever, better then the places I tried in Mexico City! Try it with chicken and eggs, both the red sauce and green sauce are excellent! Most of the time I just order the Chile Verde plate, it's so simple and so good!!
Chile Verde Pork so tender and juicy in perfectly spicy tomatillo sauce, complimented with simple rice and refried beans cooked with lard and the freshest tortillas made by the old Mexican Ladies. It is so perfect. I'm getting hungry now
author: Chris M.

description: Came here for pupusas, but they were just ok. The picked toppings were to vinegary and the pupusa was blan. They have great chips and tortillas though.
author: Michelle B.

description:
yes this place is super small and always (it seems) busy...but the food is so good. fresh made tortillas, chicharrones para morirse, carnitas... everything I've had here has been great. 
I also used them to cater a work event and it was a hit. 
you will not be sad if you eat here.
author: Ryan F.

description: For take-out burritos only: They are absolutely delicious but they're often served warm and not hot: One time the cheese wasn't even melted.
author: Better Not Bitter 1.

description:
I can go on and on about La Palma as I do to my friends but I will literally not stop raving about this place if I go on about writing it. So point blank- La Palma is hands down THE BEST Mexican food I have ever had. Burritos- excellent; Tacos-excellent; Sopes-amazing; Taco Dorados- amazing; Flautas-magical; and I have never had carnitas that was so mouth watering that I can crave it any time of the week. I am so serious about La Palma. This place is amazing. I love coming here for breakfast/ brunch on the weekends.

Oh, and BTW it's more like a grocery store/ taqueria so there's no seating inside but they do have outdoor seating. CHECK THIS PLACE OUT!!!!
author: Dara S.

description: Best tortillas and masa in the city, and super cheap. They have really improved our taco game from the typical grocery store options. Worth the trip!
author: Aaron L.

description:
Food: 5.0
Ambiance: 2.0
Food/Price: 5.0


Pros: Insanely delicious food, offers small grocery/market items, CHEAP, Burritos so good they will induce food rage

Cons: Ambiance is a little dirty and is quite crowded.

Had a local not recommended this place I wouldn't have even looked twice at La Palma an unassuming corner market/fooderie in SF's mission district. No contest there are flashier store fronts, more minimalist, more hipster, more modern, more Mexican, but this place's rotisserie chicken burrito is a force to be reckoned with. I've eaten Mexican from Florida, North Carolina, Texas, Southern California you name it, but I've never had Mexican this good. 

So good was this burrito deep in my belly welled a singular rage and I had to resist ,with bovine aplomb, the urge to dash it against the pavement and then my head to obliterate even the memory of this heavenly savor. But I possessed neither the will nor the way and pounded gluttonously this diabolical melange of beans and meat and rice and guac, forever casting into the gustatory abyss any Mexican comestible that would henceforth grace my palate. This is warning weary traveler to never go near this place for the sake of food posterity and your eternal soul.

Also this burrito was only like $7 and it was massive! Easily two meals, maybe even three for the average skinny-jeaned hipster.
author: Jarrod S.

description:
Really good burrito. It's a shame I didn't notice the outdoor seating around the corner until after I had finished standing out front to eat my burrito. Kinda wish they served tortilla chips and water or something with the burrito like a restaurant, but I get that this is more of a Mexican deli/store that just happens to serve hot food, not so much a restaurant.

More about the burrito: It had one of the best tortillas I've ever had. It was really soft and some parts were brown and flaked off nicely. I got mine with black beans, rice, cheese, sour cream, guacamole, and I believe there was pico de gallo in there, too. The basic meatless burrito option. Really tasty. I asked for a side of hot salsa and got some green salsa. Kinda wished there were more salsa options, but they probably want you to buy the salsas they have available.

Probably a great spot for locals, not so much for anyone looking for a restaurant/taqueria. Still, I'd happily get a burrito from this place again when I'm in the area.
author: P A U L.

description:
Truly I love(d) this place, but I'm disappointed in the consistency of the quality here. I've done nothing but rave about their carnitas torta to my bf for ages, and we finally had a chance to go last week. It did not live up to my memory, but I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and assume it was a slip and not a general downward trend.

* Carnitas torta - 3 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-palma-mexicatessen-san-francisco?select=FkGWfb_ciIx7wuVyQqN4yQ#FkGWfb_ciIx7wuVyQqN4yQ
The bread: not as fresh or as much toasted crunch as before. The meat: a lot less than before! And more dry in texture. The fixings: now comes with this random giant slab of cheese, less avocado (and less fresh). Overall decent but not the amazing 5 star torta I remember from last time (~1 year ago).

* Pork taco on a hard shell - 3 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-palma-mexicatessen-san-francisco?select=FkGWfb_ciIx7wuVyQqN4yQ#d9dAE9CK69V6l-ul1cHHBw
Not out-of-this-world, not terrible either. Comes with refried beans and lettuce. The shell is not super crispy but has a good crunch when you bite into it and is pretty thick. There isn't a huge proportion of meat in the taco and it's all squished to one side - need to work on even distribution. Overall not bad but I wouldn't go out of my way to recommend this.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
OG stuff here. 
If you live in SF, care for what's been here to eat, and just love amazingly flavored food for cheap. This is a rite of passage. 
I would eat here everyday if I can.
author: Andy L.

description:
salam dustan man daram be zaban persian type mikonam.
bebekhshid age hame nemitonan bekhonan .
jaee khobie vali amn anraftam .
author: Salman A.

description:
I have to admit, I did not know what a Mexicatessen was before visiting La Palma. Now I know. Good quality Mexican eats for a meal or a party. Authentico (? is that a word?), from the tortilla's to carnitas & accompaniments. A burrito to the fixings for a party of 10, La Palma delivers.

This aint 24th Street Noe Valley style, its da inner Mission wit da flava to match. Try it, you'll like it!
author: Matsuo U.

description:
BEST CHICKEN BURRITO EVER STILL!

If I had one LAST meal int he world, it would probably be La Palma's Super Chicken Burrito and Phil'z Mint Mojito Coffee.  Both are crack, no joke. Put them together, and it will give you superpowers for sure! 

I still remember the day I took my first bite of La Palma's super chicken burrito. It was LOVE at first sight. The angels sang as the flavors all melted together in harmony. I was hooked! 

Give it a try. They make everything fresh in-house. Quality and taste like no other!
author: Ellen W.

description:
DAMN Their tamales are HUGE. No wonder why they're $3+. They're tasty as hell too, but I still slathered them with hot sauce.

It's cramped inside and a bit confusing to order and pick up. I wish they were able to fix their layout somehow.. I'll be back.
author: Susy C.

description:
Would definitely come back here! Large menu where you go to the back to order then pay upfront and wait for your meal. It functions as a food place and a small store. I know they're known for their chicharron but I was not able to try it. 

I went on a tuesday afternoon after a meeting and it wasn't too busy. The prices stated on yelp are incorrect, as they have been raised. I would say things have increased by about $2 but even then, everything is reasonably priced.

I got the tacos dorados with potato and a cheese pupusa.

Damnnnn was this good. Even though I had a long commute home which made the tacos a little soggy, they were amazing. The meal was around $8 but it was big portions as it came with three tacos, rice and beans. The potato tacos were nicely seasoned and was even better with the red sauce and cabbage that came on top of it. The pupusas were near $2 each and were pretty good. 

This place is kind of far for me but I will be back.
author: Guilliana J.

description: Expected more from this area. The agua Fresca was absolutely incredible, but burrito was just alright and the pupusas leave a lot to be desired. It's priced right though, so I'll give them that. I'd be willing to put it in my lunch rotation if I lived nearby but it would never be in my list of favorites.
author: Cole I.

description:
Been here before but unfortunately didn't know about the birria on weekends. but I love this place to buy masa and other items. It's more like a little grocery store to get all your Mexican cooking needs with a take out section in the back. Will definitely have to return for the birria soon.
 Value 4/5
Atmosphere 3/5
Service 4/5
Quality 4.5/5

16.5/20
author: Nina S.

description:
Handmade tortilla! 
Lengua taco in fresh corn tortilla .. Yum
Lots of pork fried goodness around this place with ton of fresh tortillas to go with it. It's a small mkt so get all the cheese fixings as well!
author: Linda T.

description: I don't know what these guys put in their handmade tortillas but they are pretty much the best thing in the world.  I would eat a big stack of those tortillas plain.
author: Lukas B.

description:
They had a line to get into La Palma the weekend before Christmas.  They have Christmas colored chips!  Red, Green, Regular ones in a big bag.

No nacatamales when I went!  Hard to know when they have them.  I must pre-order them I guess.

I got 2 sweet corn tamales to eat at home.  $1.65 ea.  Just ok.

Blue corn veggie tamales a doz $28.68.  tried one it's the weird squishy cheese that's tofu-like & some peppers.  It tasted ok.

I forgot to ask about the Heirloom corn tortillas!  next time.

Charged it.
author: Ann L.

description:
This was taco 3 out of 6 on our taco tour of the Mission area. We ranked this spot the last at #6. The taco itself was decent, we got the chicken but I didn't think it was too memorable. Mostly, the experience was overshadowed by the confusing chaos in the store. Not sure if it was an off day, although the customers were pushing around the store as if this was the norm. There are 3 stations: one to order, one to pay, and one to pick up your food. This did not speed up the process as it should-- instead, it seemed like it confused the employees even more on who ordered what. It took us ~20-25 minutes to pick up just one taco. The time we were there, we just stood at the side observing it all. There were two orders switched, one lady hadn't received her food and was complaining, multiple orders had to be remade because the customers never got their food, and we saw the employees call out for at least 5 orders that no one claimed. 

I would try it again during a time that isn't so busy, I guess.
author: Hideko T.

description: This place has legitimate Mexican food. My "must go" for tortillas, guac, and salsas.  Tortillas are made fresh around the clock daily - bag is always full of steaming/warm tortillas as I walk out with my package.  Can't beat that for fresh!
author: Rachael S.

description:
This place is simply wonderful- delicious food and great service!  I ordered the taco bar from their catering menu for an event, and they required very little notice (the morning of) for ordering. The prices were reasonable, and we got SO MUCH food!  They packaged things well so nothing spilled or leaked during transport, and the staff there even helped me put all the food in the car trunk.  The food was very fresh with nice authentic flavors, everyone at the event said it was some the best food they've had in a while, 

There are plenty of food places in the Mission and I have tried many, this one is definitely on the top of my list!
author: Sarah W.

description:
I was blown away by how bad this was.....and that's the first time in over 200 reviews I've said that!  I found this place via YELP and it had a ranking of 4 1/2 stars.  I've posted a pic of all the gristle and bones I pulled from my carnitas burrito this afternoon.  These pieces were either cartilege you couldn't bite through, or full blown pieces of bone (2).  After all that the taste was ok though.....But that's little satisfaction.
The lay out, and ordering process, is chaotic when there's only 5 customers.  I can only imagine what it's like during mealtime.  They advertised locally sourced ingredients for their food but when I asked where the cilantro came from they had no idea?  (Recent food poisonings over Cilantro from Mexico)
They sell beer, and have seating, but you can't consume beer with your food?
What were the other people that reviewed this place thinking?  I have no idea....I will never return, and I'll make sure no one I know goes here for sure!
author: Jim P.

description:
I love this market/ restaurant. 

Their chicharon options are so good and they hit the spot eveyrtime. 

I also come here for the flautas, chips and of course their daily made fresh tortillas
author: Sol P.

description:
Love me a good Mexicatessen. Everything's made in-house at La Palma, and everybody knows it.

I've waited in line wrapped around the outside of the building to get a Carne Aasda Super Burrito plus a side of rice and beans (really?? Yes, it's that good) and chicharrones for later.

They must use extra lovin' (or extra lard, the jury is out on that one) in their tortillas because they are truly amazing and totally crave worthy. Always a fan of their Carne Asada and Carnitas burritos, the combo of rice, whole or refried beans, guac, and salsa is just right by me.
author: Crystal C.

description:
I went there expecting to taste their yummy breakfast burrito and got a big disappointment. The breakfast burrito consist of Chorizo,egg,potatoes,rice&beans...thats it...Pure perfection and of course a little avocate and crema wouldn't hurt. But No.....There was no egg and no potatoes which if not for the hunger and the chorizo I would have went back.
Can we make sure the ingredients are always the same, especially if that's what you are advertising.
No hating,  just a little constructive criticism.


Keep it Brown
author: Tee D.

description: Haley and I stopped by after a nice day of walking Rex from Crissy fields to the Golden Gate Bridge.  Had the regular and super burritos and they were filled with good meat, toppings, lots of flavors and very cheap. I can understand why they have so many reviews, we will be back for sure.
author: Hugo E.

description: I was taken here by my friend who moved to this city this past year. I was in town for last minute Christmas shopping and way dying for good food. La Palma was amazing! Sure, those who prefer a modern style of place may not like La Palma, but you can't substitute quality and heritage. Not only do they sell food, but they also sell Hispanic groceries and homemade tortillas, which by the way are used with any of the food you order that comes or is made with tortillas. I had a roasted chicken burrito super, and it was amazing! I heard the sweet corn tamales were just as great, unfortunately they were out when I went. I will be making La Palma a stop whenever I am in the City and craving real Mexican food and dining in an authentic San Francisco taqueria.
author: Zachary D.

description: Update: La Palma no longer selling Nacatamales.  The current price for one dozen tamales is $30.00.
author: Suzanne M.

description: This place is amazing! My wife and I are dedicated fans. I had the goat taco and blew my mind. Hole in the wall joints are always amazing.
author: Benni D.

description: So I am 22 now but u have been coming here since I was in the third grade... I would always get the SAME thing a burrito with just beans and rice... was never more than 5 dollars! So today I decided I wanted one... and I paid 8.25! For a tortilla beans and rice!!! The lady asked me if no meat I said no not even cheese. So she said she had to give it to me as a regular burrito but with out the meat or anything... I looked at her confused. Another lady comes over and gives the option of a bean and cheese burrito... I said sure I want to replace the cheese with rice she said she had to charge me extra... and I said okay well I don't see why if I was always charged less than 5 dollars for the same burrito for YEARS! now I paid $8.25 for a bean and rice burrito ! This use to be my favorite place to go to. But if all these white folks with money moving to the mission affected the price of a bean and rice burrito thanks but no thanks.
author: Kassandra V.

description:
Woooooo. Man. Wow. I could eat here everyday. Well ok, I could but not for that long because my heart would eventually get clogged with chicharrones but the brightest stars also burn fastest. And this place shines.

Ok stop shaking your head. I apologize. La Palma is a mexican deli (get the name?) and they have wonderful carnitas. Don't think cracklings. Think chopped fried carnitas ends. Wonderful chopped fried carnitas ends. I got two tacos on their homemade tortillas which were nice and fluffy providing a good contrast to the crispy pig parts.

This is now tied for first for my favorite mexican place is the bay area. The other being La Tapatia in South City, which coincidentally is also a deli (and makes the greatest torta ever) .
author: Misha T.

description:
Is very delicious the fish taco I love it. 
Fresh tortillas and the people is very nice
author: Aide M.

description: Great place.  The food was amazing and very authentic.  Prices were affordable if not cheap. Definitely try the huaraches for the salsa, guacamole and cream.
author: Thadeus K.

description:
Still the best place I've found in SF to buy tamale ingredients.  They have paper, string, prepared masa (several kinds), corn husks, salsas, chiles, carnitas, chicken....pretty much everything. The hand made tortillas, sopes, and huaraches are also amazing. I especially love the nopales tortillas, which I've never seen anywhere else.  They have great flavor, and seem to last longer in the fridge than the regular or blue corn tortillas.

Now that the Mission has gone all upscale, they serve prepared food and have some tables outside. This must be a huge money maker for them, and most likey the food is good (but I've never actually tried it, so can't say for sure.)

After you get your stuff, go to the cashier to pay. Whoever is at the paper counter will probably ring you up if you speak Spanish (even badly.) Otherwise wait in the line just to the right after you walk in.

PS You can't buy your lemon flavored hashish outside anymore- too upscale. Maybe you can get whatever you need to vape from a street vendor tho?
author: El B.

description:
Donde Estoy?

Being a San Franciscan that was born and raised here, I felt like a total foreigner in La Palma Mexicatessen. I walk in and see three counters with no number dispensing machine in sight (as per Yelp reviews). I go around in circles like a touron until I see what seems to be a regular just walk in so I follow him; yup, hella stalker status! He orders in Spanish, gets a number, pays at another counter and picks up his food when his number is called. Damn, I'm stoopid.

COUNTER #1:
*Chicharrons (by the pound): skin, skin with meat and skin with attached fat.
*Tamales
*Nacatamales (A Nicaraguan tamale that's larger than the typical tamale and filled with meat, potatoes, tomato paste and rice)

COUNTER #2 (back counter): THE KITCHEN
The entire menu is in Spanish but the employees do speak English and will be happy to help you.
*Burritos
*Tacos
*Quesadillas
*Tortas
*Enchiladas
*Papusas
*Roast Chicken
*Weekend Menu: Birria (Goat Stew) and Menudo (Tripe Stew)

Catering is available. 

COUNTER #3: THE MARKET LINE
*Fresh Handmade Tortillas (still warm): Flour, Harina, Spinach, Tomato and Blue Corn 
*Tortilla Chips 
*Salsas and Guacamole 
*Chorizo
*Cojita Cheese
*Masa: Corn, Cactus, Blue Corn and Sweet 
*Corn Husks and Banana Leaves

Almost everything is sold by the pound. CC's accepted.

WANT TO ORDER FOOD?
Go to Counter #2 (back counter) to place your order and you will be given a ticket number. Pay and pick-up order at Counter #1 (to the right when you walk in). 
CHICHARRON BURRITO w/ Guacamole ($5.89 + .75 for guacamole) - 3.5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/bNvaWa9wSLHjlFlrD7i9Ow?select=fB6K7YnzoZkP8sAechgzqw
I love chicharrons and lately I've been on a crazy Mexican food hiatus so I thought this combo would be out of this world. However, the most unlikely ingredient outshined the chicharron...THE TORTILLA! Yup, you read right! The harina tortilla was unlike any you would find at a regular taqueria. It was thick, soft and chewy with a rich consistency. HELLO LARD! I could have eaten this alone with salsa and be a happy camper; it was THAT good!

As far as the filling, the chicharron was very sparse. The heat from the seasoned rice and refried beans softened the chicharron causing it to lose its crackling crunch so it tasted more like salty pork jerky.

I also bought a tub of Salsa de Guacamole. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/bNvaWa9wSLHjlFlrD7i9Ow?select=3-VodcFXM5OxqpO-JohmoA The salsa de guacamole was like an avocado cream that was seamlessly thick, rich and buttery; perfect as an accompaniment if you want to add a buttery layer. My only gripe is I wish there was more of a citrus (i.e. lime) component to brighten up the flavors.  

Next time, I'm going back just for the chicharron and the harina tortillas so I can make my own chicharron soft tacos. Pure Pork Fat + Lard? Life's NEVER been so good...JUST FAT!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Goodness gracious, the burrito I had here was AWESOME AWESOME AWESOME.

It is not centrally located if you're visiting and when I went with my family, I was still a bit full from the last meal we ate. However, I had to go here and try out the burrito. 

I usually never eat burritos unless I'm really craving for it but man this Mexicatessen is so unassuming that I would never expect they're serving out food. But yes they do and great food at that. I ordered the burrito with chicarones for $6 and change. I see the burrito and it is huge. Really they give you more than a generous portion.

First bite. WOW. Those chicharones were seasoned and cooked to perfection. Now I'm no expert in the art of burritos but honestly La Palma has the best burrito I've ever eaten. Maybe I'll find another burrito that's better but every burrito I eat from now on will be measured to the one I ate here.
author: Raymart D.

description:
My first mission burrito was from La Palma, on a vacation in 2010. Husband and I looked at each other with huge eyes and mouths full of carnitas and al pastor and knew we'd be back someday. Five years later we live in strolling distance of the Mission, we've tried most of its taquerias and La Palma is still hands down the best. Is it the magical way the ingredients meld together? Or the moist, amazing meats (including smoky rotisserie chicken for a mindblowing super burrito)? No, it's the housemade tortilla, rich, soft and chewy with lard.

If that weren't great enough, La Palma is also a grocery store where you can stock up on chiles, salsas, quesos, crema and those addictive tortillas. Making tamales? Get your masa and husks here. Need 10 lbs of carnitas for your party? La Palma has you covered. Or just order a burrito, grab a seat in the sun and contemplate how good life is.
author: Cecilia L.

description: Delicious pupusas. Super authentic. Good sized supermarket with so many choices. Large kitchen in the back to make fresh food.
author: Felicia F.

description:
I love this place for the stuff I can take home: the ceviche, the guacamole, the fresh salsa, the mole sauces... all house made and fresh, ready to go in the deli fridge by the check-out.  I am also in love with the various stuffed tortillas and flat tortillas.  I love to bring home a bag of them, put them in the fridge, and eat them one at a time for lunch topped with the salsa and guacamole.  I hope they never stop making these things!

The take-out food is also really good.  I love the chile rellenos especially.  It is nice to sit outside and eat on a warm day. 

I do think that this place is more special as a Mexicatessin than as a restaurant. I would recommend going there to grocery-shop, and picking up some take out while you are there. Going there just for the take out? Yep, I've done it and did not regret it! But there are places with equally awesome take out near by.  The mexicatessin goods however, are the best I've tasted anywhere.

And while you are in the neighborhood, go across the street to La Victoria bakery and stock up on all your baked goods! Breads, desserts, pastries, rolls...  and all those yummy pan dulce breakfast breads.

It's an awesome shopping area, you can get everything you need within a block!
author: katie s.

description: Everything is made here, the tortillas are amazing! I think my favorite are the taco senoras!
author: Muhammad U.

description:
Best place to buy tortillas. Far better than what you find in a grocery store. They also have yummy chips, salsa, and guacamole. 

If I go here for lunch, I always get a torta- so good! 

Service is pretty quick, and whenever I ask someone a question, they are very helpful!
author: Maggie D.

description: Have been a regular at la Palma for a while. It's definitely more of a to go kind of spot although there's a few seats outdoors. It's basically a market with a taco shop in the back. Great taco plates.
author: Natalie S.

description:
What I ate: Tacos suave (one with chicharones and another with chicken verde) with everything, Sunkist in a bottle!
Visit date: October 13, 2011
First time? Yes, and you'll be seeing me again!

La Palma, you are my hero! You are mouth watering perfection and everything my taste buds desire. The chicken in the chicken verde is tender; the chicharones are good and salty. But what makes the tacos (in my opinion) is the aaaamaaazing salsa!! It's so fresh and so green, green...and spicy, too. The tacos were so good I started talking to them, telling them how good they were. Too much? Go try them for yourself before you call me crazy.

Bonus! Sunkist in a bottle! That was a first for me. I do love my Sunkist and think soda should always be packaged in a bottle.

The smell of fresh tortillas reel you into the store and then you're thankful you decided to listen to your nose!
author: Erin G.

description: This place it's ridiculous! They charged me $3 to keep the meat out of my burrito and put in the side. I cannot believe it. Ridiculous!
author: Nida K.

description:
I haven't been here since I was a youngster. My uncle is a dentist and had a practice in the Mission for many years. My Mom would take me in to get my teeth checked and when we left we would stop by La Palma for fresh tortillas, tamales and fresh bread. 

Fast forward to the present day and we found ourselves here on the hunt for fresh tortillas. A few options for us. Bagged up but still warm tortillas or fresh, handmade while you wait?? Handmade for sure. See, back in the days a dozen handmade corn tortillas served up piping hot wouldn't even make it home. Mom and I would kill em on the drive home. This time around they were for dinner later in the evening and sadly, they just were not the same when we warmed them up. 

Service was exceptional, the place is small but loaded with goods. We also walked away with freshly ground chile pasilla, which will be making an appearance in my secret BBQ rub next time around.
author: Hector G.

description:
The torta that I tried was so good!
My boyfriend got mole & he loved it!
Just the way my mom makes it 
Really good& the horchata was yummy 
Recommend!
Oh & really nice people too
author: Victoria F.

description: AMAZING Mexican groceries and restaurant... Yes, please!!! My partner & I just moved to SF/Cali and we're worried because all the tortillas in the stores around us were gross.com! Low & behold this place makes their own tortillas AND uses them to accompany some pretty great tasting food! Their lengua is the best I've had in the area... Just everything about this place is awesome. It gets hella packed, but it's worth it. That chicharrón they be having tho... fire!
author: David F.

description: This place is amazing! Best mexican food in the mission!! Please don't go lol jk I want to keep it the best kept secret in town.
author: Samantha L.

description: I wouldn't recommend this place to my worse enemy. I bought some chicharrones and it was very dry, salty and chewy. Not at all fresh. Must've sitting under the heat lamp all day. I tried to ask for some fresher batch but they acted like they didn't understand what I was saying. I also ordered a steak super burrito on spinach flour and they didn't have any. So I asked for wheat, they didn't have that either. Overall I was very disappointed!!!
author: Michelle M.

description:
I went in for get some food for lunch.
I ordered the stuffed bell pepper with meat.
They didn' t have any ready and I asked for the cheese bell pepper plus a small side of meat since I paid for it.The girl behind the counter said it was ok.I left with my food to go and when I opened I had 5 piece of meat, ( colorado) a tiny side of rice and beans with 3 tortillas.I paid almost 9 dollars for the meat dish, plus tips and they served me a dish worth 5-6 dollars.The food was good.Staff were polite,  the place was clean though.I have to decide if I will eat there again tho. :/ probably not.
author: Érica T.

description:
Never really been to southern America, so I cannot tell you if it's authentic. 
BUT... La Palma makes awesome and super delicious tacos, pupusa for sure. 
Cannot stop loving Mexican cuisine... Finally get a chance to stop by mission for some La Palma. Dxxn, handmade soft corn tortilla is sooooooooo good! With all other flavorful ingredients (carnitas, beans, guacamole, salsa...) it's a perfection. 
I wish I live close by mission dist. So I can have more delicious Mexican food.
author: JustinE Y.

description:
Everything I have tried is awesome here.  They're the tortillas fresh, and they have a small grocery selling the tortillas and other top notch authentic tasty goods.  
The quasi dills are particularly good
author: Michael F.

description:
There's a reason why La Palma is the best Mexicatessen in SF. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/la-palma-mexicatessen-san-francisco?userid=8Ces6YdT6j7BYycnZLrSng#CVOJnPyYq2vqRi4cenn4zQ They know their customers, and take care of the extra little details that keep customers coming back. One example, unlike other shops the chicharron (not pork rinds) is already cut into smaller pieces and sorted: con cuero (with skin), con carne (meaty), con sebo (fatty). While still charging the same competitive prices ($7.50/lb.). Home cooks can then simply toss the pieces into a stew, without the extra work of cutting and fat trimming. Also a great place to buy food for catering parties (pachanga trays, serves 25). 

Most reviews talk about the ready to eat foods (tacos, burritos, tortas, quesadillas, enchiladas, huaraches, sopes, pupusas, roast chicken, etc.) from the menu in the back, as if this were simply another taqueria. Not many realize that this shop's main business is to supply meats, stews, handmade tortillas, spices, and other ingredients to cook at home or for wholesale to other busniesses.

Almost every single SF taco truck buys their tortillas from this store. Excellent handmade quality and super cheap. Ready to quit your job and start a street food taco business? u come here to buy the taco ingredients.

Hours:
Mon-Sat 8am-6pm
Sun 8am-5pm
author: Luis C.

description:
Market with taqueria in the back with limited seating outside!

But the tortillas are hand made and the Carne Asada burrito was delicious!!!! Yummy!
author: Lauren T.

description: I placed an order through Door Dash and surprisingly this place opens up at 8:45am. We ordered 3 carne asada tacos, 1 chicken tacos, regular carne asada burrito and chicken flautas meal. The food was good and my daughter loved the tacos. It's tasted FRESH and our stomachs were happy. I'd recommend the tacos from here than other taqueria restaurants. They also gave us salsa on the side which was perfect with the tacos and flautas. The delivery was fast and came right before the 9:00am as scheduled...
author: Wena D.

description:
La Palma Mexicatessen is one compact Mexican deli. Colorful too.

For its size, La Palma manages to jam tons of goods and people in, as well as fresh offerings like handmade tortillas, chicharron con cuero, and a pupusa-like dish whose name escapes me. My friend picked up pre-prepared items, while I made sure to grab a bottle of pineapple Jarritos to go - so refreshing!

Staff here work fast to keep everyone moving. Bring cash, though credit cards are accepted.
author: Dave L.

description:
Terrible service and expensive food. 

You have to buy salsa separately- in a tub. And a huge bag of chips- Costco size--  and we got dirty looks for asking for 2 plates and forks!!!! We were a huge party, 8 adults, ordered a good amount of food and had terrible service. The food was ok, not good enough to make up for the barely-there rude-when-available service.
author: S R.

description:
This is THE place to go if you like chicharron, and the flour tortillas are delicious too.

* Taco Solano with Chili Rellano Pork (4.50) - The solano taco is more like a small quesadilla than a taco, filled with all the same ingredients plus rice, and is double the size of a taco. Chili Rellano is a tender pork that comes in large chunks, wish they used more meat. But overall, very wholesome and filling, just one is enough to fill the hungriest person up!

* Quesadilla Suiza with Chicharron ($6) - Unlike Taqueria Cancun's, this place serves the lettuce, sour cream, and other toppings on the side. If you like that semi crispy / chewy texture of chicharron, you definitely need to order your item with chicharron. It's a good deal, and a large portion, but not quite as gigantic / cheesy / meaty as the ones at Cancun, which obviously is the bar for Mexican Food in the Mission.

I got both of these for less than $12 after tax (they accept Visa and Mastercard), what a deal!
author: Jess C.

description: I found this place on random Thursday afternoon. I ordered a Taco of carnitas it was a bit of a wait but well worth it. The meat was juicy, tender, and well flavored. The tortilla it was in was delicious. I ate ever bit of it. The whole thing was a little over $3.00. This place a great value and I am coming back to try the pre cooked Chicharon with meat on it!
author: Gabriel B.

description: Really good Mexican Food. Fresh made Tortillas (not many places around). Recommended from this Mexican.
author: Roberto H.

description: Do they make good food here?  I don't know.  We keep coming here to buy masa to make home made tortillas.  That blue corn masa is amazing.  The tacos I make with that mountain of playdough are to die for.
author: Oliver D.

description:
This is the best burrito place in the city by far. Even though I call it a burrito place it had some of the best all around Mexican food in the bay. The homemade tortillas make everything that much better and the chicherones are insanely great. 

Try the haurachas they are perfect.
author: Mark Y.

description: Best chicharrones in SF.  They make their tortillas fresh.  Great quality Mexican food.  Everything I've had there has been really good from the enchiladas, flautas, tacos, etc...I like coming in there and picking up tortillas and other general goods for the home.
author: Danny H.
