description: I love this place. Fresh tortillas and most importantly chicharron!!! Do yourself a favor and order the chicharron with anything or even by itself, this is not for the faint of heart so if fried food and fat scare you simply don't order this, but if you're going to skip the diet for a day, this is my food drug of choice. It can be a bit confusing how the place works but there are always people around and someone will certainly guide you, it's not a place to be shy. Everything is good I promise.
author: Guisela L.

description: This is a place where no matter what you order you will be happy. Great service, clean, outdoor seating, delicious, delicious, delicious! Highly recommended: gorditas, tacos dorados and the chicharron! Best Mexican food on 24th street.
author: Riley C.

description:
Came by here this morning to get some tamales for Christmas Eve.  The line was around the corner.  We see a line, we get in it.

No, wait!  It's the line for the masa.  If you want to make your own tamales.

Not us!  We got in the lazy people's line and ordered seven tamales.   No, wait.  If you order a dozen, there's a price break. Okay, throw in five more pork (she said it's their most popular) and I'll freeze them.

We tried the chicken, the pork, the beef and the chicken mole.  The only one kinda dry and boring was the plain chicken one,  the pork were the best.  We didn't freeze anything.  We ate  it all.

We also ordered a super burritto and it was excellent.

Across the street at La Victoria we got some Mexican wedding cookies and some macaroons.
author: Foodlover B.

description: i adore this place, my favourites are the pupusas and tamale plates, quick service, outdoor seating and you know its great because its always busy!
author: Belle P.

description: Good, but needs to get the health score up for me to give them 5 stars.  We have some filthy restaurants in this city. I always check the scores before eating anywhere.
author: Anne S.

description:
I found out about this place from Chefs Feed. It's Corey Lee's favorite place to get Torta Cubana. 

My boyfriend ordered the Torta Cubana and loved it. I ended up getting two Chichorrans tacos...man were they delicious!  One taco was a handmade corn tortilla ($2.99) and I also got a Tacos Dorados (crispy shell, $4.99). There are more ingredients inside the Tacos Dorados, and the corn tortilla is more of a basic taco. I'd have to say I loved the corn tortilla more, since there was less going on. I felt like I could taste the meat more in that taco, compared to the tacos Dorados. 

We also shared a papusa (but mostly my bf ate it, since I got so full from the tacos!), which was pretty good. We ended up eating everything, so yes it was delicious!

You go in there and order, like a deli. There is some seating outside, and some stand-up tables as well. One complaint is that it felt pretty dodgy outside. There was a homeless guy begging for money at their doorfront, and so my bf and I ate around the corner in their seating area. However, the homeless guy followed us!  It made me feel uncomfortable. So next time I come, I will take my order to-go!
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Yum. This little shop is packed with great Mexican products and takeout options. Their homemade tortillas are so good. I also picked up a pint of the pork chile verde to take home, and it was Excellent. Try the homemade flour tortillas with butter and lard. So good.
author: C J.

description:
Awesome Mexican deli! The tortas and burritos are delicious. I recommend trying the chicharrón (pork) sandwich 

Everything is very affordable (~$6 for an entire meal). Some downsides are that they are cash only and have no seating. But there is a park and picnic area a few blocks away.
author: Vega S.

description:
My boyfriend and I, while visit Mission District in San Francisco, specifically searched for this place because of its glowing reviews on Yelp. Needless to say, we were not disappointed. La Palma Mexicatessen proudly delivers authentic Mexican cuisine to San Francisco and does it damn well.

Ambiance:
Don't expect much - it's a very small and cramped shop combining a grocery store and a takeaway restaurant at the same time. You have multiple checkout stations so it could be a bit overwhelming and confusing at first, but easy to pick up. Look to the side of the establishment if you're looking for a place to sit and chow down.

Customer Service:
Really great actually! From a dingy authentic restaurant, you usually trade in good customer service in exchange for a banging meal. However, La Palma Mexicatessen maintains a friendly attitude. Your food comes out pretty efficiently as well.

Food:
My boyfriend and I ordered 2 Burrito Supers - your choice of meat, rice, and beans, filled with guacamole, sour cream, cheese, cilantro, and onions. You could also request it to be spicy. We ordered the burritos with carne asada and no regrets. This burrito was kickass and super filling. One bite into the hot mix of fresh ingredients and wonderful flavours and we were in heaven. You have plenty of other meat options as well if you're not that huge of a fan of carne asada (god forbid) - al pastor, chile verde, colorado, carnitas, milanesa, tripitas, and even... tongue?

I have to admit that I didn't know what the vast majority of these were and tasted like, so if you're a newbie to Mexican food and not feeling that adventurous try the Carne Asada or Al Pastor.

---

The journey to find La Palma in the heart of Mission District was definitely worth it. Great customer service and a delicious burrito worth every penny - it's no wonder they rock that "People love us on Yelp" sticker.
author: Clarissa Y.

description:
Coming here is such a treat for me!  I love coming here for their chicaron with skin.  It's so darn yummy!  And you must try their sweet corn drink.  (Atol De Elote) It's like an egg nog and churro mixed together.  I will definitely come back again.

I am giving this a 4 star instead of a 5 because the Salvadorean tamales I got weren't the greatest.  The dough was soft and gooey.
author: Joyce L.

description:
The jello is super cool and yum.  Reminds me of the iris of an eye.  
The asada burritos are some of the best I've ever had.  
Make sure you tip because you're ordering more than a coffee..
author: C L.

description:
I love this place so dearly that I feel the need to repeat those who reviewed before me. 

This is the best Mexican food place in the city. Without hesitation or doubt on my part. Start out right with a carnitas burrito and ask for the "spicy beans". After that, get anything at all on the menu and wait to be blown away by the food/dollar ratio in terms of both scale and quality. 

Really want a treat? Get the taco with the hand pressed tortilla. It's like biting into a pan fried cloud. It's a bit pricer, but damn...
author: Joshua R.

description: This is the best Mexican in San Francisco!  I catered a party from La Palma.  We ordered the carnitas & asada with handmade blue corn tortillas.  The asada was to die for! Will never go anywhere else.
author: Megan M.

description:
Must Try:

-Carne Asada ( usually don't like Carne Asada tacos) ..soooo tender, so juicy!

-Chille Relleno , so fresh, real pepper taste, cheese filling is to die for!

-Enchiladas - whichever sauce you get you will love I guarantee it!

** get black beans whenever you need to pick a bean choice :P I don't know how they make it so good here!!

I always come back, at least 3-4x a month :)

Sometimes they sell sweets/desserts up in the front in baskets..whatever it is I always grab it, because I know it can't be bad tasting!
author: Selina W.

description: Counter order, pickup, find a table...  No frills but food quality is very high.
author: Des D.

description: This is my favorite place to buy Latin American food in SF.  It's affordable, (for SF standards) and delisious. Everything is perfectly cooked. My Favorite thing to do is get a fresh batch of Lard Tortillas, Carnitas or a chicken,  Some Cheese, and beans, and make my own tacos. I also love their chicharones. The only thing is finding a parking spot can be a challenge, and the neighborhood can be crawling with low level street gangsters. So bring the hooptie. Also the building is very small despite it's massive kitchen area, and can be very cramped and hard to maneuver around when full of people. This doesn't hinder the great tasting food however. Best Tortillas hands down, and what a variety. Even better than Southern California's Tortillas.
author: Vinny T.

description:
This is my staple for my monthly sunday brunch! Thanks to my fellow yelpers, I found the best place to get tacos and tamales! 

The fresh corn tortilla taco topped with black beans and meat of your choice (I always get tripe or chicharon) is the bomb! Make it a perfect brunch by getting the Champurado (mexican hot chocolate) to go with it.
author: Gordon O.

description: Boom! One of the best burritos in the city. Nice little market inside with fresh tortillas and chicharrones as well. I will be coming back here often.
author: Scott C.

description:
My roommate wanted to go to La Palma to get tamales.  She showed me some of the pictures posted on Yelp, and I wanted to tag along.

Nestled on 24th Street in the Mission, this tiny mom-and-pop shop is hard to miss because of the line that's out the door!  I ordered a chicken taco with their handmade corn tortilla and an horchata.  I think their handmade tortilla is THE best tortilla I've ever had next to being homemade.  I had the option of getting roasted chicken, but I think next time I'll get marinated chicken.  The roasted chicken was delicious, but I think the marinated chicken would've gone well the the black beans, onions, and the cilantro that were in the taco. The horchata was good too, and very sweet.  I wanted to try a strawberry tamale, because I've never heard of it before, but they ran out.  I got, instead, a corn tamale, which was heavy.  I wish there were whole kernels in the tamale.  I also wish they told me they ran out before I purchased it since the corn tamale was cheaper.  Even when my roommate tried to order a cinnamon tamale, they suggested a strawberry one.  They need to be informed as to what the inventory is.

Otherwise, I'm definitely coming back and ordering sopes because the one my roommate got looked so good and she enjoyed it.
author: Vira P.

description:
So I am embarrassed to admit that I never tried a Mission burrito when I lived in SF years ago. I was visiting the Bay Area this October and decided to add that to my SF must do list for the weekend. My friend who has lived in the Bay Area forever recommended this place. She said it was her favorite burrito spot in the neighborhood.

She and I headed there on a nice sunny Friday at lunchtime. There was a short line. We decided to make it a Mission food coma afternoon filled with various foods and drinks. Since this was the first stop, we decided to split a carne asada super burrito. It took about 10 minutes to prepare but well worth the wait for an excellent burrito.

The only reason I gave it a 4 star was the average service. My friend mentioned to the worker behind the counter that we were splitting the burrito. She offered to cut it in half. Then my friend went to pick up the burrito from the counter and noticed it was not cut. When she asked that they cut it since we were splitting it, the worked just handed her a plastic knife which barely cut through the super burrito. A little weird....anyway I would definitely come here again for the awesome food.
author: Julee D.

description:
Again, I love taking advantage of the variety of great eats along the lengthy 24th street. You can add La Palma to that list of great businesses along that street, which was at one time the hottest business on Yelp in San Francisco. 

In my book, this place is still is. The Mexicatessen is known for their hand-made tortillas, Pupusas, Tamales, Rotiserrie Chicken and other yummy foods such as Tortas, Tacos and "Burritos". 

Surprisingly, I have yet to try the shop's burrito. But as a "Burrito-lover", I might try that soon. And because the shop make their own line of flour tortillas, I might do that very soon.

As I was standing in line for some items to take home, I saw a lady dumping a fresh bucket of Chicharrón (pork rinds) inside the warmer. The lady told me they were fresh and just cooked. For $6.99 per pound, I took a half of pound for a later snack. 

The later snack didn't last long, less than two minutes to be exact. As soon as I got to my car and the bag of the pork rinds were still hot,  I had to take a bite of the treat. With the crispiness of the outer layer and the mixture of the pork's fat and lean meat make this treat explosive. Despite being a little fatty and salty, the treat isn't good for you. But it's "GRUBBIN"

If you're watching your diet, the fresh pork rinds is not a treat you can eat everyday. But after consuming over 2,000 burritos along with other unhealthy foods and a fat pimple at my age, well, my healthy days are pretty much over.
author: Matt G.

description: Found a parking spot right out front so gave this place a shot. The real deal authentic food. I ordered a torta from a photo i saw near the counter... Wow. Torta cubana - buttered & grilled fresh baked bread, refried beans, sausage, bacon, fried chicken, melted cheese, jalapeño, avocado, queso, tomato, lettuce. Lucky to make it out alive, ha! Would go back no questions asked.
author: Jason D.

description: In our tireless mission to find truly traditional tamales for our Friendsmas, made up of all So Cal natives who crave truly Mexican tamales, we tried La Palma.  They were absolutely incredible, even days later and after multiple reheatings.  Enjoying their tamales will definitely be a new holiday tradition for my SF family!  The salsa was pretty good, too!
author: Katie S.

description: Been a Mission Boy my whole life, the fresh homemade tortillas were always in my home. My favorite, carnitas burritos... The best in Califas... I like puro Carne, only carnitas and extra onions, cilantro, Pico DE Gallo. Been eating here all my life. Since 1951 I moved away for 10 year's and had a carnitas burrito and the taste had not changed its been making me smile for over 60 years.
author: Robert R.

description: I have been coming here since I was a kid.  It was at that time the only place where you could buy handmade corn tortillas on a daily basis.  I can't say that I have ever tried their burritos or other items, we always go here to buy the stuff to make our own at home...carnitas, queso fresco,masa, tortillas,salsa, guacamole,etc. Their carnitas are the best-much less fat and sinew than most purveyors and don't start me on their chicharrones-all warm and wrapped in a hot hand made corn tortilla...my husband always had to break into the packages by the time we reached the car! Many a happy moment was spent perched on the bumper of the car with the trunk open chowing down on these morsels from heaven!
author: Edith C.

description:
My favorite Mexican restaurant -- really more like the name says: a "Mexicatessen", since there is no seating. Be sure to pick up a tub of fresh guacamole. 

It's pretty straightforward: Order what you want, pay, then pick it up. I like the super burrito without rice. I find it keeps me full all day long and is mighty tasty!
author: N B.

description: Fantastic place for fresh tortillas, pupusas, huaraches, sopes, and all creations made with them. Great roast chickens too. Sweet and helpful people working behind the counter.
author: Sam S.

description:
Love this place!!!! I have a very sensitive stomach and I have to say that La palma have never ever given me heartburn or an upset stomach!!
Love their tamales!!! The chicharones is sooooo delicious and addicting so maybe order it once in a while because of all the fat. Their tacos are the bomb!!! 
It's a little hole in the wall in the hood that makes the best food for take out if you're not in the mood to cook.
author: SF Lady G.

description:
The Suiza is pretty bomb, thin with lots of cheese. The Guacamole/Salsa comes separate which is pretty nice sometimes.

The tacos are terrible though, the shell is too thick and heavy and it doesnt taste that great. I would recommend against them.

The ordering system is confusing as hell, you have to order, pay, and pick up your food in 3 different places.
author: Rohan D.

description:
Wow!  These are the BEST homemade flour tortillas in ALL of California!  Better than those found in Old Town Sacramento, better than those found in East Los Angeles, even better than those found in all of Texas!

I drive 45 minutes 2 times every month just to stock up!  H E A V E N!!
author: William O.

description: I ordered the breakfast burrito. The serving was very generous, truthfully I was disappointed in the taste. It left me gassy and bloated for the rest of the day. But they had great selection in jarritos.
author: Fernilla S.

description: Come here for retail, not to eat. I live down the block and used to come in often for burritos, but the last 3 or 4 times I've came in I've regretted it, and I think they have new staff that don't care about the quality. For the price you shouldn't have to settle for cold meat and a half stale tortilla, and watching the guys behind the counter chat for 5 minutes while your food sits ready is nerve wracking. This is a great place to buy ingredients to use at home, but the current service is terrible.
author: Tristam M.

description:
Eh, we came here after searching for the best carnitas burritos. They got my order wrong (black beans instead of pinto, forgot jalapenos & hot sauce instead of pico de gallo) & we waited what felt like an incredibly long time (nearly 15 minutes) for a burrito that was fine, but definitely not the best carnitas burrito. My fiance also got the chicarron burrito & we couldn't tell the difference between that & my carnitas burrito.

Glad we tried it, but there is a long list of other places in the Mission I'd hit up first before coming back here.
author: Chantelle D.

description:
If you want to eat excellent AUTHENTIC Mexican food then you eat here. If you want to get FAUX Mexican food then go to Pancho Villas or Chipotle.  I had the chile relleno with rice and refried beans. It was super delicious. The chile relleno was freshly made and tasty. The sauce had just the right amount of heat (spice). The beans were right on point, and the rice was good but I have had better. I also had the huarache which was hot off the grill and tasted so yummy with the tomatillo sauce and queso. I also bought to take home a dozen blue corn tortillas and 2 lbs of the blue corn masa to make a few tamales @ home. I just love this place!

BTW: There is outdoor seating and it was so cool eating everything al fresco.
author: K A.

description: Just your neighborhood Mexican foods shop with Wonderful tortillas in several flavores made onsite. Standard menu with some standouts. Friendly service.
author: U S.

description:
Love love love love La Palma.  I took advantage of being in the old neighborhood yesterday by stopping by to pick up some of my favorite foods.  I purchased a bag of freshly made tortillas - so fresh that the bag was hot and steaming, a bag of homemade potato chips (simply cannot resist these) and a few bags of spices and some varieties of whole chilies that I wasn't familiar with.

The store is the same as ever, packed with hungry people waiting for their order, Mexican music blaring, the smell of freshly made tortillas, and friendly and helpful cashiers ringing up your purchases.

 La Palma is one of the things I really miss about living in La Mission.

*sigh*
author: .Hon H.

description:
Chicharrón, Chicharrón, Chicharrón!!! Make sure to get the Chicharrón with skin & meat for the delicious fattiness.

I ordered the regular burrito with (of course) Chicharrón and refried beans. Expect a 3 x 6 inch size. It's ridiculous. I paired it with the classic Horchata drink (rice milk with nutmeg & cinnamon) so my mouth didn't feel too greasy/oily. This was all for less than $7. 

Staff here is super nice. They also have a little Mexican mart with tortillas, Quesadilla Salvadorena, flan, huge bags of tortilla chips, etc. It also has outdoor seating; it's a nice spot to check out.
author: Joanna H.

description:
My girlfriend and I found this place in our quest for the holy grail: a quality hard shell taco in San Francisco.  A helpful quora-er pointed it out and so we came.

Overall this place was the holy grail: these tacos were AWESOME, and cheap: 3 for under $5 and I was full.  

The flavor of the meat was delicious, it tasted fresh, and it was not dried out.  It was juicy and flavorful and it seemed they cooked it that day.  The tacos were topped with cheese and cabbage and it was great.

My girlfriend had the rice with her tacos and the rice was not dried up either.  

There were a variety of meats available, and the cashier gave us samples to help us decide.

There's also cool outdoor seating where you can relax and enjoy the sights and sounds.

Places to improve...the chips and salsa left something to be desired.  The chips were a little hard, and the salsa was runny.  But they are really cheap: just 99 cents, so give em a try if you like.

Lastly, it's confusing inside.  You come inside and there's a cash register right there, but that's not where you order, that's where you pick up food.  You order further back but there's no signs that tell you that.
author: Charlie B.

description:
Holy, freaking, moly.  I had a carne asada burrito and it was so amazing it nearly reached the level of being a spiritual experience.  The tortilla is really the real standout here -- easily the best tortilla I've ever had.  It had that wonderful crepe-like consistency that a properly done tortilla has(I presume this is thanks to copious amounts of lard.  Worth it).

I've lived in a lot of places in california and tried many different kinds of burrito, and this spot is definitely a solid top 5 in terms of all time top burritos.  Easily the best burrito I've found in SF.
author: Yan L.

description:
Can we say FRESH?

Yes we can and that it is. My stomach is growling just thinking about this place. The smell of fresh hot tortillas waiting to be consumed is simply mind blowing. 

What do I recommend? EVERYTHING. 

That's it. Review done.
author: Jen W.

description: This weekend while visiting la palma i encountered the rudest, most unprofessional cashier working here.  I have been a loyal customer of la palma for decades and find the behavior of this individual deplorable and will never step foot in this place again. Im sure this place has made tons of money here all these years maybe thats why customer service isn't a priority.
author: Sam G.

description: Best Tortillas! The service is quick, the food is good and authentic, and the price is right.
author: Courtney N.

description:
It's got the authenticity, price and sabor-saber of a far, far seedier establishment - but runs like a well-cleaned, well-greased wheel: LPM takes credit cards, makes-to-order hot, fresh, hand-rolled tacos and papusas, and doubles as a modest Mexican grocer.

My roommate returns again and again for the cheese and bean papusas, but I actually prefer the soft tacos (especially the chicken-in-sauce), and the Quesadilla La Palma - filled with fresh grilled vegetables. I've also never spent more than $9 at a time here. Win-zo.
author: Liz C.

description: Rating the taqueria in the back. Ordered a champurrado and a couple tamales. Both were delicious except the tamales really needed more sauce.
author: Will D.

description:
Fantastic tacos (opt for one with a handmade tortilla).  

Their tortillas are fantastic, and totally fresh (the ladies are rolling them off the tortilla assembly line in plain sight), and the habanero salsa is to die for.

Everyone in the store is so friendly and eager to help, despite the language barrier that sometimes crops up.
author: Vandana N.

description: Best tortillas in the mission which means best tacos and burrito. Meat well flavored, just ask for extra. Forget the beans and rice in the burrito if you are like ne and orefer meat and guac. The pozole is also delicious made with patita! Yum! Very authentic!
author: Tommy C.

description:
I like mashups and I think they can be applied to food. Take La Palma's regular burrito with refried beans and spicy sauce and add to it their chile relleno (replace meat) and you will find yourself hooked to one hot chile relleno burrito mashup. 

Tip: It's a deli and a store with limited (but outdoor!) seating. Order at the deli in the back, take the ticket and pay and pick up your food in the front.
author: Jane K.

description: I heard this place was good and I wasn't disappointed. The ingredients are all so fresh, the staff is friendly and helpful. Plus they sell salsa, guacamole and fresh homemade tortillas. This place has it all
author: Christian G.

description:
I smelled the goodness wafting from its doors half a block away, and what a block. Beware, the neighborhood is beyond shay-dee. I felt a bit uncomfortable walking around, even in broad day light. 

The place is a lot smaller than I expected, but they had a wide variety of dried chiles. The guy behind the counter was very helpful in assisting me to pick out a few varieties of chilies. They came in pretty big bags but the prices were super affordable. I bought chile negro, ancho chiles and California chiles. Can't wait to whip some Mexican dishes for my boyfriend!!
author: Alice W.

description:
La Palma Mexicatessen seems to sell everything: tacos, pupusas, tortas, chicarones, burritos, tortillas,  and huraches, etc.  i seem to have ordered the one item they're not very good at: super burritos. 

Sampling: beef super burrito (6.19) since regulars were 5.59, got a super
-usual size for a super. not too spicy, mushy and uncooked rice, grizzly beef, mushy  beans, a bit of sour cream, some guacamole, a little salsa
-no chips, salsa,  nor pickled veggies

frijoles refritos:
-order at the deli counter, pay at the front, pick up food on the right.
-heard pupusas. nacatamales are the bomb here.
-place is cramped.
-will repeat with tamales or nacatamles.
author: Victor G.

description: The best tortillas you can find. Great salsas. You can buy both and take home. The food they serve is among the best Mexican in SF.
author: Michael C.

description: Their torta cubana might be the best sandwich I ever had. Used to go here when working in the mission. Busy, but worth the wait!
author: Robert K.

description: Got the carne asada Sonora taco and everything about it was so yummy!!!! It included a flour tortilla, carne asada, salsa, rice, cheese and sour cream. Will start coming back more often
author: Jennifer S.

description:
A cute little grocery store (meaning NOT a restaurant, no place to sit).  Got a great veggie huarache, it was excellent.  Perfect to eat out on the street on a warm sunny afternoon.  

Would definitely come back for grocery shopping!  Stuff was super cheap and looked authentic.
author: Monica R.

description: You'd be surprised as a humble eatery and supplier, how much they provide for much of the Mexican restaurant community in SF. 6 million+ tortillas a year alone go to one of their major customers alone. Steeped in tradition, and producing them proudly in that way, they provide their own, and many others indirectly, some tasty eats. 4.5 stars
author: Kim N.

description: Oh wow, this place is so good, wish I lived in the neighborhood, would come in every day for the cheese enchiladas and yummy ranchera sauce. Will definitely be back, am intrigued by the line of people buying the tubs of guacamole.
author: J P.

description: La Palma! I love you! High quality food made with love and packed with so much taste that my now husband and I had to have them cater our wedding! It was a joy to work with them every step of the way. Thanks, La Palma for 20 years of love!
author: matthew d.

description: Traveling from Northern California, this was a total score finding la Palma.  The food was amazing. The place is small but service was great and fast. I love seeing the authentic food and the old traditional ways of making tortillas still alive at this restaurant. I ordered the chicken ford it's and it was absolutely terrific.
author: Barbe K.

description: Their burritos and enchiladas taste like they're made with stale bacon grease. The awful enchiladas aren't baked. They're fried in a stovetop skillet, with a watery sauce poured over them. Rude staff. If you find someone who speaks English, you're lucky. Their deli foods aren't fresh. You can get better tortillas, Mexican cheeses and Mexican beverages of all types from local area grocery stores. What La Palma seems to be best known for is their prepared masa for tamale-makers.
author: Pam J.

description:
This place, ever since I was a kid (yes i'm a rare, native San Franciscan) has made quality, authentic food. Always a good choice for huaraches, tamales, and pupusas. Ok, so it can seem a slight bit greasy, but shit! it's friggin good. 

Also a good place to get your mexican cheese and tortillas or homemade things you may want to attempt. If you're picking up sour cream and haven't tried salvadorean vs mexican vs regular sour cream... the salvadorean sour cream is a little saltier and thicker than the other two. Works really well when showcased, but may not be what you want if you're making a dish that needs a little creamy topping. 

Oh yeh, and they have fresh carnitas and other fried meats (Buche' anyone?) that are yummy. The chorizos and longanizas are great. give this place a gander if you're in the area, chances are you'll find something you'll like... unless you're vegan =(.
author: Vittorio L.

description:
The food at La Palma is basically the most authentic, the cleanest and most affordable Mexican food in the Mission. They sell big containers of fresh guacamole and salsa in the big fridge for like $3.00. The tacos are $2 and killer, this place is good stuff. Homemade corn and flour tortillas for $2.

To order, walk to the back (and take a ticket if crowded) and order at the back cash registar, then walk up front and pay for it near the door. Your number will be called near the door when your food is ready. 

Warning, not very vegetarian friendly! The flour tortillas and refried beans are containing lard (corn tortillas are w/out lard). Also they keep weird hours, not open past like 4pm. Hardly anyone working speaks English so either learn Spanish or take a Spanish speaker.
author: Shannon Z.

description: Once again, chicharrones are addictively outstanding. Salsa teriffic, chips mega fine. But we found a new use for one of their staples, homemade tortillas. Great appetizer, cut in triangles top with roasted duck with hoisin and soy sauce, crema with  cilantro and green onions, bake at 350 for a few and serve. Used the same tortillas with queso fresco and romano, pickled peppers and green onions and roast for a bit. Serve all with farmers market sauteed and salted padron peppers, watermelon radishes. Ahh, three day weekend!
author: Kelly K.

description: Oh. My. Goodness. This place is as good as it gets! I had been wanting to go to La Palma for quite some time, and recently found myself down on 24th St. on a mission for some carnitas. Because I grew up in San Diego, I am a little judgmental toward the Mexican food of Northern California (i.e. Chipotle just doesn't do it for me), but as soon as I entered La Palma, I knew I found a gem. All around the store are homemade tortillas, salsas, guacamole, cotija cheese, chips, dried chipotle peppers, and other delicious things for you to take home to enjoy later. As you proceed to the back, you see the open kitchen where employees are making tortillas from scratch and preparing food. La Palma is doing it right. And my carnitas burrito was absolutely heavenly. I cannot wait to come back here and try more of my favorite dishes!
author: Brita B.

description: Great, home style authentic Mexican...
author: Sasha B.

description:
I don't really go off to the mission that often but when I do, I make sure I could satisfy my mexican food craving. 
I actually did not expect this place to be so cramped, considering that it is essentially a grocery store and a taqueria in one. You can definitely tell this place is legit by the customers waiting in line and the fact that the menu is mostly in spanish.

The shrimp super burrito is AMAZING. Normally, I wouldn't really take notice of the ingredients but you could really tell that it was made fresh. The tortilla was soft and nicely made (you could even watch them make the tortillas while waiting for your burrito) and the shrimp was extremely plump and full of flavor. 

In addition to the food, I really like the customer service. While ordering my burrito, I asked the cashier if it was possible to have shrimp. He really went out of the way to make sure there was some available and really friendly about it. It really makes a difference when the cashier makes an effort to converse with you and make sure you get the best food possible. :)
author: Jennifer W.

description: Guacamole was amazing. Staff was helpful. Mixed up my friend's order and put in beans when she asked for none. Cactus chips were crispy and nice and salty. Stood at table outdoors to eat.
author: L M.

description:
I have been to San Francisco numerous times and I have visited the Mission yet I had never had a burrito there. Unacceptable! I found myself back in the city on the bay and it was imperative I remedy the situation.

I was staying in Mission this trip which worked out perfectly. Knowing how that neighborhood is inundated with Mexican joints I searched Yelp for something close to the apartment and had a high star rating. La Palma Mexicatessen was at the top of the list.

La Palma Mexicatessen is a Mexican grocery store with a kitchen in the back. The store is somewhat small but when I entered there was a good amount of people waiting around for their orders. I felt I was in a good spot. The menu was varied but I went straight to the burritos and decided on a rice, black bean, cheese, and chicharones. I like my burritos simple, yo. I couldn't find any seating in the store so I get back to the apartment and ripped into it. Um...YUM! This is a quality burrito and I ate the whole damn thing in one sitting. The chicharones, the main event, were tender and juicy. The beans and rice were cooked just right. 

I certainly lucked out putting my faith in this place and I was not disappointed. So glad I finally had a Mission burrito. Absolutely worth the hype.
author: Kiki M.

description: Definitely the best Mexican restaurant ever. It's also very inexpensive considering the taste and quality of the food. I went there twice back in the days when I didn't like Mexican food. And that's saying something. Please treat yo tongue and get a burrito!
author: Iljin C.

description: I'm not sure why this place has high reviews. The food taste bland. The meat is tasteless and smothered in sauce that had an awful taste. The salsa was watery and bland. The taco shells were greasy and over cooked. The mission has taquerias 100 times better then this join. What a disappointing lunch
author: Izzy A.

description:
The best tongue I've ever tasted in a taco, it is both incredibly rich, and deep in flavor.  The Chicharones is also prepared and seasoned really well and probably my favorite thing on the menu.  I love this place for a quick pick-me-up bolt of sustenance, and if I am not in the mood to sit down and order, or if I know that i'll have to soon be on my way. 

They are speedy, inexpensive, and there is usually an abundance of shaded seating to the side of the restaurant. Their portions are also really generous, I can usually share half of a taco, which will fuel me for the next few hours.
author: Ty T.

description: Born & raised in San Francisco, I've been coming to La Palma since I was a child in the early 70's.  There used to be delicious carnitas sold in bulk along with small home made tortillas to make your own taquitos..those options are still available, but at a very hefty price.  Today I stopped by to buy some carnitas meat, chicharrones, huaraches with chorizo, arroz y frijoles refritos.  The prices were high, the ordering was chaotic, the woman behind the counter couldn't seem to understand (even though I told her in Spanish) that I wanted just 1lb of carnitas & 1 lb or chicharrones-finally she got it.  I went to the counter, paid for rice, beans, huaraches with chorizo (delicious by the way), 1 coke & 1 flan-$24.00, then a minute later I was asked to pay again (with a credit card for both transactions by the way) for the meat...?? Really?? Okay, anyway I paid, another $22.00-wow! For that price I would expect some really good meat, well I was very disappointed; I got into my car, popped a chicharron in my mouth only to nearly crack a tooth!! I mean it was ROCK hard, not crispy, but ROCK HARD! WTH?  I took it out and tried another piece...nothing but a blob of deep fried fat-I choked, coughed and hacked all the way home.  Now this is from someone who can appreciate the tasty fatty bits-this was just a nasty blob of congealed deep fried grease that almost make me vomit.  Seriously I would not buy meat or probably much of anything else here again-the only thing I'd be willing to pay for would be the huaraches with chorizo.  So sad that another old school Mission institution has sold out...
author: Wendy S.

description: Amazing hand made tacos! Huarches are thicker tortillas with a filling baked in. Rich and delicious!
author: Kokoe J.

description: I had one of their super burritos and I've got to tell you, it was great.  I've been to many burrito places throughout the city over the years and I've gotta tell you this place has the best ones. Great atmosphere and if you need to buy anything else to take home related to Hispanic cooking this is the place. I'll be going back there again.
author: Tim P.

description:
Ok... the verdict is finally in:
Best Chile Verde in the Bay.  Hands down.  And the price is right.  Grab a quart and some tortillas to take home! mmmhmmm!
author: Josh K.

description: Homemade tortillas?! I literally just stood in the crowded market and watched all the ladies in the back make the tortillas. When you first walk in, it's a little confusing bc there are 4 registers. I came to order burritos which we ordered and paid for at one of the back registers. then you wait at the front register to pick up your fresh meals. Don't forgot to pick up a small bag of chicharrons, so delicious and salty. I think the burrito was okay, but the experience definitely reminded me of Mexico :)
author: Serena L.

description:
To be fair I've only eaten here once. I got the chicken super burrito w/o sour cream. It's my standard Mexican-restaurant tastiness heuristic, like a burger + shake for an American restaurant, or pad thai at a Thai restaurant.

The burrito was enormous but not nearly as tasty as Taqueria cancun. I might try it again if I'm hungry for Mexican but not a burrito.
author: Max H.

description: I ordered from this place because they were on doordash....but seriously was disappointed with their pupusas. I know I shouldn't have ordered a Salvadorean food from a Mexican place but thought we would try it. Never again! These things are flavorless and masa was hard and dry as can be. Won't be coming back again to try the food.
author: Eddie P.

description:
This place had a line through the only aisle the shop has. People were snatching corn tortillas from cardboard boxes. The cashier was grabbing giant deep fried pork rinds. It was hectic, exciting.

I ordered the carnitas taco. The tortillas are created and sold there. It's a thick corn tortilla that doesn't fall apart when you/they put a lot of food inside of it. GENIUS. It's like a corn pita, nothing special other than it being thick, possibly too thick for some people..

I could live off of these tacos. All of the ingredients were oh so fresh. Juicy carnitas, fresh tomatoes, onions, and cilantro. They aren't that big, so order another item along with it.
author: Rahil P.

description: The carnitas burrito here was quick and easy to order and so good. Nice casual option.
author: Donnie G.

description:
La Palma Mexicatessen: part grocery store, part kitchen, and all awesome. You haven't had a full Mission experience until you've had La Palma.

Hands down, La Palma makes the Mission's best burritos, pupusas, tacos, and whatever else can be made. Don't even try to argue with me about how La Taqueria makes the best tacos or how El Farolito makes the best burritos. Pound for pound, everything coming out of La Palma will knock out the competition. As an added bonus, all of the tortillas and tacos are made fresh to order so you'll never have to wonder if that bag of tortillas has been sitting on top of the steam machine for weeks or months at a time.

When you get here, make your way to the register in the rear in front of the menus to order. The front registers are usually for buying groceries and other items. Bear in mind that this place is quite cramped, but this will give you time to really appreciate all of the Mexican goods that you never knew existed. If you run through the menu and still can't decide on anything, I suggest grabbing a super burrito with your favorite meat or some of the handmade tacos. Both will satisfy you like no other. The burritos just taste better with the fresh tortilla. They're just softer and more moist. And the tacos actually taste like tacos! We're all used to the steamed premade taco tortillas that most taquerias use. At La Palma, the fresh taco tortillas actually have some bite to them and don't fall apart on the first bite. For once, my tacos end up in my mouth and not on my shirt.

Best part of La Palma? The 'exotic' meats like lengua and buche taste way better than the 'standard' carne asadas and pollo. Most taquerias half-ass the meats that aren't big sellers since they know not a lot of people will be eating them and they might just end up wasted. At La Palma, everything tastes good and every meat is shown just as much care as any other. I realize this sounds a little overly sentimental but settling for poorly cooked meat is just a travesty.

So, do yourself a favor, stop at La Palma and grab a bite. You won't regret it.
author: Frank Y.

description:
Grades:

Super Burrito: A
Hard shell tacos: A
Tortas: 
Price: A
Service: B people are friendly but a bit slow at times. Only take card with ten dollar minimum which is not too bad but inconvenient. 

What bothers me is lack of salsa when you buy chips. You need to get a huge thing of salsa if you want chips or eat chips alone. No free salsa bar or small salsa samples or nada.
author: Charles S.

description:
I ordered catered food from here over the weekend. I ordered the PQT#1 x2 and the PQT#2 x1 the pqt #1 was $79 each but i ordered 2 and the pqt #2 was $60 so about $210 out the door. for that the #1 came with 3 pounds of asada, 3 pounds of carnitas, rice, beans, guacamole, salsa, and grilled mexican style,onions  and a kilo of freshly made in house homemade tortillas for each meal and since i had 2 i had double all the portions the #2 had 3 pounds carne el pastor plus the above extras and they gave me a free whole chicken on the side. There is no easy way to describe the food but I will try.

In the movie "once upon a time in mexico" starring johnny depp and antonio banderas there is a scene where johnny depp is in mexico eating food with some criminal. He tell the criminal that he has eating all over the world and that that food in mexico he is eating in the scene is the best food he has ever had, he says it is so good that he is going to finish it and then go shoot the chef because that will balance the world out because the food in the world should never be that good. The food from La Palma is that good, in fact it is so good that i drove from sacramento at 5am to san francisco to get it and back a 5 hour trip and I waited an hour until they opened at 8am just to have it. 
it is sooo good that I am offically changing my favorite food of 20 years from pizza to La Palmas carne el pastor although the carnitas was a close second for me and all my family claim the carnitas was first and the el pastor second followed by the asada ( which for asada was so perfectly cooked and not dry it was amazing) the el pastor was loss for words good. It was an unreal experience that was very real. I have a new go to place for all catering events and that is La Palma. Another funny fact is the line was snakeing out the door at 8:08 am within a few minutes of opening on a saturday. the free whole chicken was perfectly cooked too. It fell right off the bone. everything tasted so good. This is hands down the best mexican food california has to offer. I wish I was exaggerating but im not it was that good. Dont take my word for it and instead get some you will be a believer too.
Best of all no fake flavorings no artificial anything and no preservatives in any of this food, it was all fresh and home made
author: Tmo457 W.

description:
What could be more fitting in SF than a 100th review for an outstanding taqueria?  I always have a soft spot for taquerias that are tucked into little markets.... some of my very best experiences have come in this unassuming format.  Disfruta!!!

Simple recommendation - hand-made tacos.  The tortillas are thick and heavenly.  The meats (we tried carnitas mmmm and pollo ranchero, moist & flavorful) are excellent.  We had a hand-made and a super burrito.  I got the super because I had to share with the dog ;   OK, partly a lie, because that's what we monkeys are good at.   But the dog did get a bunch.

The taco is high-five and honestly have not tasted better here or really anywhere I can think of.   The burrito is very competitive but if you want to be sent to heaven, just stick to the hand-made tacos.  You will be glad!
author: Bob K.

description:
an sf staple comparable to how bostons got legal & reginas, nyc has grimaldis & katz's, austin boasts stubbs & franklins and chicago w/al's or malnati's

inside is comparable to molinari's (nb) w/out the nazi structure.  this place is equipped w/so much tasty impulsive grub its like goin to trader joes baked or famished on payday

60+ years in town merits a 'must visit' in the mish

chicharrones are their signature but across the board they're freshly grrreat in whatever you may have a taste for mexican wise.  everywhere you look there's somethin that attracts your eyes, which instinctly prompts your arms to make a reach

ridiculously good food, fair prices, plenty of staff to assist as lapalma is the syndicate big boy on the block when it comes to fresh in house tortillas...slinging 'em to a home or tacolicious near you
author: Clark G.

description: Fresh made tortillas are delicious and so good! I also got their guacamole salsa, regular salsa and fresh cheese (can't remember the name because it was eaten up so fast)! I will come back here again and again! Next time I'm going to try some of their other things I missed out on because I got there as they were closing. Yes, they do sell out of things.
author: Tiny K.

description: Gorditas! A stuffed like pastry with your choice of meat and picante with cabbage, queso fresco and other fun ingredients. Trust that these are a must! I would definitely go for the carnitas, a heavenly marinated pork meat! Definitely go for 2, one is simply too little for this bite of deliciousness! ;)
author: Daniela U.

description:
I tried the tacos in the back of this small Mexican grocery store. The handmade tortillas are what drew me here, but come for the awesome chicharrones, 3 kinds to boot.

I had 3 tacos with handmade tortillas. Keep in mind that the tortillas are quite thick and filling, much thicker than my favorite ones at Poc Chuc. Two tacos would have been ideal. I tried al pastor, roast chicken and chicharonnes, my favorite being the chicharrones. The tacos come with your choice of beans as well. I wouldn't mind a bit of salsa on the side though.

Outdoor seating, so come on a nice day and enjoy!
author: Derrick V.

description: My great grandma took me for the first time the day I learned how to make tamales.  This is the only place I will buy my masa from.  It holds a special place in my heart, and gives me a piece of my Nana every time I go there, and make tamales with their masa.
author: Janette R.

description: Great service from staff in explaining what the vegetarian options were, quick service, good food & not expensive. They have many vegetarian options & will accommodate you easily for the items you want made vegetarian. They are very familiar with the ingredients as well. The menu is more than most authentic Mexican restaurants have as well. In addition, they sell Mexican food items that you can take home, like chipotle tortillas.
author: Mihir M.

description: Best handmade tortillas and homemade salsa, ever! Great paquetes for parties. Killer carnitas. I'll never cook again.
author: Spiferina P.

description: Great tortillas, as everyone says.  It's a solid all-around place, with great prepared food and good staples (fresh cheeses, grains, tortillas, etc)
author: Byron D.

description:
There isn't any seats in the shop, but you can find some summer seats by the corner... definitely too cold for winter :|

I tried the tacos carnitas, meat was juicy and flavorful! But the THICK tortilla made the dish overall 3 instead of 4 stars...

The shop is really narrow and the open door made the place really cold while we were waiting for the tacos :(
author: Ka L.

description:
im a huge fan of mexican hole in the wall places to eat. this is a good example. 

amazing food packed full of flavor and not that bad on my wallet. i ate a bit of this and a bit of that but what stuck out was the chicharones. omg. me and my buddy at up a half pound of it in the quickness. 

easy parking, great tortillas, great customer service. i love this place
author: Richard H.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in the city. Everything I've had is delicious. Definitely try the chili verde.
author: Robert Q.

description: Seriously craving some tacos, my very pregnant sister dragged me here to La Palma's for lunch yesterday. We had a really great experience!! Thank God, because I couldn't deal with my sister if she was unsatisfied hahaha. She had the Carne Asada tacos and was delighted and wanted to order another service! On the other hand, I had a couple of burritos and was equally delighted. Yum, yum, La Palma's a great spot.
author: Gaston B.

description: The food is pretty good at this place "normally" but the service horrible which made me give the place a 2 star. Last time we visited they totally forgot our order and when we asked 20 min later it was behind the counter COLD, suprise. They really could have re-done the items since the mistake was on them. We ate it anyways, cold and decided not to come back. Also this is more of a take to go, as the only seating it outside and often full.
author: Beth P.

description: I'm from Tucson, AZ and always trying to find authentic Mexican food in SF. This place hit the spot! The blue corn tamale is unreal, and flavorful. The staff is very accommodating and able to make recommendations.
author: Tyler M.

description:
Utter failure. Miserable and upsetting experience.

After standing at the Pick-up counter for 30 minutes for what I assumed was going to be the best and freshest Mexican food that I've ever tasted, I'm told they don't have my order. 

I hand a chap my paid receipt and he scurries off to find out where my order is. But it hasn't been made. Without coming back to me, they get my order ready within another 5 minutes and hand it to me. 

WITHOUT A SIMPLE APOLOGY! 

Now accidents happen and we all make mistakes.  What makes mistakes forgivable is when someone acknowledges they've made one, and even better if they hand out a sincere-sounding apology. I don't mean grovelling and I don't even mean profusive. Just a straightforward, honest apology. 

With none forthcoming with my much-delayed order, I was feeling a bit put off. But I thought in their hurry to finally get me my order, they might've forgotten the niceties. So I inquired 'why' my order took 30 minutes, giving anyone a chance to apologise. 

No decent response and no apology. 

No business. 

Rather than apologise, one guy behind the counter offered to refund my money.

I really would have preferred the food with an apology, but since that apparently was not an option, I took the refund. 

It looks like the food is pretty popular,  though.
author: Dom Y.

description:
The best thing about La Palma is the fact that they make their tortillas fresh.  I love seeing them transform a ball of dough into a tortillain one second with their magical tortilla press.   I had the following today:

Veggie Huarche (3.00)  Lots of shredded cabbage, onions, and cilantro on top of an oval tortilla filled with beans/cheese.  It was very much like a pupusa but with veggies on top.  Pretty good but kinda boring.

Pupusa (almost 2.29 each)-- I had one with cheese/beans.  The cheese is really aromatic but the texture of the pupusa was too thick and doughy.  I prefer ones with thinner skin and that soaks up the sauce.  The tomato sauce here tastes exactly like watered down ketchup!  That is not good.  I do like their cabbage mixture that goes on top of the pupusa.  I weren't buy their pupusas again.
 
Tacos (3 dollars)--  I had a tongue taco and they were very generous with the meat and there were lots of garnishing.  The fall apart chewy handmade shell gave it a very authentic and fresh twist.  I like it!  My partner enjoyed his with pork skin taco (there are three kinds of pork skin here).  One of the pork skins offered here has a good deal of meat still on it and all of them are 6 dollars a pound.

Nacatamale (3 dollars)-- pork tamale with all the trimmings.   It's about two pounds of pork, RICE, masa, green olives, tomato paste, and potatoes.  Greasy, acidic from the tomato paste, and just plain comforting!  Make sure you have this with something light like veggies because it's a bit too rich by itself.
 
La Palma is in a nice quiet area of the Mission.  It's difficult to find parking but it's a nice place to get some really fresh and high quality Mexican food.  You can feel their pride when you walk in because it's a clean place that is run efficiently.  It's not the cheapest place or even the best place in the Mission but it's one of the top places for sure.
author: Lorissa W.

description:
My dad was born and raised in SF. This place has been around since his childhood. I think it's family operated. Home made tortillas, fresh carnitas, and mexican queso fresco. The 45 minute drive from San Jose to San Francisco is never a let down when you go to La Palma. Parking and seating are scarce.

The worst time to go is around 11 am on Sundays because there is a nearby Catholic Church. A whole flood of people go eat after mass, so if you're in the area either get there by 10:00 am or wait until noon. Otherwise you are in for a long wait.
author: Vanessa G.

description: I have lived in the city since 1986, how is it I have never been here before?  I bought a pound of carnitas to bring home, when my roomate tasted them, she cried, they reminded her of being back in Mexico.  I also bought some spinach tortillas (YUM) and fresh cheeses, guacamole sauce and sweet corn tamales (we have yet to try).  I will be coming back as soon as I can.  I want some corn tortillas and one of everything else!
author: Donna H.

description:
When you order a burrito, and you definitely should, they make your tortilla on the spot. This alone is reason enough to eat here.

Try the chile verde--pork stewed in tomatillo sauce--it's transcendent.

Also recommend: the huarache with chile colorado on top. 

Everything is dead cheap, and really, half the time when I go out to a fancy hipster restaurant, I wind up wishing I'd just eaten here instead.

You'll never regret it!
author: Jamey M.

description: Friendly service but the horchata is sickly sweet and the enchiladas were tasteless. We were offered a choice of mild or spicy. We both ordered spicy and both dishes lacked flavor. Will not return. Two stars for friendly service and bomb refried beans.  Enchiladas were also Luke warm.
author: Alex C.

description: Seriously some of these best homemade tortillas I've ever eaten. Made with all of the good stuff - flour and lard - and fresh, you won't be disappointed. Staff is super nice and helpful as well. I dream about these tortillas on the daily.
author: Johanna L.

description: The best burrito I've had in San Francisco and quite possibly my life.  This is the alpha-omega--the meaning of life.
author: Mike C.

description:
Ah, quite possibly the best tacos in SF.  Handmade tortillas made right for you to see - so mouthwatering!

Tamales are also dangerously delicious.  

So the line can be daunting, but it's well worth it.  While you're there, note how cheap some of the classic Mexican market items are here, that is, if you know about that kind of stuff. If you have dark hair, they probably will speak to you in spanish just a heads up

La Palma Mexicatessen * seriously really worth checking out if you're in this neighborhood.
author: Athena S.

description: Talk about great authentic food!  They have everything from a to z. Something new to us was the chicharon burritos and papusas. Might sound kinda weird but oh it so good. You can also buy ingredients for home, the most popular item seemed like the tortilla dough. It's a must try joint if your in the area.
author: T L.

description: First tamales that I've liked that aren't my mom's. So delicious although the prices were a little higher than what I'm used to seeing but so good. Definitely worth coming
author: Francisca C.

description: Super Burrito with Colorado Beef. Holy Cow! Champurrado great consistency, that's corn masa and cinnamon, a Mexican hot chocolate made to perfection. Chips, salsa, guacamole, with bags of cactus chips all made in house. Super legit, one of the best in Mission authenticity.
author: Wilson T.

description: Best birria in San Francisco, plus fresh masa, habanero salsa, and great guacamole! Their chips are among the best in the City, and their menu options are  plentiful. On weekends you can ameliorate your hangover pains with their menudo!
author: Frank B.

description: Everything I've eaten here tastes great (my favorites are menudo and the torta desayuno), but I always manage to end up waiting for like 15 minutes after ordering before it comes out. I wouldn't recommend coming for take out if you're in a rush, but otherwise worth the wait.
author: Matt B.

description:
Took a day trip up here and saw the many high Yelp reviews. If I could give it 3.5 stars I would as I fed a family of five for $20 and that is amazing.  Price is unbeatable. I got a veggie burrito and it was OK. Not sure what everyone is crazy raving about. It was good, but not anything crazy that I hadn't had before. Pupusas were good, thick and filled nicely. $2 a pop for those, can't really go wrong. 

We sat outside on the patio and got lucky that we got a seat. If you are going with a family or a few people then you need to know inside is crowded and tons of people ordering, buying small groceries, etc. You have to sit outside to eat. 

Like I said, nothing I would really go out of my way for, but it was good and very affordable.
author: Omeed B.

description: Fresh masa daily.  One of the few places in the bay area that make real masa.  All the food is great.  The tamales are excellent.  All of the tortillas are like in Mexico.  The beans are excellent.   This place is totally awesome.  The real deal.  The catering packs are the best deal in the city.  I have been going here for over twenty years and it has only gotten better.  MASa!
author: Johnny B.

description:
Great spot. I come here for some Mexican groceries, cheese, fresh tortillas, and tacos once in awhile. 

Their tortillas are delicious, probably the best I've ever had.  I generally go for the handmade corn, but the machine made taste just as good and are cheaper.  You can get smaller and thinner or larger and thicker. 

The last time I was there, I grabbed a can of hominy and got 2 tacos al pastor, which come with black beans, which I think is a nice addition.  I really like their salsa, but my partner thought it was a bit too spicy. I got the tacos on the handmade corn tortillas, which were fried a bit before adding the meat and beans, so they were a bit greasy, but that didn't bother me because the beans and meat weren't really greasy and I was really hungry!

They also sell a variety of homemade mole sauces which I can't wait to try!

All in all, this is a great place to know about if you like Mexican food, whether you like to buy it or make it at home.
author: Piper A.

description: Anything in these home made tortillas will be good. Only outside seating, but sill so worth it.
author: Isaac R.

description: The homemade tortillas, and pupusas, of which I tried all 4 kinds of pupusas were great. My favorite was the bean and cheese with their homemade cabbage slaw!  I also had  a bite of the chili relleno and the carnitas regular burrito, all equally tasty. I also tried two different types of tamales. Tamale verde was ok, a bit dry. The red tamale was quite good. I prefer a smoother moister masa, but the flavor was very enjoyable.  I will be ordering more pupusas to take home for my family.
author: Serita M.

description:
Best Mexican Food hands down. If it isn't La Palma Mexicatessen's Mexican food, then I can't eat it. 
I've met two of the owners and they are the nicest people in the world. Because of them and their staff, you'll understand why this place always has a line and filled with customers checking out their other grocery items.
Their prices are basically way too hard to believe. A burrito with basically everything (burrito super) in it is $6, and the taco sorona (which is super large as in larger than my face) for about $4. It has rice, sour cream, salsa fresca, cheese, and your choice of meat (I got the canitas).
My boyfriend had the burrito super for $6. It has gucamole, beans, rice, cilantro, sour cream, onions, and your choice of meat (he got the tongue).
My boyfriend had to help me finish my taco sorono, (again its bigger than my face), and had to save part of his burrito for later. (he's a big eater too).
I've had their quesadillas and they're equally as yummy as the tacos and burritos.
Lastly, I definitely recommend buying the gucamole. It's sooo delicous. The avocados in it are so fresh and aren't mushy at all. It's to die for.
author: Rach K.

description: Sure, ordering is like going to the DMV (3 separate lines, no handholding) but one bite of that carnitas taco with handmade blue corn tortilla and you are ready for more bureaucracy.
author: Alice W.

description: I always knew they did great catering, but now that I am in this hood, I love shopping here! We love all their various salsas and sauces- the moles, ceviche, nopales are all great and make a boring chicken dinner way more exciting. It's also nice to slow cook a pork shoulder and do a big taco buffet. The dark red salsa is my new favorite addition to everything!!! They also have dried beans bagged up by the pound and huaraches at the counter. Those are great to take for lunch with salsa and cheese!
author: Alisha A.

description:
Beware, food nerds. Once you taste the salty fatty porky wondrousness that is the Chicharones con Grasita (fried pork with fat) here, you will find yourself wandering back day after day for your fix. For me it's easy. I work around the corner, so wandering in every day for a super-Atkins lunch of a bag o'fried pork is yet another benefit of working in the public sector. 

Everything I have tried here is absolutely delicious. The tacos Sonora are something special.
author: Brock D.

description:
Didn't live up to the hype, at least for me anyways.  Wanted to try somewhere new and found la palma on yelp.  Had the carnitas and al pastor handmade tacos, plus a huarache  bc it looked good. 

Meat was just ok, a little bland, and the tacos seemed just slapped together.  I also thought the tortillas were bland too, but I don't love plain corn tortillas to begin with, so not a big deal there.

The place sure does look authentic though!
author: Mark B.

description:
La Palma is a celebration of food. This place houses a restaurant, molino and grocery store in the smallest of spaces.

The handmade tortillas are beyond amazing and La Palma truly celebrates the beautiful technique that is tortilla making.

I highly recommend their food and will return whenever possible to eat their yummy pork!
author: Hilda Z.

description: I went today to La Palma and haven't been for a while because the last time I ordered a dozen of tamales, half chicken and half pork, they hardly had any meat in them and they were mostly all masa. So i was disappointed again today with a mostly masa dozen of tamales. Beware if you order them by the half or dozen. I will look for tamales elsewhere.
author: J D.

description:
I was lovin this place before I even walked in the door. The smell was amazing and, when I got inside, I saw why. A small store up front but a bustling open kitchen in the back with lots of fresh stuff being made....corn tortillas, BBQ, chicharrons, etc. A jackpot of authentic Mexican cookin' going on back there. 

I got a small Colorado beef burrito and my daughter got a cheese quesadilla. We got some chips / salsa / guac on the side. Really yum! Fresh salsas are great. If you are on a quest for authentic Mexican food, put La Palma on the list.
author: Robert W.

description:
Would you like a hunk of fried pork?
It's rhetorical, the answer is yes!
I had chicharrones tacos and a pork nacatamale.
Best everything in SF.  I knew it was going to be good when she asked it I wanted the homemade tortillas.
Walk through the little store to the back order your goodness and then take it outside and sit at one of the tables on the side.
author: Jake H.

description:
Good quality south of the border Mexi food. Not big portions for the money you spend but definitely good food. I'd go back and try the carnitas. I had the chili verde. Eh. Good but not a lot of pork in it. The tortillas were good but make sure you ask for the homemade flour ones. They have a tortilla factory inside this store/restaurant. The tamales were very good, too.
I'd go back if in the area but not out of my way for it.
author: Gator B.

description:
I love their super burritos with carnitas!  The carnitas is nice and juicy and they have the best wrap ever!  They're made fresh, you actually see them making tortilla's in the back.  It's pretty awesome! I usually don't eat the burrito wraps (least favorite part of the burrito)  but theirs is thin, soft, chewy and holds together all the ingredients beautifully! A bite into their burrito is a mouthful of yummy Mexican goodness :)

I've also purchased their tubs of guacamole, it's delish! Best guacamole ever!
author: Veronica N.

description: I'm sorry, but this place does not live up to the hype. My super burrito tasted of grease and little else, but the chicken bone I nearly swallowed did add that touch of danger a diner really looks for in an eating establishment. The tacos were described by my bf as bland and unappealing, filled with cartilage and bones. Save a call to 911 and stop by a taco truck instead.
author: Todd X.

description:
As a Bay Area native, it's rare that I'm blown away by my meal at a taqueria. But there was something about my burrito yesterday that makes me want to come back every time I'm hungry. I'm pretty sure it was the tortilla - thick, chewy, crispy in all the right places, but the carnitas were delicious too.

I know it's a Mexican place, but their papusas are also really amazing. I had part of my friend's chicharron papusa and I couldn't stop picking at it despite her swatting my hand away. I can't wait to go back to try more food!

And the makeshift patio area on a nice day is pretty bomb.
author: Kara R.

description: Been going since I was a kid....still the best love the Hand Made Corn....Viva La Raza....
author: Matthew R.

description:
Was in the area for a xilonen ceremony at Raza park and took a look at what was around on yelp, saw this place and thought 'hey, why not.' I was with a friend and i still hadnt eaten anything yet. All i can say is the place is great for food. The line sometimes is long and the wait takes a bit but very worth it. everything is made right there same day fresh. not too pricey and very good. it was like having a home cooked meal all over again. :3 
Although not a sit down place(though they could seriously benefit from it if they were) all of it is worth for the food.
If you want some authentic mexican, fresh made food i recommend this place. the food was soooooooo good i might just be dreaming about this place for a while :3
author: Joji V.

description: Best place on mission , I think ! They're nachos are so good and their pupusas are huge if u normally get two somewhere else just get one here that's how big they are! I travel all the way from Richmond jus to get MASA from this place for tamales or tortillas !!!! Definitely recommend this place
author: Laura S.

description: Their price is competitive, but expect any chips and salsa to come with anything. I always get their burritos because they always make it with fresh tortillas. If you can choose (reg, wheat, tomato, spinach), the wheat tortilla is the way to go. Worse case, even the reg flour one is fresh and tasty. I dont really care for their nachos though, as its nothing special. Otherwise, havent had anything else. Btw, they make fresh tortillas, etc, that you can buy. They do close early though.
author: Allen K.

description:
When returning to San Francisco, there have been times I've driven the rental car right from SFO airport with luggage in the trunk straight to La Palma.  I love their carnitas flautas!  

They have a full tortilleria operating in the back, so you can get extremely fresh, barely-made tortillas by the dozen.  Other times I've purchased fresh carnitas, tamales and other awesome meals or parts thereof.  If you're making tamales at home, you can also get the tamale dough pre-made, ready and bagged up...
author: Mike A.

description:
This place is whats really real. I came here looking for masa to make tamales and I see a bunch of old mexican women feeling up packs of tortillas trying to find the warmest ones. It was at that point that I realized I made the right move heading down there. I ordered 20 lbs of masa cause that's how I roll. When they brought out the giant bag all the old ladies started looking at each other wondering who was about to wreck all that shit. They all shook their heads and then one looked at me. The expression on her face was pretty much "no it can't be" then they saw me take the masa. One of them asked me if it was for my mother, I told her no, I was making tamales and she told me I better call my mother.

the chips and tapatio packs are a good look too.
author: Sergio O.

description:
This restaurant is better than other gross fast food Mexican like el farolito, but they really should organize the the checkout and order process.

Their Huaraches are amazing!
author: Saulo A.

description: Hands down the best food in the mission. As long as you can figure out how to navigate the shop.
author: Pamela G.

description:
GET your MASA here!  This is our second year making Tamales.  Both years we bought 2/3 coarse prepared masa and 1/3 fine prepared masa.  It makes for a deliciously balanced tamal with a great texture.  YUM!

I also bought the dried chili pods (ancho, guajillo and new mexican) for my red sauce for the pork.

Their newest set up makes it a little easier to get in and out a bit more easily. 

My boyfriend loves their queso fresca.  I recommend the fresh salsas and guacamole.

Street parking is usually easy, staff is friendly and helpful.
author: Laura G.

description:
Best tamale I've ever had. Tasty cornmeal surrounding moist fresh chicken and even with tasty salsa inside. (See picture.) Best $2.10 I've ever spent.

The quesadilla (~$5) with carne asada was also pretty good (also see picture) - it was made fresh to order and came with GOOD homemade chunky guacamole, fresh salsa, and fresh creme instead or sour cream. 

La Palma is definitely in a very Mexican part of the Mission. I was one of the very few non-Mexican clientele in this mini Mexican corner store/delicatessen. I felt a bit out of place but it was so cool to see fresh tortillas being made in the back by the Mexican ladies, stacks of fresh packaged tortillas I can take home, and a hot case containing a huge mound of carnitas that you can buy and take home by the pound.  Some of the other Mexican customers bought big bags of tortilla flour or corn meal dough (masa). 

All the signs are in Spanish so luckily I had my pathetic but useful few years of high school Spanish ready. Funny - Thought I'd impress them and ordered the tamale and quesadilla in Spanish but got a reply "what kind of quesadilla do you want" in English. I guess my Spanish was so pitiful that they responded back in English!

Bottom line: Cool and very authentic Mexican place in the Mission for awesome tamales, good quesadillas, carnitas, and any other freshly made ingredients for your Mexican meal or restaurant.
author: Jim C.

description:
Some of the best Mexican food in the Mission, bar-none. Wander in from 24th street and spy the ladies in the back, making tortillas by hand. 

Whether you're looking for something made-to-order (select your food at the back counter, and take your receipt to the front to pay. I recommend the tacos dorados with carnitas, the gorditas, or tamales), or you can get your fixin's to go. 

One of the best places to buy corn husks and masa to make tamales, any (and all) dried Mexican chiles and fresh chicharones for tacos. The salsa, oh my god, the salsa! 

It's a deli, though, so they close early in the evening. The only seating available is located outside. Perfect for a sunny SF luncheon.
author: Christina S.

description:
La Palma Mexicatessen's super burrito with chicharones was the perfect example of too much of a good thing.  

The crispiness of the outer skin of the chicharones combined with the juiciness of the fat remaining created a hurricane of greasy goodness for the first half of the burrito.  However, the buildup of oils and the sudden desire to be on an exercise bike midway through the burrito made the second half more difficult to finish.  The chicharones even overwhelmed the sturdier whole wheat tortilla.  

However, because of the fresh tortilla and fair pricing, I be back for another try - next time with a different meat.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I am Mexican and came to live in the US in my late 20s. This is to say I am often not happy with how others define Mexican food (please don't fry it, add yellow cheese to it or mention a Burrito. I looove Burritos, by the way. But they are not Mexican.)

Anywaaay, La Palma is the real deal: it tastes like food I would find back home. 
The taco al pastor is epic, their roasted chicken taco my favorite, and they are really good with my numerous involuntary idiosyncrasies (no red tomato, no dairy) which makes them downright angelic. The prices are really really low. 

Many people complain about lines - just visit at off peak hours. And, use one of the tables outside to the left (if you take Mexican food home it gets cold and the tortillas get soggy.)
author: D Z.

description:
Firstly I have NO EXPERIENCE with Mexican cuisine. Sorry, I am a GRINGO of note !
Anyhow - best thing to do when stuck in a moment with a foreign menu glaring back at you .... ask the employees for their favorites !

So we did ... There were 3 of us and we all got a flavorful, decent meal for a reasonable price. 

I love that they make almost all of their food on the premises and the staff were SUPER FRIENDLY.

I would try it again in a heartbeat !
author: Fieora C.

description:
"Yes, I made the carnitas."  (Lie. I bought them at La Palma.  'cause why on earth would I go to all that trouble when I can by the most perfect pile of crisp-juicy carnitas meat at La Palma and toss it into the slow cooker to keep warm?)

Oh, and their bags of house-made tortilla chips?  Salty crisp golden triangles of heaven.

This is the best place to go for home-made items and you don't want to make at home yourself.  The ultimate party trick!  Gracias, La Palma!
author: Julie L.

description:
I dream about coming back here every day. If I lived in sf, this place would def be a weekly thing, without a doubt.

I only got a bunch of their packaged items when I was passing by with my boyfriend, but everything we got was so so incredibly good. The tortillas, beans, rice, all of it, to die for. Who knew such simple things when done so well could be so effin amazing? Oh, and I hate sour cream. I seriously cannot stand it and the salvadorean sour cream was so good. I couldn't stop eating it. It has a completely different flavor and texture than the American crap. Wow, if only I had been introduced to this type of sour cream first, I wouldn't be so averse to the typical stuff you find at the grocery store.
author: Trinh N.

description: Unbelievably good. They switch up their filling of the day for burritos. They have those fried meat pieces that are also very interesting.
author: Anders N.

description:
This place has great food & it's super cheap!  It's a grocery store/deli/restaurant with outdoor seating right across from some of the fantastic murals in the Mission district.

I got the 1/2 L Menudo for $3.39 (how cheap is that?!).  It was amazing!  The meat was incredibly soft and melted in my mouth.  If you are normally squeamish about stomach/intestine meat - don't be, it's nothing to be afraid of, it's just like any other meat but much softer and meltier.  It's actually very tasty.  The broth was spicy and savory.  It came with cabbage and onions to thicken the soup.  All in all, a very hearty, delicious meal, great for a cold day.  

I'm definitely coming back to try some of their other eats.
author: Bee M.

description: One of my favorite spots for food and Mexican groceries! Everything is so fresh and amazingly tasty. Doesn't get much better.
author: Bridget B.

description: Best tortas in the city, especially the breakfast torta. SOOO good! It really is inexpensive and a good find. You know everything is fresh since probably 2/3 of the establishment is a huge kitchen and you can see them making everything in the back. The only downside to this place is that once or twice I have been harassed by some poor soul who was a bit off his rocker.  Otherwise this place is awesome! I would suggest getting the food to go due to lack of seating.
author: Mark M.

description: I've been coming to this place since I was a kid. As a proud born and raised San Franciscan I can say this place never will dissapoint.  Fresh Tortillas? Masa? or maybe you need some fresh pupusas, tamales, or maybe even a burrito? Whatever you're craving maybe some fresh salsa, tortilla chips, or guacamole, tacos,?
