Lo que tu quieras!! this place has got it. :)  Try the pupusas they are the best in SF !
author: Yeni K.

description: Delicious burrito with carnitas. Looking forward to going back to try other things. The menu is extensive and the store has tons of goodies to buy. Someone was buying big bags of pre-made masa for tamales. This seems to be the local joint for all your latin food needs. Outside tables too.
author: K R.

description: Five stars for a hole in the wall taco joint? You better believe it.  Freshly made tortillas (they have 4 - 5 people making them fresh in back),  loads of variety, cheap prices, and one of the best burritos that I've ever had make this place a stop that's definitely worth it. Being right off the 101 from SFO doesn't hurt either...A great place to grab a quick bite before heading into the city.  Lastly, I love the outdoor seating.  Much nicer than sitting in some grimey taco place.  Check this place out -- you won't regret it.
author: JOHN C.

description: I tried la palma for the 1st time this weekend. The reviews are very accurate & did not disappoint! I tried a huarache & a carnitas taco, both very delicious. I will defenitely be coming back to la palma.
author: Yvonne M.

description:
Go La Palma, go!   Best Mexicatessen in the city.  

La Palma was one of my favorite places when I was a kid- apparently not much has changed.  My dad would always get me one of those round glass bottles of apple juice and a cup of jello layered in the colors of the Mexican flag, and I'd be happy for hours just watching the ladies slapping tortillas into shape by hand.  

Nowadays I'm forever craving their  tamales and carnitas (both of which you can buy in bulk- so good, but maybe not for you), and still love watching the ladies busy at work in the back. 

The tamales are especially amazing.  Here's a tip-  they freeze really well too.  I also really like their homemade tortilla chips:  colorful, non-greasy, and even organic. And of course, you can't get better handmade tortillas anywhere else. 

This is a family owned place and they really are the nicest people ever.
author: Joanne G.

description:
My mission was to do make-your-own "sopes" for the weekly poker gang.  

First and only stop necessary: La Palma Mexicatessen: you can buy freshly made, warm sope masa boats in packets of 12 for about $3.  Then, I asked for 2 pounds of carnitas meat.  Perfect.  Next, I grabbed a small tub of Mexican crema, some refried beans, avocados, salsa.  Presto: authentic sopes for the poker crew to gobble down while  looking for that inside straight.
author: Laurence W.

description:
I love this place.. You can get all kinds of stuff here, ingredients to make your own food, premade stuff that you can still use to make your own meals, and cooked meals too if you're hungry when you're in there. Also meats, cheeses, salsas, everything. Tamales around Christmas time. Free calendars every year around that time too.

The handmade flour tortillas are amazing. I used to eat them by themselves and I still could. And they're made with no perservatives. You can tell because if you don't eat em in 2 weeks they start getting moldy.

Oh yeah and fried platanos! I don't know anywhere else you can get all this.

It's right near 3 great panaderias too. Usually I try to go on Sundays while everyone's in church so I can get some churros at Dominguez Bakery.

Oh and I'm not sure when they remodeled, but it looks real nice now. There was nothing wrong with it before, but it just looks real modern and new now. Nice colorful menus that are easier to read. It's also a lot more roomier too.
author: Steve R.

description: This place is AMAZING!!!!!!!  IF you need chips or tortillas this is the place to buy them. THey are a great supermarket.  Everything is priced moderately.  The food is UNBELIEVABLE!!!!! The cubana torta is the best mexican torta i've ever had I could eat it every day!
author: Julie B.

description: Just ok in the take out category. I've been looking to add to my list of go-to favorites and wanted to try out this one on there for The Mission . . . the look continues. Good, but by no means great, or even real good. Carnitas is my yardstick for a taqueria and this was actually overdone and waaaaaay salty. Menu's too big not to try again, but when it comes to taquerias in SF, you can hit one once a week for a year and never eat at one twice. I will give it up for their home made tortillas. Worth the stop in for DIY night.
author: Tristan C.

description: Ordered 4 popusas.. 2cheese 1 bean n cheese and 1 revuelta. We got 3 been n cheese n 1 revuelta... Their salsa tastes like spaghetti sauce.. Not impressed!
author: Heather M.

description: Sometimes it's a little hard to field through the countless number of taquerias in San Francisco. Its can seem as if there is someone slinging tacos on every corner. Well, look no further... This place is delicious! They make fresh tortillas and are best delicious when served warm. Try the black bean huaraches for breakfast... Delicious! Everything is made in-house. My mouth is watering now... Nom nom.
author: Thomas Nathan S.

description:
They make the best tortillas, both corn and flour. The secret is the not so secret use of lard. It gives the flour tortillas a wonderful chew and depth that is not present in most other taquerias in SF. The flour tortillas for burritos are made TO ORDER. A premeasured lump of flour/lard is placed on a press and the perfectly round tortilla is then placed on the flattop. It does not get any fresher. Seriously awesome. 

Loss of a star because their al pastor is lacking in flavor, char, and freshness. The hunks of meat are on the large side and not too plentiful, meaning some areas of the burrito have no meat at all. Stick to asada, carnitas and chicharrones.
author: Bryan M.

description: I had to wait almost 15 mins for my food, but the cashier was very apologetic. Super Burrito was enormous and delicious! About $9.50 for two cans of DC and the burrito. I enjoyed sitting outside and stuffing my face in the sun.
author: Rachel C.

description: Excellent fresh corn tortillas, sopes, cooked meats - great for last minute pickup dinner parties. The real deal.
author: Caneel R.

description:
So for some reason, I've been on a Mexican food kick lately.  I mean seriously.  This was my fifth burrito/taco meal I've eaten in a week!

La Palma Mexicatessen is store/restaurant (take-out orders only).  They close at 6pm (5pm on wknds) so unless you're in the area during the day, you're SOL.  

Luckily, I happened to be in the neighborhood today and got a chance to check it out.  La Palma is known for its homemade tortillas and it was good to see that they sell these separately.

You order in the back, pay in the front and wait for your food in front as well.

I got the super burrito with carnitas.  They have specific tortillas (flour, whole wheat, cactus).  I got the cactus kind b/c it sounded interesting and I also got a chicken tamale.

The burrito definitely has some heft so you won't be disappointed if you're looking for something substantial.  I'm not sure if they got the order right with mine because the pork pieces were rather large and not the seasoned, browned pork that I normally associate with carnitas.  But after my first bite, I didn't really care as the large chunks of meat were very tender and of good quality.   

What was interesting though was first time that I can remember, I think the tortilla in the burrito overshadowed the meat and filling inside.  The tortilla is soft but has some substance so that it won't break and make a mess.  Typically, I don't look forward to the last bites of a burrito where it's all just carb-heavy tortilla where it's been folded in.  But in this case, that was the best part!

The tamale was just ok.  The chicken was dry and the tamale itself paled to the burrito.  Would skip this next time.

FYI, they do cater.
author: F. P.

description:
Love it! Drop a benjamin and you can throw a party and feed about 20 people. 

CHICARONES!!! Fried pork with skin and fat and a sprinkle of salt = BLISS

Papusas are huge (like 5-6 inches in diameter) and NOT covered in lard or shortening.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
oh my effing gawd... thankyou thank thankyou thankyou yelp. 

This place gets four stars for a bomb ass tasting burrito that litteraly i took one lok at and thought I can not wait to shove this in my mouth.  Moist and stuffed with goodness this is hands down the best yelp discovery to date.

Co worker and I had to go pick up some precast panels and as always did it during lunch so we could sample more fare from SF. Mexican sounded googd. The little place is on the corner and as always parking is kinda difficult in the mission area but we got all star parking. 

Ok here is how you order here. You walk in on the left next to the counter and there is a guy at the far end on the right who will take your order. You then proceed to either the guy on the right in the back or one of the two registers in the front of the store to pay. Its really confusing and crowded so hopefully this will help first timers. After you pay at one of the three stations you proceed to the register closest to the door near the front to pick up your food. 

Note they will call your number form the back, the front, the side, from all over. The pick up spot is the place in front however. Keep your receipt to in order to pick up your food. 

They get minus one star though because hey I get it I am a white girl sorry for living, but just like other people complain all the time about being treated differently it happens to us too. I wasn't sure of where to pay etc since it was my first time in there and I didn't understand the system. When I asked where to go one lady literally started speaking very loudly and saying one word at a time like I was an idiot. It wasn't to be helpful since immediatly afterwords she began speaking to her friend in spanish and gesturing at me to which they both laughed. My coworker speaks passble spanish and snapped back at them to which they shut up. I get it Im a dumb white girl. I'm spending money in the place you work so stfu. 

Thankfully the food outweighed the rudness but I def will explore other options before going back.
author: Meg N.

description: Food here is cheap.  The chicharrones look better than what they taste like.  They are pretty dry but some pieces are crunchy and some others are just very tough.  If you are in the area and want something cheap and greasy to eat definitely try this place.
author: Fatty A.

description:
This is a great place to get food to-go. . . I highly recommend this place for when you need to get amazing food for lots of people but need to keep it within a budget.  Of course, it's also perfect for one, for two, for four peeps.  La Palma ROCKS my world!

I fantasize about their chicken a la mexicana, rice, fresh tortillas and their avo-salsa-verde.  (Secret Confession:  when I am feeling blue, I will order the above items, sit in my car and eat blissfully by myself while listening to NPR)  Mmmmm. . . I also love to order their carnitas or carne asada by the pound and take it home to share with my peeps. 

They have great platters and party trays for your office party, movie night with your peeps, and also to impress your visiting family with authentic mind-blowing Mexican food.  

This is also the perfect food to bring to Stern Grove for summertime picnics.  I have made many folks completely green with envy when they see my La Palma extravaganza spread out on my blankets.

One thing to know. . . they close early so make sure to get there before 7 PM or else you will be bummed out!  Also bring change for the parking meters.

I love the remodel too!  Makes it easier to get your items. . .  Thanks, Haro Family for providing such a great service to San Francisco!
author: Freida N.

description:
I absolutely love this place.  I've been visiting La Palma regularly since I moved to the City a few years ago, and cannot get enough. While La Palma may be most visited for its many hot food options like tacos, tortas, burritos, and other mexican fare, they are also a full blown tortilleria. As a result, you can pick up all your fresh masa for tortillas, tamales, or pick up a dozen ready made tortillas. 

When I finally decided to do homemade tamales for Christmas last year, I was happy that La Palma wasn't far away. I picked up a few pounds of unprepared masa, some lard from the cold case, and was on my way.

There tortilla chips are also of the utmost quality, not bland and processed like what you get at Safeway.  These are the real deal, and perfect for ceviche, or your favorite salsa. They also have a few varieties of cheeses, chorizo, and my oh so favorite carnitas! They have a few different preparations, so make sure to grab a 1/4 pound of each to figure out your favorite.  

Overall, a great neighborhood spot. Next time you're in the area, or even if you're not in the area (I live across town), make a trip to La Palma, and I'm sure you'll find something you like.
author: David M.

description:
Just went here today for lunch...I can see why TB is raving about it. I just get to see the finish goods but its great to be in there...an authentic Mexican Mercado...;-) ...i meant this in a good way.

We had the shoft tell tacos and chicharon. Its great to know that you can get the maza here for tamales...I have always wanted to try cooking tamales. The place is packed and it looks like that they have everything you need when it comes to Latino cooking in there.

You got to check them out.
author: Malou C.

description: The chicharron here was a bit over fried IMO. They had the mouth feel of small finishing nails. It did have porky goodness once your teeth managed to break it down. Maybe I was here on a bad day? Be prepared to wait some time for your food during the lunch hour... The huarache had nice corn flavor.
author: John H.

description:
I had an Al Pastor Super Burrito with refried beans- my usual.

It was pretty good, with good ingredients and well-made. I wouldn't quite put it with El Farolito or Guadalajara, but I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it either, especially because it's close to Potrero and the relatively easy parking there.

The actual market looked really cool too, but I wasn't shopping at the moment.

The only reason this review isn't 5 stars is that the Tamarindo I ordered was expensive and so disgusting that I had to throw it away. It's literally the worst I've ever had- a mass of old sugar-water. The employee taking my order also couldn't speak English well enough to answer basic questions, which is understandable in the Mission but also disappointing.
author: Ned D.

description:
La Palma is still my go to place for corn tortillas.  Yum yummy.

However, I don't understand the lines to get the food here.  The salsa is pretty good but I thought the tamales were too large and too dry.  Really good with salsa slathered all over it but otherwise difficult ot choke down.

The staff, as always, is super friendly.
author: Jean K.

description: Came in for beans and rice.  Was happy to find they also have fresh made tortillas.  Friendly service.
author: Cali N.

description: Big, fat, child sized burritos. Um yes. Don't miss out on some diverse and delicious Mexican food! Keep in mind though, there is no seating inside, and just a few tables outside, so make a plan for where you are going to consume your big bad burrito.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
I'm going to chime in here and rave about La Palma.  What can be better than fresh hot tortillas for dinner any time i want them.  A bag of home made corn tortillas is under a buck!!

It's not just the tortillas.  In a neighborhood where there are three taquerias on every block, La Palma's food stands out.  That's really saying a lot.  

They also carry fresh sour cream, dairy-made cheeses, masa, corn husks and everything you need to make tamales --which I have every intention of trying!

Yep, there's a damned good reason that La Palma gets such high ratings.  I'm all about mom-pop shops and this is a shining example.  --They've been family-owned and in the Mission since 1953.
author: Amy A.

description:
La Palma is a classic SF establishment.  I have been coming here with my dad since I was a kid. Up until recently I thought it was just the tortillas and the chips that make this place amazing. I then ordered tacos, made on those hand made tortillas.  I then had to come back for a burrito, and now I understand that I am not realizing the full potential of La Palma.  Food here just tastes fresh, and I think that is what makes it so good

I cannot recommend this place enough, the food is fantastic, and the staff is always so friendly.
author: Eric M.

description:
I had not been here in 10 years, because we moved to NC.
We just went back last week and it may be even better than before.
We went to several Mexican restaurants in SF, but nothing came close.
It is so fabulous - I want to move back!!
It is great to watch the ladies making the tacos by hand.
Spanish is helpful, but they will get it right anyway.

The Chicharones are brilliant.  I had a chicharones burrito...OMG!!
author: Bob M.

description: After years of going to la Palma and other spots I can say with certainty this is the greatest burrito I have ever have.  Fresh made to order tortillas with amazing meat and a ton of veggies. Perfect * * * * *
author: Sean K.

description: Best tortillas in town! I love trying all the different types of tortillas! They even have handmade tortillas!! The food is also amazing! my favorite are the gorditas and chile verde. The sweet tamales are also delicious.
author: Adriana H.

description:
5 stars because:

- Every item in the burrito is fresh and succulent.
- I took a chance one day and ordered a chicken burrito (which is always dry as the desert at taquerias) and my god. Juicy, perfectly cooked goodness.
- Fresh tortillas, tortilla chips, traditional candies, REAL mexican food.
- Not too sure what the hell these other folks are talkin' about with the ladies on register. I think they're ADORABLE. Every time I come in, the younger lady with curly scrunched hair always smiles and speaks to me in Spanish - which really helps me brush up on mine. They're so wonderful there and super quick!
- Inexpensive, huge burritos with amazing portions, for me one burrito is two meals!

You need to go here, if you've never experienced this place.. DO IT.

...if I haaaad to say one negative thing it'd be that this place isn't open later! EXPAND YOUR HOURS LA PALMAAA!
author: Jena R.

description: Had 3 yummy crispy potato tacos that my daughter and I devoured!
author: MounFou N.

description:
This place is awesome. Lots of ingredients for Mexican food, great takeaway food. Cheap, cheap, cheap. The carnitas were superb.

They also make party plates for catering.
author: Sam P.

description:
I love this place... I have had more than 5 different orders from here so far, and all 5 were delicious. Anytime a coworker asks if I want anything from here is always a yes. So far I've tried

Crispy chicken tacos, pollo torta, grilled chicken, pork ribs, and carne asada plate. All with really good refried beans. I would order any of these dishes again.

Their is definitely a line during lunch rush hour. So get here before or after if you want to get your food in a timely manner.
author: Anthony V.

description: best fresh tortillas! the tortillas melt in your mouth. the food is great too. i like that they have tables outside for you to sit and enjoy the food. it's also cool that its a tortilla factory.
author: Farbod F.

description:
I recently used La Palma to order food for a party at work.  Ordering was a breeze.  I just walked in, told them what I wanted and when, and was told I could pay on pick-up.  In the end, the food was great, well-liked by the party goers, and there was a ton of it for what we paid.  Great deal.  

The only reason I cannot give them 5 stars is that when we arrived to pick up the food it was not ready.  In fact, it appeared some of the dishes had not been started.  We had to wait 45+ minutes for the food to be ready, which made us late for the party.  If you do decide to use them, make sure you allow some extra time at pick-up.
author: L C.

description:
Delicious!
I had La Palma cater an event for a CCSF event, and it was really decently priced for what we got:
25 chicken tamales
25 cheese enchiladas
24 mini chicarones pupusas
rice 
beans
lots of salsas
mmmmmmmmmmm
Everyone was so happy with it and they were ready to go with the order, and was on top of it- it made my day a whole lot easier!

Thanks La Palma!
author: Lauren S.

description:
Best burrito I've ever had.
The tortilla wrap is super soft and chewy.
So so good.
author: Fred C.

description:
This has always been my Favorite  place for burritos and HOMEMADE tortillas....the carnitas are perfect crispy succulence....and you can shop for mexican ingredients too....

What more can you ask for, Dinner and quick grocery shopping for your next meal. Authentic eats here folks!

Atmosphere is small, no place to sit, but who wants to do that when you're in the Mission on a nice Sunny day.
author: Ritz R.

description:
After traveling abroad for a few months sans burritos, I was ecstatic to walk into La Palma and order up some classic Mexican food.

As a first-timer, I went with a chicken taco on a handmade corn tortilla and a bean and cheese burrito. First things first - if you're a regular amount of hungry, you do not need more than a single burrito.

That being said, both the taco and burrito were delicious. The taco was fresh and tasty, and the chicken had excellent flavor. The black beans wreaked havoc on the tortilla, but it was nothing a few napkins couldn't handle.

The burrito was like a cheesy punch in the stomach. I loved it, but I walked away desperate for a bed in which to nap off the food coma.

Oh, and bonus points for charging a ridiculously-low $1.35 for Nantucket Nectars.
author: Nick S.

description:
Back when I was living with my Nicaraguan ex-boyfriend we went here for nacatamales. He thought it was one of the only places to get them but, in all honesty, he was not too in touch with his roots so that could be a gross misstatement. However, they were large and tasty plus relatively inexpensive which are all good things in my book.
Cheap, delicious, by the pound, homemade on the spot tortillas and carnitas were also amazing. 
Given that there's no real Mexican food on Kauai (where I now live) much less a mexiatessen I'd gladly go here again in a heartbeat.
author: Jill D.

description: We love Ida and the food at this place!   The tortilla's are AMAZING the food is always fresh and delicious.
author: Ronald S.

description: Can't say that the service was good it's a grocery store with food  made to order and pay at the cashier.  I ordered the veggies burrito and love it so much.  A must when visiting San Francisco.
author: Dom S.

description:
My husband and I were wandering around the Mission and we had a hankering for some good tacos/tamales/pupusas/tortas and the like.  Well, we were certainly in the right place for all those things, but which shop/restaurant to choose from!?!?  I say, choose the shop/restaurant with the biggest line, and that's how we came across La Palma.  The shop was packed with people buying fresh tortillas, masa, meats, and hot prepared items.  There were so many delicious items, many of which I'm not familiar with but were dying to try ( I was staring at a big pan of chicharrones at the deli and drooling).  

We ordered a couple of pupusas and an El Salvadorian tamale.  The tamale was wrapped in a plantain leaf rather than a corn husk (which is used in Mexican tamales).  The plantain leaf gives a different but delicious aroma to the masa.  The pupusas were delightfully chewy and filled with cheesy/meaty goodness, and were accompanied by some pickled cabbage and pupusa sauce.  

Yeah, we're coming back and we're bringing our appetites.
author: Beth K.

description:
This place is NUMBER ONE on Yelp's rating of all Mexican restaurants in the city.  Number ONE.  And there aren't even any tables or chairs here?!  Anyway, it's definitely good.

I got a perfect carnitas burrito.  Perfect shape, size, contents.  It held together like a beautiful bouquet of melded Mexican flavors.  The freshly made tortilla was an exquisite wrap...  Annnnd I just used the word "exquisite" to describe a tortilla.

A very busy shop at midday on Sunday, but I assume it's always pretty busy considering the numerous offerings of freshly-made items; packaged tortillas that almost melt the bag, they are so warm; fresh corn chips; and all sorts of other Mexissentials.

Very friendly, too!
author: Laura B.

description:
Several items from La Palma were brought in for a company dinner. Let me tell you - it was all delicious!

We had:  tortillas, carnitas, chicken mole, rice, beans, enchiladas, tamales, guacamole, salsa, and chips. I tried everything but the chips, enchiladas and tamales - I was way too full to eat one of everything! - and it was all outstanding. Specifically, the mole was *to die for* with a heavy dose of nutmeg and cinnamon to make it rich and enough spice to give it a healthy but pleasant burn.

I will definitely go there for food on my own, after having this take-out food. If it's that good to-go, I can imagine how good it is fresh from the source!
author: Karen C.

description: I'm only speaking for the tortillas.  Sometimes they're a great size, fit my pan just right.  Other times, whoever makes them is lazy or high, or just not paying attention, as they're so small and thick that you can't put anything on them, and they're nasty from being so thick.  La Palma, at least one of your tortilla makers needs to be schooled.  Meanwhile, I'll find another tortilla maker, these are useless.
author: julie t.

description:
Finally! I've been searching for a legit burrito in SF. I mean, I haven't been putting much effort into this search, but whatever, I found it!
I got to exercise my Spanish skills that I half learned while taking Spanish for like 4 years. 

I got a vegetarian burrito, SO good. I don't get sour cream or guacamole (yeah I know, I'm weird) so it's hard to get a good burrito that isn't super dry. HOORAY! Here it is! The tortilla knocks it out of the park. I also LOVE that there wasn't way too much salsa. I usually don't get salsa and have been getting it lately to add a little more to it, but man, they put the perfect amount! The hot sauce tops it off. Plus, it was like a foot long!

HUGE kick ass burrito at a SMALL price. What more could you want?
author: Shelby H.

description:
I must say I am usually extremely reluctant to go to the Mission district because of all the "ghetto danger" you see on the news.

Putting that aside, I am really glad that I did. It is such an overlooked part of San Francisco. It was my first time driving through Mission (and actually paying attention to my surroundings) there is just so much culture and diversity all jam packed into a few blocks. Also Dynamo Donuts is there as well. 

So La Palma Mexicatassen. I should mention do NOT park on Mission St. itself. Turn off into a block and park somewhere there... It's much easier to park and leave... And not risk getting sideswiped by an anonymous! 

For the price, and the burrito... WOW. BEST burrito I ever had. The amount of meat is ridiculous. This burrito is just filled with so much meat, I'm complaining that there isn't enough beans and rice! Love their carnitas, their chicken is just okay. Also the tamales really suck for some reason.... It is the opposite ratio of their burrito. It's like 80% masa (am I spelling it correctly? Forgive me, I have long forgotten Spanish since my high school days) the flour part, and 20% meat. And they were quite expensive, so SKIP tamales and get a delicious handmade tortilla (you can see them make it in the back!) AND buy their fresh salsa in the fridge on the side. Also you can taste their divine cheese they have at the back behind the register in the front where you pay. This woman who was in front of me said she drove all the way from Daly City to buy this cheese. I have no idea what it's called besides blanco queso (which means white cheese) but I am shocked, I love it. It is really fresh and crisp. You can definitely taste the difference. 

I would say run inside the store, order your burrito, run out safely to your car and drive off a reasonable distance and enjoy. Yes, I am still afraid to be in the Mission for more than 20 minutes. You'll thank me for the burrito later.
author: Jay L.

description:
Wanted to try this place because of the Yelp reviews. I was very disappointed when I tried to get jalapeños, the cashier informed me that they charge extra! So then I asked if I could substitute the sour cream and he stated that they don't do substitutions. Needless to say, I will never be back since the burritos were average at best. 

Taquerias are a dime a dozen in this town and most have these out for free. I won't be coming back!
author: Nansee P.

description:
Been coming here or years, mostly to buy masa dough for tamales during the holidays. Tamales always turn out great. Their tortillas are fantastic!!! I'm pretty sure they're the only tortilleria in the area. The food they have at the taqueria is so good. I had some potato tacos dorados and they were delicious. Even the simple tomato salsa the tacos come with was fantastic. I suspect, although not completely sure, that they fry them in manteca (lard) which is why they are so good. I'd rather eat manteca then poisonous vegetable oils. 
The only con is that the organization could be confusing for new comers. They're are three different cashiers and four different lines. Make sure you're in the right one. Order taqueria food towards the back right, order tortillas, masa etc dead center to the back, pay for taqueria food at the front right register closest to the entrance, and if you are just buying groceries, pay at the register that is to the left of you when you walk in.
author: Melissa M.

description: I finally found my San Diego in SF! When I was in college in SD, I had some of the best Mexican food, not to mention tortillas I ever ate.  Coming back to SF, Burrito Express didn't quite cut it anymore, although its still good! Found this place after a suggestion from a friend's dad and OMG!  I was transported back to my college days.  Their flour tortillas are the best!  We had an order of chicharones, carnitas, a bag of flour and one of corn tortillas, rice, beans, salsa, and avocado salsa.  The only thing is that it was a bit confusing where to order your food because there are a couple stations.
author: Christy A.

description:
Man, do I love this place....
I ttried almost everything on their menu but huaraches, gorditas and quesadillas are tops! And very reasonably priced too!
Can't wait to try the nopales tortillas I bought today.
author: Dario B.

description:
not perfect but I like their tortillas with NO peERVSEVATives

con:

the food is too salty for me
author: Sunny O.

description: Great food, had the best vegetarian burrito Iv ever had. And the staff were really friendly.
author: Elizabeth B.

description: Amazing spot with great simple street food and lots of offerings with an assortment of hand made tortillas
author: Alonso A.

description: I was really excited to try this place, I ordered a chicken super burrito and man was I disappointed. It was very bland which surprised me because I told them spicy. I also think the whole operation of the restaurant needs improving and the cashier only spoke Spanish but she seemed nice. I don't recommend this place and I won't be coming back.
author: Rose H.

description:
It's the best place to go on 24th Street if you want real Mexican food! 

I won't eat Mexican food anywhere else on 24th! 

The prices are reasonable and the quality is the best! 

If your in the mission and want a burrito, nachos, or flautas don't settle for El farrolito head down to la Palma.
author: Cindy D.

description: Best Mexican food EVER! I go here for lunch, dinner, parties, groceries, everything! I love this place!
author: Andrea P.

description:
I had a very vivid and complicated dream last night. 

I dreamed that I opened a gourmet tamale place called "Tamales". In my shop I was selling the most ridiculous over the top tamales, BBQ duck tamales, Havarti and fresh basil tamales, even desert tamales. The funny part is that anyone that knows me knows I generally don't like fancy food.

La Palma Mexicatessen's nacatamale is still my favorite.
author: Manny F.

description:
I loved the food. it was sooo soo good. i had a gordita, tacos de canasta, and french fries (freshly cut and made) i did not like the long wait for food, its a very small cluddler space it took way to long to be served. but the food made up for it....since it was really worth it!
:)
author: Erika A.

description: Fresh hot tortillas... yum.... hand made flour tortillas...Bought containers full of goodies to bring home and everyone put their own filling in the hot tortillas. Carnitas today was tender and moist. Last week, dried and hard... salsa good... guacamole was delicous for a plastic bucket... Refried beans, better than I have time to do. Only thing was the chicken... no one wanted any of it. It was shreds of dry white meat chicken in a tomato base stew. Of course, I ordered the largest container of it. Too bad, otherwise everything else was very good.
author: jane f.

description: I live far away from here and drive an hour or more to get here. And once I do I come across the rudest people. I was helped by 3 different people and all with a bad attitude. To the extent that I will not come back.
author: Raquel R.

description:
Now that I have tried La Palma three times, I can't really justify what all the hub-bubb is about this place. After giving the tamales, al pastor, carne asada and carnitas a shot, I found them all to be average at best and certainly not worth waiting in line for. The meats were all bland and overcooked--well more like sitting out all day--and by the time they have completed any order, some part of it has become cold and soggy. By the time I get my grub home from here (I live five blocks away) I am stuck with piles of foil-wrapped mushy tastelessness. 

There are few high points that earned the two stars, namely the tortillas, tortilla chips and the chicharones. If you need to do a little shopping to prepare your own meal, La Palma can hook you up with some decent ingredients and kick-ass tortillas, but if you are going for prepared mexican food, there are plenty of places that have La Palma beat in service, quality and taste.
author: Owen R.

description: I love fresh masa...last year i bought 5 pounds for tamales. Get there before the line out the door. While you are waiting for the chili verde to cook at home, buy some huarchetes con chorizo(spelled it wrong, i am gringo! and dont care), they have everything for your mexican feast. I cant wait to try something different for this christmas.
author: Shawn L.

description: Mexican food is my favorite, I'll have to admit. Normally I just grab a taco from a Tex-Mex fast food place, but this time my boyfriend and I decided to stop in and try some authentic Mexican food. I'm really glad we did. Our waiter couldn't speak English very well so he was kind of hard to understand, but he was very friendly at least. I got the quesadillas and my boyfriend got the enchiladas. We ended up splitting our food and sharing it because both of the meals were so good. I liked the authentic feel it gave off, and I do love extra cheesy quesadillas, so I left full and happy.
author: Monica L.

description: I got a huge order of food for a birthday party and people were raving!  We got a slew of burritos and quesadillas, but the real showstoppers were the flautas.  I'd recommend La Palma as an alternative to traditional catering any day!
author: Denise G.

description: One of the best tacos ive ever had!!_ carnitas and al pastor!! Cute seating area outside. Yummy strawberry drinks....the enchilladas were not that great. But will def. Come back for the tacos and homemade tortillas.
author: Cristyn T.

description:
What a cool place! I have just started coming to La Palma so I'm just getting used to what they offer. So far I've only gotten tacos (carnitas and tripitas) and a few grocery items such as tortillas and cheese. Their tacos are as good as they get, not better, but at the top with places like El Gran Taco Loco Taqueria San Jose and El Tonayense.

It's super crowded because it's a small store with a huge inventory. You must come here for prepared Mexican food and many of the things you might need to create your own Mexican meal. 

La Palma is one of the many great businesses you will find on 24th Street in the Mish.
author: Yvette K.

description:
I really wish I remembered more of my HS spanish when I go here. Still, I've not had any real problem ordering. You need patience here anyway, since it's very popular. Someday maybe I'll buy some masa here myself.

They make very big, very tasty burritos, with a good price attached. Their tacos suaves are quite tasty. And they have fresh tortillas to buy too. There are a lot of things on the menu i've not had a chance to try yet, but I'll be back and keep trying more.

The major downside to this place are the hours - closes by dinner time :(
author: neil c.

description:
Last time I tried a place solely due to it being in Yelp's top 5 (Ike's), I was a little disappoitned, as I had set my expectatiosn pretty high. While star reviews aren't everything though, you have to maintain an amazing level of consistency to be rated in the top restaurants in San Francisco.

And all the hype was true. I wasn't superhungry, so I only got a tamale, but this is the type of place where you can tell everything is going to be good.
author: Mark A.

description: In July of 1972 I had my first burrito . . . a chile verde burrito from La Palma. I had never tasted anything like it, nor anything as delicious. Oh my.
author: Jane M.

description:
Superlatives do not begin to describe this Mexican delicatessen. 

The tortillas, pupusas, gorditas, potato chips, chicharrones, etc are all made fresh in the morning. We got there at 930am and there was already a line of 4, eagerly awaiting their order.

We ordered a quart of menudo, a pupusa and a plate of carnitas quesadillas. While they prepared our meal, I shopped and bought some chorizo, pickled jalapenos and fresh gorditas to keep in the fridge. I really wanted to pick up some cotija and queso fresca, but already have a shelf-full of cheese I want to pillage through before buying any more queso. This, coming from a lactose intolerant individual.

We sat in front of the church on the sidewalk to eat our meal, and it was one of the most delightful experiences to have in SF on a warm winter day.

The bf and I practically licked our plates and foil clean. The pupusas had the aroma of fresh maize, and the quesadilla was sinfully delicious with helpful heapings of guacamole, sour cream and salsa. 

The menudo was full of soft, luscious organ meats and I even had a bone with marrow and gelatin still hanging on for dear life until meeting their doom at the hands of a hungry mamasita.

Driving home, we discussed starting a weekend tradition of driving out to the Outer Mission and eating on the sidewalk, which is a nice and tasty brunch alternative.
author: May T.

description:
There are just some places that don't have their sht together. 

This place does. 

The Carnitas are savory! And the next day leftovers-- just tastes even better! 

I used to order from La Palma for my office & (just about) everyone loves their food. 

The refried beans are yummy. Porky, yummy.
Their Guacamole' sauce is so addicting. Just right!

They are bad-ass at catering. They have Panchanga Trays. You can choose a tray category: A, B, C, D, et cetera.

If you're feeding a ton of people, you can basically just order a "Letter" and then set your trays out and have people dig in!

HELLO TO MY FRIENDS AT LA PALMA! ::WAVES::
author: Sheila S.

description: Great food! The super nachos are really good, but be prepared to share with people because it is impossible to finish by yourself!
author: Sandra F.

description: A great place to go for my favorite pupusas and huaraches, La Palma also does a great catering business and has delicious and cheap chips, salsa and fresh tortillas.
author: Robby W.

description:
Go to La Palma's because:
- you won't have to drive into the dirty heart of the Mission
- there's ample street parking
- they use the absolute freshest ingredients
- there's plenty of outdoor seating

The Qusadilla Suiza with Carnitas did not disappoint. Enough for 2 people. I'll be having the rest for dinner.
author: Carnley P.

description: I love mexico. I love mexican food. I love Mexican people. I love all things Mexican. I love La Palma Mexicatessen.  The tortillas, the guacamole, the beans, the sopas, the delicious fresh salsas and the obscure bottled salsas from mexico and the friendly people.  The food is so good. The vibe is lively and friendly...a great reminder of Mexico on a cold dreary San Francisco day...makes me wish I was there but La Palma is as close as I can get right now.
author: Nilu r.

description: THE BEST EVER!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I usually go to Pancho Villa's on 16th. St. for tacos. I buy Sopes & Pupusas & Tamales here!! THE BEST IN THE CITY OUTSIDE OF MEXICO!!  I lived in Mexico City!! BEST home made flavor!!! Buy the hand made tortillas, some green salsa, Queso Fresco, and Carnitas. Take them home. Heat the meat & torts. Put the meat in the torts w/ salsa, queso (cheese) and get ready for a "Food-Gasim!"
author: Sabrina R.

description:
I love coming here. It's like a candy shop for me.

There are all manner of Mexican food stuffs both fresh and canned. The mexicatessen part sells burritos and tortas but honestly I've never bothered. It's mostly about the tortillas for me.  If you haven't had a hand-made, still warm tortilla then you may want to ponder the fact that you haven't had a real tortilla. 

They also have arroz con leche popsicles. It's like frozen horchata on a stick! Fresh masa is like a $1 a pound. A dollar for a pound of ANYTHING is a good deal. Carnitas sold by the pound. Fried. Pork. By. The. Pound. Are you starting to see why I love this place? 

If the food feels as if someone's grandmother made it it's because someone's grandmother DID make it. There are like 20 women in the back making everything and it appears that none of them are younger than 60. Are there labor laws against things like this? Doesn't matter. MORE TORTILLAS, LADIES!!

If you love authentic Mexican food do yourself a favor and go to La Palma. Orale! Esta mierda es como CRACK! (I really don't like using that term but it sounds WAY cooler in Spanish.)
author: Josua P.

description: Awesome authentic Mexican food.  I've gotten the gordita, taco senora, and the huarrache here and they were all very tasty.  I especially love their home-made guacs and salsas.  Yum!
author: Elaine N.

description: Huaraches: get them. Reminds me of oblong pupusas. I love the frijoles ones. They also have fresh tortillas, chicharrones, and other prepared foods and ingredients I haven't tried. Accessible on the 48 bus line or a 1/2 mile walk from 24th St and Mission. Within walking distance are many popular places including Humphrey Slocombe. Maybe walking is the way to go.
author: Yan E.

description: Best taqueria I've been to in the mission. And that's saying something. Get the super chicken burrito.
author: Nikhil G.

description:
I actually haven't been here in a few years but the  other day my hubby brought home some hand made corn tortillas, carnitas, and all the fixin's. It was fabulously yummy. Simply good. This is authentic Mexican food and products, not the Bobby Flay version all fanicified and stuff.

I was first introduced to this place several years ago by a co-worker at Green's who was from the Yucatan. He showed a group of us how to make tamales wrapped in banana leaves rather than corn husks. It was fun, simple and delicious. We bought the pre-made masa, mole, and the banana leaves from La Palma to save time. We put chicken, pork, olives, and unsweetened chocolate in them as well. Sometimes the simplest things in life end up being the best.

I introduced my husband to this place and now he visits and utilizes their yummy items more than me. I think this place is so successful because the food is always fresh and you get the feeling that a little old grandma is making all the food for you and only you. 

I really should visit them again soon!!
author: Esa Y.

description:
Man I feel like an dick giving this place only a 3 star rating because all of you like it SOOOO much. 

Granted, it does have white person appeal (see my favorite website http://stuffwhitepeoplelike.wordpress.com/).  See concept #71 . I am white fyi so stop asking.

It is as follows: 
In most situations, white people are very comforted by seeing their own kind. However, when they are eating at a new ethnic restaurant or traveling to a foreign nation, nothing spoils their fun more than seeing another white person.

Many white people will look into the window of an ethnic restaurant to see if there are other white people in there. It is determined to be an acceptable restaurant if the white people in there are accompanied by ethnic friends. But if there is a table occupied entirely by white people, it is deemed unacceptable.

The arrival of the "other white people" to either restaurants or vacation spots instantly means that lines will grow, authenticity will be lost, and the euphoria of being a cultural pioneer will be over.

So yea- this place is an AUTHENTIC mexican joint on 24th thats for sure. My gringo authentico meter tells me so and I must say that makes it exciting in itself. The menu is in spanish not english (sweet!). When they yell out your number, its in spanish not english (the food here must be amazing!).

If you want to have some fun, take your friend who isn't from California and doesn't speak a lick of spanish and watch them tremble in terror as they try to figure everything out and place an order.  They place will confuse the shit out of them and make them very uncomfortable.

Alright onto the food. This is just for tacos nothing else. They DO make their own tortillas in the back (bonus) but you know what? These were tasty I admit but really thick and by the time I took my to go order back to where I was eating they were also soggy (perhaps this is my fault). I'm also not a huge fan of the carne asada. Its fine, nothing special though. You can find meat and salsa and cilantro better than this in the mission (If I catch you putting beans on your taco I will kick you in the balls, or the...well...you will get kicked in the crotch region)

I still say Farolito up the street on Mission and 24th kicks this places ass. 

Morgan gives you 3 stars...
author: Morgan H.

description: Delicious assortment of Mexican food in a carry out setting.  Like many have said, the homemade tortillas are definitely one of the draws.  Getting the taco on a homemade tortilla is definitely worth it.  The carnitas are a little greasy but very tasty.  This is a great spot to pick up provisions for a tailgate or for a group watching sports.
author: Brandon I.

description:
La Palma makes good burritos, tacos, and papusas.  What I like most, though, are their bags full o' home made tortillas.  You can watch them making the tortillas while you are standing around waiting for your burrito.  I have a tortilla press, but for the price, I'd rather let the experts at La Palma make them for me.  Finaly, if you're looking for ingredients to cook authentic Mexican food a casa, La Palma is a great resource.

Wow - an entire review without sarcasm or off-topic anecdotes!  Amazing!
author: Joe C.

description:
Delicious pupusas and huaraches.  

Wonderful selection of Mexican groceries, chiles and frozen food.
author: lisa g.

description:
This review is for the catering services only. 

Last Friday my household held a pre-wedding party for about 75 people. The invitation promised food, drink, and mirth, and who are we to come up short? Since so many of the guests were in from the east coast, our goal was to provide a little bit of local flavor to the proceedings, and we entrusted La Palma with part one of that. La Palma, in a word, knocked it out of the park. 

I started the process on Monday by phone and followed up on Tuesday to speak with the people directly, get a sense for the place, and leave a deposit. I left feeling confident that I had made an excellent choice. They were super helpful and walked me through all the ordering (even helping me remember to think of the vegetarians!), provided me an estimate and I paid the deposit. I will say that a background in Spanish helped to talk to a few of the people, but there was plenty of English spoken by most of the people I talked to. If that sort of thing concerns you. 

Picked up the food on Friday afternoon at 12:30, and they were ready to go as soon as they saw me. I never caught the name of the woman who helped us out, but she and her team helped us get everything into the car, explained the additional preparation requirements for some of the foods, and offered serving advice. They even called immediately when realizing I had left one small part of the order behind that I wouldn't likely have noticed if they didn't. We ordered the A, B, and C plates, which fed the 75 people they estimated it would with plenty of leftovers for our house! Yay to tamales all week. All the food came out to just shy of $500, which sounds like a lot until you break it down. $7 a person for catering? Pretty good, I think. 

Most importantly of all, our guests were impressed - very happy with the food and some particularly rave reviews. I've got the same rave reviews for Paco and his crew at La Palma. They handled our business professionally, made some great tasting food, and most importantly pulled the whole thing off with no more a hassle than the four blocks we had to return to get the last set of tamales. When you're planning an event with such potential for stress, it's nice to have a business you can count on, and La Palma was that.
author: Ian M.

description: How can you rely on these people? I called 2 weeks in advance of our catering date, and placed the order, with a request for veggi enchiladas instead of plain cheese. They said that it would be an extra charge and they would call me back in 30 mins with the amount. The took my credit card information over the call. However, a week and at least 10 phone calls later they have not bothered to call back. Every person you get on the phone says you need to talk to someone else - how come i didn't need to call someone else to give my credit card information or place the order? They lied to me with a straight face multiple times, apologized multiple times and didn't call back multiple times. Now I've made mt 11th call to cancel the order - and guess what? The catering manager (a position they created over the  phone with me) lol is out today, so they will leave her a message. Instead of dealing with these inept fools I've had to call my credit card company and tell them not to accept any charges from them. Extremely poor customer service. Very disappointing.
author: Ritesh R.

description: I really wanted to find some fresh tortilla chips, salsa, and guacamole for a pay per view boxing get together. And after doing some searching on yelp, I decided to give this place a shot. I'm really glad I did. The pico de gallo salsa was good, but you really have to get the guacamole because it's superrrr good. And the tortillas were definitely not your boring typical bag of chips, they were thick and freshly made. This is definitely the place to go for yummy tortilla chips and salsas for a party. Hopefully I will get to the other stuff they sell, which all looks pretty good, but for now I'm all content with the chips and dips.
author: April D.

description:
ok, i have been back to la palma on several occasions now, and i have to upgrade them to 4 stars. their pupusas are pretty darn tasty. had a pupusa revuelta the other day with curtido and salsa. the pupusa was crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside, and had just the right seasoning (definitely not too salty or greasy, which i hate in my food). the curtido was not too strong either, and the salsa was a perfect accompaniment to a very well-made piece of heaven. also, i salivate every time i walk by their chicarron, which i will buy very soon in a taco or burrito.

they have revamped their interior recently, as the place looks much more upbeat. the food i believe is still the same, but the service is more gringo-friendly, which i am forever grateful for.
author: Danny C.

description:
I waited 1.5 hours this morning with my mom in line outside for fresh masa on xmas eve.  I think it'll be worth it as my mom's tamales are amazing.  We were the only white ladies in line but no one seemed to be making fun of us (so much as I could tell).
If you want a cheap trip to Mexico hang out around here for a while.  The only language you will hear is Spanish (except the AA building across the street) and you are sure be greeted kindly.  I enjoyed watching all the families out and about.
author: Lauren S.

description:
????  Highly advise to bring a Spanish speaking friend if you don't speak Spanish.  The menu on the board is in Spanish and they call out your number in Spanish.

I had a meal plate with meat, rice and beans.  It was OK.  Others -- soft tortillas, tortilla chips and guacamole -- were also OK.  

Overall, the food was average, or little better for some.  Just didn't get the hype.
author: Mami T.

description:
So I stopped in La Palma for lunch one afternoon, excited after reading all of the impressive Yelp reviews.  I was so eager to finally have my La Palma experience and couldn't wait to run home and yelp my 5 star review.  Hell, I even brought my friend from Mexico to order so that I didn't miss out on any of the authenticity.

Now maybe it was over-hyped for me, but I was incredibly underwhelmed.  I'm not at all the type of person who tries to defy the crowd, and hand out overly critical reviews, but honestly, it just wasn't THAT amazing.  The tortillas for the tacos were quite good, I'll definitely give you that - freshly made and delicious, but the toppings and the rest of the condiments were really mediocre.  Aside from the tortillas, the rest was just like any other taqueria in the Mission.  The tacos weren't all that flavorful and the other items we tried were all pretty greasy.  Now, I may sound like a snob, but my Mexican friend completely agreed.  The fact that the food was super cheap did help to make up for the fact that it wasn't anything outstanding.  It made me think "hey, you get what you pay for."
author: Dubs W.

description:
I'VE FOUND YOU, REAL MEXICAN FOOD.

I'm used to So-Cal down-ole dirty Mexican shops like La Palma, and this one does even better.

Okay, so there's a language barrier, but WHATEVER the stuff is so good.

My roomie and I pitstopped here to get food on our hike to Twin Peaks, but we soon found after eating this stuff that we weren't going to make it up Twin Peaks as fast as we thought.

+ FOOD

Carnitas Taco
Carnitas Gordita
Carnitas Burrito
Carne Asada Nachos
Quesadilla

LESS THAN $20. WTFACK.

Everything tasted so good and so real. The shop is literally just a shop, the food stuff is in the back where you can see them make fresh tortillas. This is how it's supposed to be for reals!

I need to taste all the meats, but I just splurged on carnitas everything this time around because I was so happy. They take their sweet time to make a real quesadilla too. We were wondering why it took longer than the other simply wrapped stuff, but they were legitimately heating it up and getting it to the just the right texture.

Must...go...again...soon...
author: Charles L.

description: Delicious Chincarones (sp?) tacos, tried my first papusoa here it was great,  I'd ask for no beans or on the side of the tacos. 2 tacos, about 4$
author: Jill F.

description:
3 tips:

1) When you order "carne asada" anything at the deli counter, they fish out a piece and grill it up then and only then.  So you will wait for a little longer for the freshness...yeah!

2) If you cannot find a ripe avocado at any one of the half-dozen or so produce markets within 3 blocks of here, you will surely find one here.

3) Hand-made tortillas make great walking snacks, but the pupusas will get messy, unless they're eaten cold.
author: Bruce L.

description: I always enjoy going to La Palma. It's a down-to-earth, authentic, and delicious place to get some good Mexican food. You can also just buy stuff from the delicatessen part of the store to make your own Mexican food. And their tamales are the best I've had in San Francisco.
author: Ian F.

description: Handmade tortillas. Must chicharones taco. Carnitas also delicious. Tables and chairs outside-definite plus!
author: Ro B.

description:
I really like this Mexicatessen.  I love to make Pazole. But before I discovered La Palma, I would have to go to several different stores for all of the spices and sides I needed.  They have the ancho chili peppers and lots of them.  This is key to a true Pazole.  They also have ground pasilla peppers. And any spice you would ever possibly need for a Mexican dish.
The daily made tortillas and tortilla chips are among the best. And their salsas, the tomatilla, pico di gallo and the Chile X Picante. Why even bother trying to choose among them? Just buy all three.  
So far I'm just a customer of the grocery store. But they do serve prepared food to go in the back and one of these days I will try it.
author: Cindy B.

description:
I walked past this place for four years when I was in high school. And it's not until i'm twice that age that I come here for some eating. Yes, I know I'm old. Shut up.

So anyways, when you come in, grab a number and wait your turn. Make sure you know your numbers in spanish too. Speaking spanish here has its benefits, and I'm happy to say that I'm so glad I stuck around to learn it. 

Once your number is called, you rattle off your order: tamales (mexican/nicaraguan?), burrito, pupusas, and the like. If you're OG order your masa here for some home made tamales. The service isn't super fast, but by god, the wait is worth it. Make sure you grab some chips on the way out the door too.

This place is the bomb. I regret not coming in any earlier, but I'm so happy that I have found a little piece of heaven on 24th Street.

PS: sometimes I'm the only non-latino person in there who just happens to speak spanish. only in SF.
author: Charlene L.

description:
Mex deli heaven - cheap, fresh and amazing.  I haven't had guacamole this good in months.  It's on the thick side, uneven and chunky,  just as I prefer. You can see chunks of ripe avocado.   And the salsa fresca is great.  I didn't see a salsa bar but they sell a couple of types of salsa a la carte.  I saw the army of women making tortillas and putting tortillas in a machine...they come out on a conveyor belt.  

I touched the bag of huaraches and the warmth made them irresistible.  Huaraches remind me of pupusas but they're longer and flatter (a little smaller than Trader Joe's naan but similar in shape and thickness).  They're made with fresh masa and filled with mashed black beans.  They're cooked on a griddle.  Slight chewy, they're great as a base for toppings.  They're about 60 cents each (a steal).  Top them with guacamole and salsa and you can feed two people for $8.  The chicken tamale was only $2!  And it was delicious with that dreamy guacamole.  

I didn't spend too much time looking at the grocery items since it's such a small, cramped space.  I didn't see any pan dulce though but there are plenty of places to pick that up in the neighborhood (try La Victoria's or Dominguez Bakery).
author: Lolia S.

description: A wonderful little neighborhood gem that offers all kinds of fresh Mexican goodies in a corner store / taqueria fashion. The big bags of fresh chips are amazing and very fairly priced, also the pupusas are warm and fresh every time I go in there.
author: Zachary S.

description:
Been coming here since my poor old Nonie decided to stop making her own tortillas (so, forever)...and good news, La Palma's are wayyyyyy better! (sorry, Nonie). There are endless forms of the almighty tortilla here...just as many as there are forms of women. You have your thin, flat ones (great for bending and twisting), your thicker ones that can handle a little more meat (sorry!), and little curvy cups that beckon as you walk by to be filled with as many toppings as you can find. 

Oh, and their pupusas are awesome!
author: Annie B.

description: After living in the Mission for 4 years I have finally found the holy grail of street tacos - the green pork on handmade tortillas is the best taco I have EVER eaten - I have to go there for lunch again now I've yelped about it!  Go - Weird paying and collecting ones order system, but once you figure it out it's all good - plus you can sit on their sidewalk tables to enjoy the food and the neighborhood - FAB
author: Jo H.

description:
My La Palma Experience
I was hosting a Mexican Fiesta for a few of my friends and I heard this place sells fresh hand made tortillas. So I drove around the mission for a good half hour looking for this place. Someone told me it was on 21st and Florida. I drove to 21st -- it wasn't there. So I proceeded to go two more blocks to 23rd and turned back. I was determined to find it so I drove up folsom from 21st to 23rd again. I couldn't find it and got so frustrated I decided to go home. As I was driving down Florida to head to the freeway, I pass 24th and there it was. 

I found sweet parking right in front. I went in and stood in the long line. The spanish speaking ladies were shouting out their orders and getting all these yummy smelling food. I kept nodding at the guy behind the counter to tell him I was ready to order. No reaction. After about 5 minutes of this, the guy next to me shows me a ticket number. Arghh...so I try and find that  ticket machine, but can't. The store is so small...where else can they hide it. I finally found it and got my order of mexican rice and 3 bags of tortillas. 

I go home and cooked up a delicious meal of burritos with the fresh tortillas. I kept the rest in the freezer and they taste just as good.
author: Sue L.

description:
For the past year I saw La Palma on the front page of Yelp and wondered why? So I finally went to see if it made sense.

This is a little slice of Mexico in the mission, imagine that :). Very unique. Basically it's a Mexican deli where you can get fresh dough for your tortillas and chips. The salsa is priced pretty reasonably 3.60 for a tub. The chips were super salty but good. 

I got a burrito when I visited. I wasn't blown away but I don't think this place is for burritos.
author: Michael S.

description:
Why did it take me 10 years to find this place? Born and raised in SoCal, I grew up eating Mexican food - maybe our own version, but still, outside CA, not many kids savored eating guacamole and salsa with tacos at the ripe age of 8.

But back to the Mission and this revelation. Mother-in-law in tow for a long weekend visit, we decided to make dinner at home -featuring margaritas with limonitos (key limes), rotisserie bbq chicken, fresh guacamole, and a queso fresco appetizer with tomatillo salsa.

Once in the store, I spied a woman with a huge cylinder shaped piece of fresh cheese walking towards the door. We asked about queso fresco, and my husband thought he was directed to the fridge along the wall near the register. NNNNOOOOOOO.....just before giving up, I found it - the white earthy treasure under a cloche near the register - freshly made queso fresco. We actually had a storebought version at home from Whole Foods and the difference was not only visible and taste-able - it was vastly different. FRESH IS BETTER!!

We also left with a warm stack of fresh corn tortillas made in house - no preservatives. Sorry forgot to mention we also made a delicious chicken tortilla soup with them!

Will be back for more.

p.s. Everyone who works at La Palma was wonderful!
author: Mariangela S.

description:
Character. Choice. Cheer.

I love this place. Mexicatessen is the best way to gain an appreciation for the universe of Mexican sandwiches once you boil (or fry!) it down to its basics. 

Why does La Palma call themselves a Mexicatessen? 
They focus on Latin "sandwiches" (i.e. fillings bounded by bread) made out of fresh ingredients, while you wait, much like a deli would for Anglo-Judaic sandwiches. Taking that analogy further, if Kasa is the Indian Taqueria and is Apple-esque (see my review), then Mexicatessen is the Latin Katz's Deli and is very Microsoft-esqsue (complex and bewildering choices!). Phew! The Earl of Sandwich would pause from his card game to pay heed...

I could barely understand the range of options, but realised by watching my friends order, that  Mexican sandwich architecture works like this:
1) Pick a filling (some kind of meat + cheese + garnish + onions etc.)
2) Pick any one of several outer bread shells (thin flappy, thin crispy, corn-based, flour-based, soggy, oily, fluffy, puffy, fatty, or fried)
3) Decide if the filling goes inside, atop, rolled-within or sandwiched within the bread shell, then process by frying, grilling or smothering in liquids of varying degrees of sogginess or greasiness
3) Execute. Add sides like chips, salsas etc. for flavor and crunch
4) Pack into white styrofoam box. Bill. Close.

Mexican sandwiches include pupusas, gorditas, quesadillas, burritos and so on. Grab your boxes and retire to Dolores park, or the green medians in Bernal Heights, and enjoy! I also liked their shelves, with a range of private labelled Latin American merchandise, makes for great stocking up, or photography. The colors are heartwarming and genuine. Nice name too, keep up the good fight!
author: Amit S.

description: Awesome!   The best tamales, fresh flour tortillas made with lard and butter, and freshly made guacamole.  But even better than their food is the people who work there. They are friendly, know their products, efficient, fun and damn hard workers. If you  want excellent freshly made Mexican food - this is the place to go!!
author: Ed P.

description:
I'll give La Palma an extra star for two good things I had on a subsequent visit:

1) Fried plantains.  Awesome and cheap.

2) Nacatamales.  A nacatamal is a Central American tamal filled with corn meal masa (of course), seasoned pork, and god knows what else all wrapped in a banana leaf and steamed.  These were pretty good, I think, since I've never had one before, but it wasn't bad at all!  And it was much more interesting than a typical bland tamal.

Nevertheless, the pupusas are still boring.  Buena suerte!
author: Daniel S.

description: best tortillas ever! warm and delicious. love the chicharron too
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
Wonderful place for freshly made Mexican food ranging from tortillas to tamales to masa to Mexican cheeses.
The store is small and a little cramped, but it's worth working your way to the back to see the women patting out corn tortillas and smelling the fresh food.
author: Philip C.

description:
The reason spanish classes were so ineffective in high school, I've realized, is because we didn't take class trips to La Palma. It's amazing how much tears and sweat rolling down your face as you furiously try to decipher the menu and remember how to properly conjugate verbs before your number is called can do for one's spanish speaking skills. To further improve effectiveness, refuse to accept help in english and assure them "no hay problema!" over and over again. 

Actually, come here a little later at night and not only are they super friendly and helpful, there's no line and you can take your sweet time. The tamales and carnitas here are awesome and super cheap. Really, there's nothing better than food that costs barely anything more than making a meal at home, tastes amazing, and comes with a one-minute, pulse-accelerating spanish lesson.
author: Eric H.

description:
I went by here to pick up some tamales for a pre work event. Have not been here in awhile. I ended up buying some fresh tortillias and salsa. The tamales were a hit. 
They also sell masa for regular and sweet tamales. 
Everyone is so nice here too. 
Plus a great selection of chilies.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Ok, we get it. Great tortillas. But everyone seems to be missing out on what makes La Palma so friggin' good. 

Listen, I'll only say it once: POTATO CHIPS

Hand cut and fried on the spot (used to be in lard, but they got all health conscious or some crap) and comes in a plastic baggie with tapatio hot sauce to drizzle on top. sweet.
author: Brer R.

description:
Wow, I'm super impressed and excited about La Palma!  

Tortillas are so fresh, tasty and wonderful!

The carne asada burrito is fantastic!  Finally, a carne that is perfectly spiced and expertly grilled!!!  The burrito was rolled perfectly--every bite had all of the flavors.  MMM!

Very happy and will definitely be going back!
author: Tysen C.

description: Everything is fresh and made from scratch. Great tacos, stuffed tortillas, and the burritos are OK.. But the chicharrones rock. Eat 'em while they're hot, and you'll think you died and went to heaven.
author: Matt M.

description: This place is the BOMB!!!! If you make Tamales, they have the best masa around!!!! The staff is AWESOME, The other foods are GREAT, and they have chiles and other stuff to make GREAT Tamales. I've gone back on a weekly basis as I'm making a ton of tamales lately and I just LOVE this place!!!!
author: Troy H.

description:
We found La Palma while doing research on the best place to buy a large amount of carnitas for our housewarming party. We were delighted to find that this Mexicatessen's version of the tasty delight of carnivores everywhere lived up to expectations. The burritos are killer, the flat flour quesadillas only rivaled by La Taq, and their selection is the most authentic I've seen in San Francisco. Chicharron, anyone? La Palma is even complete with little old abuelas in the back hand rolling thick, doughy tortillas and hacking up huge mounds of crispy pork.

Don't forget to grab a ticket as you enter, or you'll end up standing around like an idiot waiting for your turn. Oh, and it's extremely helpful to brush up on your Spanish ordering skills beforehand. As it's a Mexicatessen and not a restaurant or taqueria, all orders are take-out only. The plus side is that you can stock up on taco sauce and other grocery items while you wait.

By the way - 10 pounds of carnitas is more than you think. We could have done with half as much, but then wouldn't have had the joy of days of carnitas burritos at home and even a special carnitas chili I invented to use the leftovers. We still had to throw out 2 or 3 pounds, despite our best efforts. And we never even opened our second pack of 100 tortillas. Oops.
author: Veronica L.

description:
I came to La Palma to buy supplies for the Mexican food cooking night that a few friends and I were planning, and have gotta say, I was kind of underwhelmed with their grocery selection. But yes, the tortillas were required, and I gladly partaked in their fresh goodness.

I haven't had take-out from here yet, but perhaps my tune will change after I have.
author: Courtney P.

description: Everything here is amazing. Eat in or prepare at home, most authentic Mexican in SF.
author: Greg L.

description:
My sister in law and I decided to make tamales ( first time ever, no previous experience. How crazy is that for 2 white girls to take on this
task)?. We decided that we would use the prepared masa dough from
La Palma and handle all other elements of tamale making on our own. What a hoot we had making tamales and drinking beer and wine. We ended up making 80 tamales and they were absolutely delicious. I give
70 percent of the credit to the masa from La Palma and the rest of the credit to the two crazy drunk white girls.
author: Cindy J.

description:
This is one of the best places to eat in the Mission. Everything here is handmade, fresh!

BTW Get a Tamale from here. (if you like the Tamale Lady's, this is where she buys hers from)
author: Danny S.

description:
My ma and I bought some masa preparada for tamale makin a while back and she claimed this was the best pre-prepped masa she's ever used - my ma would know. I also happen to know that the Tamale Lady uses this masa (I asked her), so nuff said. 

Oh! - and the carnitas are the real deal; the best I've had in the City. Nuff said take two.
author: Prattle P.

description:
I thought I'd died and gone to... the Yucatan.

Seriously the best tortillas I've ever had, made by the finest hardworking masa-pounding army of old ladies I've ever seen. Swing by and grab some fresh warm tortillas (they'll ask you "manos" or "machina", go manos if you never have before), as much carnitas as you can safely pack away, some chili verde, proceed directly to the nearest flat surface and assemble the best taco you've ever had north of the border.

Once you've recovered, head back in for some fresh chorizo (for tomorrow morning's eggs, duh) and any manner of fresh, dried, canned, bottled mexican delight that tickles your fancy.

Wash. Rinse. Repeat. Rejoice.
author: Ben D.

description:
YAY!!!!! I finally found the best mexican food the city.  I have been searching for years!  This place makes everything fresh!  You can see the authentic mexican mamas making the tortillas right behind the counter.  When I order food here it makes me proud to be Mexican.  You see everyone working hard and taking pride in what they are cooking.

My favorite are the CARNITAS, they are fresh and juicy.  I sometimes order it by the pound and bring it home to make tacos, if I'm taking a lunch break I will order it in a burrito...it is the BEST burrito I have ever ordered...EVER!!!  My boyfriend loves the rotisserie chicken!  We order chicken in so many different place in the city, (italian, mediterrean, middle eastern, american) and by far they have the moistest and most flavorful chicken.  Everything I have tried here has been Fantastic!!!

THANK YOU LA PALMA for being Authentic and Delicious!!!
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
Wonderful carnitas!
The tortillas are made fresh in house!
By far the best mexican food in sf!!!
author: Christopher L.

description:
I was looking for a bakery when I stumbled across this place.  I knew I had to go inside and check it out.  I'm never in this part of town.  Since then I've been here about four times and I'm already trying to figure out when I can go again.  Some of the things I've purchased (some repeatedly):

Jamaica Mix
Fresh Sopes
Fresh Tortillas
Fresh Gorditas stuffed with beans and cheese, potatoes and chicarrones
Queso Fresco
Fresh Tamarind
Burritos
Refried Beans
Salsa
Guacamole
Crema Mexicana
Cajeta (yum!!)
Chips

I love the tortillas and they even have the itty bitty ones used for tacos.  All of the corn products are made right on the spot!  How did I not ever know about 24th St. and all the goodies found there?  Everything is pretty cheap and the people there are all pretty helpful.

I'll be back this weekend in the morning!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Four stars for flour and corn tortillas made in front of you in every size and thickness, some still warm in the bag.  I think they're inventing new types and shapes of tortillas, just like pasta companies invent their own shapes.  Another star if the sandwiches and toppings inside are even half as good as the tortillas.

Really good chips too and random Mexican corner store items.  You can grab and at the register or take a number and wait your turn (there's usually a line) for the prepared meals. Very yum.

..update review...

Just had the food.  Yup, five stars.  Wow.  Fresh tortillas makes all the difference.
author: Gil S.

description:
The rare five-star review.  I threw a party recently and bought ten (yes, ten!) pounds of carnitas from here, 180 handmade corn tortillas, a couple of Mexican salsas, and proceeded to have a full on Mexican gorge-fest back at the proverbial ranch.  We ate about 5 - 6 pounds of the carnitas when all was said and done several days later.  At $6 a pound, I can see why there are so many taquerias springing up, and it almost made me think I'd just make my own henceforth.  However, it turns out that having ten pounds of carnitas in one place can lead to a feeling of carnitas immersion rarely experienced.  I went at LEAST two weeks without eating carnitas, sort of on the rebound, and then tonight at Gordo Taqueria on 9th and Irving was when I finally broke through and had it again.

One more tale of glory -- my girlfriend and I went on an exploratory expedition here before the grand Carnitas Purchasing of 2007, and tried things from the back counter including a pork tamale (which I loved, had a jalapeno spanning its length inside that I didn't notice until the whole thing slid into my mouth on the first bite, and boy, was that spicy), a chicharron taco (crispy pork skin with bits of meat attached, oh yeah, this thing clogged my arteries so fast I didn't even have time to say CARNITAS, g/f says I can only eat two a year, I am counting the days), a carne asada taco (my personal fave this time around), and a carnitas quesadilla (yummmm).  All high qual.

When we picked up the carnitas bag we also grabbed several burritos, this time I felt edificated so I got a carne asada burrito, my friend had same, and g/f had chicken.  It turns out their chicken is seriously tasty.

These guys have earned my undying love and affection.  It's tough to order since you really will do better if you know some spanish, and don't miss the number-ticket machine at the front right when you walk in.  But deal with it -- it's worth it.
author: Walter K.

description:
La Palma!?! More like, Da Bomb-a! (DONT JUDGE)

This place is the real deal, and has been a staple of my life since childhood. There is nothing to really say. Go if you have never been. That is all.
author: Bobby P.

description: El Toro, Pancho Villa, Cancun, El Faro all surround us but we like to drive down to La Palma for delicious carne asada and carnitas.  They have a family package - 3lbs carne asada, 3lbs carnitas, quart of rice/beans, 1 pt gucamole, 1/2 chile picante, 2lbs of corn toritillas that can feed 10 adults for under $50 is an awesome deal!
author: Mason M.

description:
My dear friend Carmen recommended La Palma to me and I've been passing the recommendation on to others. The best place to get freshly made tortillas, smokin' good carnitas, and everything else that goes with authentic, delicious Mexican food.

Oh and don't forget to pick up a bag of the homemade potato chips!
author: umeboshi l.

description:
I cannot walk by with more than a dollar in my pocket and not buy tortillas.  If I only have a dollar, I buy a packet of machine-made corn tortillas, still warm and steaming up the plastic.  When I have a few bucks more, I splurge for the hand-made ones.
