My latest crush: tortillas made with masa con nopalitos.  Who knew that ground-up cactus would make the best tortillas in the Mission that much better?
author: J P.

description:
Just broke my only-free-range-meat rule to try the lauded huaraches con pollo here and they've made a believer out of me.  
Seriously, the combination of toppings and the chicken prep was nothing short of mexican heaven, and all for $3.50!
The cozy visual of the tortillas being made by the women in the back only heightened the experience (which was good because it took around 15 minutes to get my order).  I really had to resist buying a huge bag of warm tortillas and queso (as I'm headed out of town tomorrow) but I will be back to stock my fridge very soon.
Here's a better idea.  Put in your order, scoot down the street for a Phil's coffee, and return for some of the best cheap authentic mex I've had in this city.
author: Ann Larie V.

description:
Every now and then, I'm in need of carnitas...BY THE POUND!  What a perfect was of being super lazy on a weekend afternoon that merges into the evening: grabbing some carnitas and fresh corn tortillas, some salsa fresca, or getting cilantro and onions (and chopping it up), avocados. Perfect. 

They cater as well (as you could see by the menu)...Super Bowl Sunday is coming up. Hmmm...
author: Ted P.

description:
Oh, La Palma, how do you pack so much Mexiliciousness into such a tiny space? 

Sure you can get tacos, but also my favorite less known Mexican foods: huaraches, Sopes and Pozole. You can buy several kinds of mole paste. You can even buy caramel made from goats milk and the best homemade tortillas.  You can also buy everything you need to make tamales. 

It is chaotic, and you will either have to eat at the tables outside, or on the steps of the church diagonally across the street, but in exchange you can get a delicious meal for cheap and have it be fresh and tasty. And did I say Cheap? Barato!
author: Darien W.

description: I just had the best burrito that I've had in the Bay area so far.  The tortilla was fresh, chewy and soft;  the rice and beans were cooked and seasoned perfectly.  The only shortfall is lack of salsa inside the burrito, but otherwise it's perfect!!   Looking forward to my next burrito :)
author: Mandy C.

description: Where locals go for BOMB carnitas, best tortillas in SF, huaraches, queso fresco... my family is always happy when they see me holding the yellow La Palma bags :)  ok...craving La Palma now!!!
author: Humble T.

description: I think La Palma is the "BOMB" cause they have fresh hand made  tortillas (blue corn) organic ...very hard to find anywhere else in the US ...I'm so spoil by them.. and their Champurrado to die for! and the atole de maiz. and TAMALES .HMMMMM!!!!!!!! anyway it reminds me of my childhood...Thanks La Palma... "Cause I"M AN ALIEN"
author: laura c.

description:
3.5 Stars.  I enjoyed it a lot, but I felt like there's better.  And because I haven't yet found better, I decided to let it count as 4 stars.  

The friends and I stopped in for pupusas, but ended up with huaraches and gorditas.  No one was disappointed.  The huaraches were stuffed with an aromatic bean and cheese filling.  My order of huaraches con carnitas was good ... and big.  Although, after one, I felt like I could eat another.  One and a half would've probably been just enough to get me through a couple of hours.

I heard the gordita was also good, but I didn't get a chance to try it as they shoveled it away too quickly.  I think it's a good indicator that the food is ... edible.

All in all, I'd go again, definitely.
author: Ann E.

description:
La Palma, La Palma, La Palma! They sell carnitas by the pound, crispy on the outside and perfectly tender and moist on the inside.  Where else can you get homemade tortillas still steaming up the bag along with the perfect guacamole?  

La Palma took me back to the Shafter bakery, Grandpa Juan would pick up breakfast consisting of fresh tortillas, carnitas and pan dulce.  I have found a new love in the city and the appreciation of my past just by one bite of fresh, homemade Mexican food.
author: Valarie A.

description:
Mission reminds me of Mexican style Chinatown by looks and the authentic ethnic food. When I walked into La Palma, I almost felt like the first Asian ever to step foot into the premise. Didn't grab a number like I was suppose to for ordering and I stood their like a straight fool trying to read the menu which was in Spanish only. Thank god I knew carne, carnitas, burrito, and suiza since that's all I wanted to eat anyways. The burrito with carne asada was ridiculously good with the homemade tortillas. There's a team of mamacitas in the back pounding out tortillas for days so that they are fresh and delicious. The quesadilla (suiza) was aight, nothing special but still good. 

No tables or seats so you gotta do the to-go. Or if you're sky ballin, you can eat on top of a BMW parked outside like I did. Too bad it wasn't mine.
author: Ed L.

description:
Reminds me of another classic El Modelo in Albuquerque, Nuevo Mexico.
La Palma is special and it is the real deal.  Great homemade tamales, corn and flour tortillas.  Order a taco--enjoy the Carne Asada--the best in the Bay Area; succulent, lean and absolutely amazing!

This is a special place for me to get my comfort food.
While you are here pick up masa to make your own tamales.  This place smells like sweet corn.  I love this place.
A place to go for some gorgeous chiles-- you will never see these chiles in a mainline grocer.  Absolutely beautiful.  Chiles they have Chile Nuevo Mexico, Chile Ancho, Chile  Pasilla - esta muy bonitas!

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
CARNITAS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
The best in the city and the tortillas are killer. I eat lunch with the guys from my shop every Friday and La Palma is always a favorite!
author: JR H.

description:
All this place needs is a few tables tucked away somewhere.  Once you get to the back and see the ladies making tortillas by hand, you know it's gotta be good.  Their handmade tortilla tacos are about the size of a small burrito, and muy delicioso.

Best bet is to get a handmade taco to go, then walk down to Garfield Square at 25th and Harrison and enjoy your food in the Mission sun.
author: Phill W.

description: Best taco joint in SF, no question. This place is amazing, they make fresh tortillas in the back (thick or thin ones), and they can make you basically anything you want to order. For chicken dishes, for example, they have roast chicken, grilled chicken, and chicken in spicy sauce. Only downfall is that it isn't open late, so the only time I can really go is on weekend afternoons.
author: Dana O.

description: The food here is delicioso! This is the closest thing to Mexican home cooking. All the food is fresh, and so yummy!!
author: Jessica C.

description: The whole wheat flour tortillas,of course no lard. They are thick and wonderful .My boyfriend is now addicted.YUMM-O.
author: Lia N.

description:
Oh, carnitas. Chile verde by the quart. Masa preparada, queso fresco, pupusas, chicharrones. The menu is huge and scary, but if you take a minute, relax and draw on all of those years of high school Spanish, you won't be sorry. How can you go wrong with a pound of carnitas? If you have to, just point! 
Tamales: Buy 5 lbs of masa, a quart of chile colorado, cheese, a few cans of veggies, beans, and a bag of corn husks.  Ooh, and make some fresh corn to throw in. Host a tamale making party, fill 'em (read: invite your sister and her boyfriend over and have them do all the work), tie 'em, steam 'em, eat what you can and freeze the rest. Tamale making has never been easier.
author: tracy d.

description: Great family run business, good hand made tortillas, fast service always polite. Fresh chips and salsa.  Carnitas are the best!!   I come from a family of amazing mexican cooks and this food is just like home!!!  , I highly recommend the hand made tortillas and the carnitas, the chorizos and queso fresco are great for the perfect breakfast!
author: Lisa D.

description:
Meats from La Gallinita? Check.
Fruit & Cheese from Casa Lucas? Check.

And now for the most important stop...tortillas (and various tortilla relatives) from La Palma.  Seriously, if I lived closer I would only buy tortillas here.  All freshly hand-made, it's yet another crippling blow to my Safeway-induced grocery complacency.  Damn you San Francisco!
author: Wes M.

description:
I stumbled upon La Palma after buying some produce down the street at Casa Lucas(Also amazing!!!). I have long been addicted to mexican food, especially the classic chips and salsa before any meal. After buying their all natural home made tortilla chips, I cannot bring myself to buy anything else. I work at a grocery store, and while that is more convenient than a trip to the mission, it is nowhere near as satisfying. I have yet to try the food they prepare there except for the rice. That is my next plan of action. The rice is good, complimented the food we made at home. The chips... insane. Most may think chips are chips, but my mexican boyfriend and I are addicted. These are the only tortilla chips either of us will eat with OR WITHOUT salsa.... something neither of us would normally crave to do. 


Yay La Palma for your deliciously perfect AND all natural chips :)

Another perk? $2.29 for their medium sized bag (which is huge)
author: Kate V.

description:
Delicious fresh tamales at a bargain price. I discovered this place thanks to another Yelper and am 100% grateful. 

Be sure you are good with pointing or speaking Spanish, because this is a legit ethnic grocery store.
author: Liz K.

description:
A few friends and I decided to have a chili cook-off on Super Bowl Sunday this year.  While my friends were buying Safeway Select ground turkey for their comical attempts at chili, I dropped by La Palma to pick up some fresh chorizo and some dried ancho chiles for my famous Spicy Lamb & Chorizo Chili (tm).  Not to toot my own horn, but my chili was easily the best tasting thing I have ever put in my mouth in my entire life.  Thanks, La Palma.

Needless to say, I won the cook-off.
author: Alex P.

description:
I tried this spot becuase of yelp. 
It's not a big place, but it's oozing with all of the mexican food essentials.

The salsas are AMAZING! Especially the green one with avocado (not guacamole). Man, I could eat that shit on my breakfast cereal.
author: Lawrence A.

description:
Excellent Mexican fair at cheap price. I've been to Mexico, and I know how to say certain phrases, but I highly recommend reading Leah E's review as a tutorial. After getting the number ticket at the front, there weren't that much time to gaze at the menu too long, so I advise you to have something in your mind before you go. 

I ordered tacos (pollo/carnitas) with tortilla mano - the thick handmade tortilla, and pollo tamale. I loved the tacos. The flavors definitely brought back the memories of the trip to the Mexico. Although, I thought that the size of the tortilla was bigger than I imagined. Tamale was so-so for me. Ok, it was a lot better than the average Mexican restaurant tamale, but didn't quite like the filling, and the outer masa casing was just ok. 

It's a grocery store, so there isn't a place to sit down inside. My brother and I spotted a church across the street and sat down on its front steps. It was a very pleasant lunch experience.
author: Mio S.

description: I love this place for it's chile verde burrito super, with black beans and without crema.  I can't speak about their other dishes, but the burritos are RICOS and very LARGE.  You definitely get the bang for your buck.  This place is legit, and the people that work there usually address you in spanish initially, but no worries if you can't speak it, they also speak english.  The only bummer is there is no inside seating.
author: Kaitlin H.

description:
What's not to like about a Mexicatessen? What a unique and wonderful shop! I have never tried any of their prepared foods, but La Palma always has delish smells wafting out of it's front doors. This was the first place I tried gorditas stuffed with chicarron and a Salvadorian quesadilla. I am hooked! I had no idea what to expect from the odd looking chunk of Salvadorian quesadilla, but it was superb! It was a semisweet ultra dense "cake" which tasted of yummy cheese (Parmesan perhaps) and was covered in sesame seeds. It tasted like an improved version of cornbread to me and I gobbled it up. A Salvadorian quesadilla is my kind of treat, simple, carb and cheese filled, and delish!  The gorditas were yummy as well and I would definitely buy them again.

I would have given them 5 stars, but I purchased their flour tortillas and was disappointed. I am spoiled by the thick, flavorful tortillas from Casa Vicky's in San Jose. In my mind, they can't be beat!
author: Sarah P.

description: Great catering---- the package deals made it easy on me so that I didn't have to pick individual items for 30 people. Food was great---maybe too great, as now I've been put in charge of ordering the food for all future office parties---and delivered right to door (for $40 delivery fee). We now have tons of delicious leftovers. Thanks, Mariana!
author: Kate L.

description: This place is a nice (not so much) hole in the wall in the Mission district.  Their shop is in the front (and sell their own "home" made products and their restaurant section is in the back.  Going to the counter, you order whatever you'd like from their menu board, wait to get your food, then pay at the counter (you can also get additional stuff on your way to the stand).  I ordered a House special number one and a taco.  They both were very flavorful and and were delicous! Getting your food takes a while and there is a wait to checkout, but worth the wait.
author: Adam S.

description:
If you like mexican food, why not just get all the necessary ingredients and make it yourself? That's the concept of La Palma, they sell you really good quality meats, beans, rice, tortillas, tamales, pretty much whatever you need. Want that crumbly cubed mexican cheese? They got that! Not to mention most things are cheap as hell.

I get their pork chile verde and I am able to have mexican feasts for 4-5 days  at a time.
author: Daniel R.

description: A Mexican friend of mine turned me onto this place. It is really good. It's not a restaurant though. Its a market with to go food. I am a Chile Relleno fanatic and they are the best I have had here. They have the best Carnitas too. Buy a couple of pounds and throw in the freezer and use when you are ready. They also make their own tamales and tortillas. The best, and reasonable in price too.
author: Dougaldo C.

description: I've been coming here since kindergarten when my teacher used to buy us pupusas for lunch at the mini park btw york and bryant st. Balompie and la santaneca are my favorite pupusa places now but I still visit La Palma once in a while because it feels nolstalgic. Also as far as I know, this is the place to go if you need to stock up on any ingredients for making tamales etc. The staff here are also super nice.
author: Tina L.

description: Picked up a big bag of Guajillo Chiles for $2.19, Huge bag of Tortilla chips for $3.50 and Huge pint of salsa for $3.39.  This place rocks.
author: Jim J.

description: Did a take out for a group of 6.  The blue corn gorditas stuffed with zuccini were excellent.  Guacamole dip perfect.  Salvadorean sour cream was tangy and rich.  Carne Asada delicious, though a bit dry.  Person behind the counter saw me looking a bit lost and came to help very patiently.  Will return.
author: Ash A.

description:
I love shopping here, but eating here isn't always such a pleasure. 

Three stars for the prepared food: The last time I went, the carnitas in my taco were grey and bland; I can't believe i actually threw away a carnitas taco, but I did.

As a store, I give La Palma four stars. It's my go-to place for fresh masa -- simple or preparada (with lard), fina for tortillas or coarse for tamales -- handmade tortillas, and gorgeous fresh-rendered lard for all those Mexican cooking projects. The grocery selection isn't as good as over at Casa Lucas a few doors down, though.
author: anita c.

description:
I haven't tried the taqueria options at La Palma yet, but they get 5 stars for their "Chile X Picante" housemade salsa. Yes, it appears that I have found a panacea for my spice addiction. This salsa, so very hot! It's a blended roasted chile concoction in 1/2 pint tubs located in the fridge case along the walls. 

They also get props for varying varieties of chicharrones and selling lotto tickets. Their hours prohibit me from hitting up my spicy fix more often, perhaps that's part of its allure.
author: Candice L.

description:
I grew up in the neighborhood and was raised on La Palma's handmade corn tortillas and queso fresco.  It ruined me for all other corn tortillas.  I won't eat them if they are not handmade EVER and neither should you. 

I was just home this weekend, stocked up at La Palma and brought a ton of stuff back to NYC.  When my mom comes to visit me here she brings La Palma with her.  It's like that!  FIRME!
author: Josie C.

description: Full Mexican and more menu and a little store all in one.  Greasy but good tacos.  Worst tamale I ever ate though.  I would advise against the tamales.  The place looks clean and offers friendly service.
author: Scott A.

description:
First off, this is no seating in this place, so don't plan to eat there.

Probably the best place for masa, tortillas and sopes (to take home and fill your self). The tamales are ok (stick to the Salvadorian style, there much better than the Mexican style). Most of those "Mexican" women are actually Central Americans though, not that. there's anything wrong with that. I think it's owned by Salvadorians because I rarely hear a Mexican accent in the joint.

They also sell molcajetes there for a reasonable price as well as chiles, queso fresco and dry beans.

I've never tried the cooked food except for an occasional tamal.
author: Hank S.

description:
Weird. I found myself speaking really bad Spanglish ordering my food, though I had the accent going. The chicken taco, in a handmade tortilla, w/black beans and fresh salsa was delicious. Same for the chicharron taco, but that one was a bit too tough for me.

Rookies: get a number, order your food, pay at the front counter. You should've seen how lost I looked. :-)
author: Maximillian M.

description: Just bought dozens of tortillas for dinner party and they are just not the best. Big variety of products. The take away food looks good.
author: Fred  D.

description: ¡Que delicioso!  Character abounds, tortillas astound,  sopes cause your tummy to make wonderful sounds.  Reasonably priced.  Unreasonably satisfying.  Go with someone whose initials are EAH and you'll never be the same.
author: N A.

description:
With the tortilla machine humming along, a group of customers watched a staff member count and stuff a bag with soft, warm corn tortillas. As the bag was filled and priced, she continued pulling torts from the machine, counting and setting them aside. While they were all warm and fresh, I noticed that those in line, waiting for their number to be called for other items, would wait until the most recent bag was placed on the counter, with the other just packaged tortillas, so they could get the freshest bag. It made for an interesting watch, all the bags were just plucked from the tortilla machine, but everyone wanted the most recently packed bag. 

Anyway ... this is a great place in The Mission to pick up Mexican food staples, from masa for tamales to fresh tortillas to cheeses and other food stuff.
author: Rafael R.

description:
Looking for spinach tortillas to add variety and taste to your burrittos this is the place!!!!! I've looked at other stores but no luck yet.  

PS  They usually have to be specially ordered but they surpass the plain 'ol flour tortillas
author: D M.

description:
I ordered a chicken taco on a handmade tortilla, with guacamole. SO GOOD. Lots of really good chicken, perfect tortilla, great guacamole. It was a suprising amount of food - usually one taco isn't much, but this was substantial. and delicious!

I also had a tamale (chicken), which was fine, but left much to be desired, especially compared to the taco of awesomeness. It was a little dry, not bad, but not really good either.

Bonus points because no one laughed at me when I ordered in Spanish. I got exactly what I wanted, so my spanish must be at least understandable, if not good. Good to know.
author: zoe s.

description: One of my all time favorite places since childhood!! the burritos are ah-mazing..hand-made FRESH flour tortillas..its like music to my taste buds!
author: Mig I.

description: This is by far the best mexican food I have ever eaten.  The first time I went there the ordering/purchasing process was a little confusing, but it was so worth it.  I got the veggie burrito, and it was incredible.  The ingredients taste so fresh and aren't heavy as so many mexican dishes are.  The portions are humongous, so expect to have some leftovers.  Their tortillas are handmade and you can watch them being made as you order your food, the tortillas alone are enough to make the hour long bus ride worth it.  I always buy some tortillas and some of their amazing guacamole to take home.  Their pupusas are also amazing and very authentic.  I love sitting outside on the patio and enjoying the sunny weather in the Mission as there is no indoor seating.
author: brittany r.

description: We discovered La Palma probably almost a year ago, and the relationship has been on and off. La Palma is not a sit down restaurant. There are a couple outside tables, if it's nice out, but basically, this is a Mexican grocery store with a take out part in the back. There is a sign that stresses that they use no preservatives. They make their own...everything. Their tortillas are awesome tasting, the cactus chips, the guacamole, they even make their own popsicles, which I've never tried. The burritos are big and tasty, but the best things are the papusas (bean & cheese!) and the tacos sonoras. Oh and one special pepper thing they had only one time and we've never been able to find it again. Those tacos are not the tiny things you get in other places. HOWEVER, it's not always good. For one thing, they often as not mess up our order. The order, payment, and getting the food are in 4 different places, which complicates things and clutters the store, and when everything's wrapped up in the bag it's hard to check. By the time we get home half an hour later or so, it's too far to go back when we realize we're missing some things, or this has the wrong meat, or meat when it's supposed to be vegetarian, etc. Virtually every time we go, we say ok, we're on a break from La Palma now. The next time comes around and we say hmm we were on a break, why? Then we eat there and remember. This last time, we ordered five tacos sonoras between the two of us, four carnitas and one asade. It was an easy order, so they only messed it up as they were taking it, and we received the right food. I think that was the FIRST time we got everything we've ordered, and we've been there at least ten times. But it was fatty. Often the meat is good quality, but you can't tell when, sometimes it will be poor. I did LOVE that tortilla on the taco, and the sauces, but La Palma, we're once again on a break. However, I do recommend that you come here. Especially if you want the fixings to make something at home, go here. Or, just try their various offerings, especially if you live nearby and can run back easily if you realize you're missing something. It's not often you get cheap, homemade, non preservative food. (yes, did I mention it's really cheap yay). As you can see, I'm still conflicted about this place.
author: Merredith L.

description:
La Palma is the best place we've found in SF to purchase Mexican staples like freshly-made warm corn tortillas, bags of dried chiles (Pasilla, Nuevo Mexico, Guajillo -- you name it), queso fresco, fresh tortilla chips, chorizo, and house-made salsas. The prepared foods are ridiculously delicious -- even something as simple as a quesadilla is wonderful at La Palma. If you go on Sundays, expect long lines and don't forget to grab a number as you walk in the door (the dispenser's usually to your right as you enter). If you're lucky, they'll have freshly-made huaraches (flat football-shaped corn tortillas filled with refried beans) or gorditas filled with chicharrones bagged and ready for you to carry out.

Note that La Palma has a small selection of canned goods (beans, hominy, etc.) but DOES NOT carry fresh produce -- but quit yer bitchin' because there are plenty of other places nearby that do.

Best Sunday morning idea ever: head to La Palma to grab supplies for a last-minute brunch with friends -- chorizo (to pan fry and scramble with eggs and a little S&P), canned black beans (to toss into a pot with jalapenos, onions, tons of cumin, and a dash of salt), and fresh salsa, queso fresco, and crema to serve on the side. And if they've got fresh, hot huaraches, your guests will beg to stay for dinner.
author: J C.

description: The tortillas are the best!  I had to grab a bunch of them on my recent trip to SF.  Much better than the crappy, bland tortillas here on the east coast.  I just wish you could order them online : (
author: Kitty C.

description: This place passes the simple but surprisingly difficult Chile Relleno Test with flying colors, mmm mmmmm! Delicious homemade relleno sauce as well....
author: j-bird y.

description: Of all the mexican fare to choose from in the mission, i think this is THE BEST.  They make their own EVERYTHING.  Tortillas, chips, chiccarones, salsa, etc.  I havent had anything ther I didnt love.
author: LT B.

description: I just moved into the Mission and think this is a great place. Fantastic breakfast burittos.
author: William M.

description:
I love this place. I've been coming since I was a kid with my dad and I still drive all the way from San Jose just to visit those wonderful ladies slaving away to make me the best tortillas ever. This is the only place I fully enjoy eating carnitas from b/c i'm not really big on pork but they just make it so goooood.

Best place ever.
author: Ashley T.

description:
I cannot put into words how much I love this place. This place is the only reason I would ever consider moving into the mission, it's that bomb.

Awesome tacos, bomb ass chicarone, tasty carnitas, Mexican AND El Salvadorian tamales. OH YEA, almost forgot, those sexy ladies in the back making tortillas all day. I could wait in line and stare at them all day. And if you've ever been here around lunch time, you will wait all day and you'll get a chance to take in the visual appeal of those sexy ladies pounding vigorously on some masa. Hmmmm.......
author: Mojo L.

description: Categorize this into "places you can go to watch your food made from scratch by hand." The deli sells lard-based tortillas made on the premises, chicherones, and other delicacies to local families. You can see people stocking up for family meals- too much work to do it all by hand these days. They have a few tables outside and an awkward ordering system.
author: Heather D.

description:
A quarter for a pack of tortillas; that's how much they used to cost, & I'm sure they haven't gone up too much in price since.  

Never been to Mexico, but I imagine this is what the stores look like there.  Great for cheap spices, authentic ingredients and the most AMAZING guacamole and salsa short of making it yourself.  I suggest the biggest container, as it's great on tortillas heated with a bit of queso blanco, which they conveniently sell there as well.  

And don't forget the big bag of chips.  Good chips and salsa sound so simplistic, but as with all simple things, really easy to get wrong.
author: L. K.

description:
I saw the other La Palma reviews and had to chime in.

I've been enjoying this place for 40+ years!  La Palma has always been a destination for me.  I used to live in the North Bay and I would drive down just for the tortillas and carnitas.

I'm spoiled now, living very close.

I can't think of many things that have remained consistently great over such a long period of time, but La Palma is definitely one!
author: Alberto P.

description: This unassuming store on 24th in the MIssion is off the hook. I say that after trying just one of their products...the wheat tortillas. They are amazing, freshly made at La Plama, and amazingly tasty! The also have corn, flour and CACTUS tortillas; cant wait to get my hands on those puppies. You better believe another review is sure to follow as soon as I try 'em out. If you get a taste in the mean time do me a faor and lemme know what you think. Ive had these tortillas for a few days now and they still seem pretty fresh...ummm yummy....as I rub me belly :D
author: Vivek N.

description: I am keeping this short and sweet.   Seriously the best flour tortillas I have ever had on a burrito.  They melt in your mouth.  A must try.
author: Jon S.

description: Quite possibly the best taco I've ever eaten. To me, it wasn't really carnitas because it wasn't crispy. I would call it shredded pork. But it was delicious and on a heavenly freshly-made tortilla. Great cheese pupusa too - not greasy, filled with flavorful cheese and mild chilis. My family loved the carne asada tacos too. I do think it's a summer place though, because it's a market with a few outdoor tables.
author: Mary Beth O.

description:
LA PALMA FOR DUMMIES (Non-Spanish Speaker Version 101)

Yesterday was my 3rd or 4th visit to La Palma by myself, without my Spanish-speaking girlfriend.

I love the place and crave their tortilla a mano (handmade tortillas)  so much but I always feel intimidated to go there by myself without my gf's language proficiency .   I've been wanting to try more of their stuff but  I just did not have the courage given my nearly non-existent Spanish-speaking capabilities.

So, I created this La Palma For Dummies/La Palma Survival Guide:

Social Scene:   Mission neighborhood Spanish-Speaking People, sometimes a whole family with 3 kids packed inside the store. 98% Latin, 1% white and % Asian (me).

Ambiance:  Mad house. The place is so jammed pack that I was literally elbow to elbow with people. This is a shop or a grocery store, not a restaurant.

Service:  Friendly staff.

Treats:  Handmade tortillas, fresh cheese, chorizos, tacos, burritos, carnitas, tamales, rice plates 

How to order:  
1.  Find your way to the back of the store.  You'll walk through a very narrow aisle of Spanish goods until you arrive at the huge  counter.  Grab a number from number dispensing machine.
2.  Hold on to your number and wait for yours to be called in Spanish.  (Thanks to my Spanish conquistadores I know at least how to count in Spanish.)  Keep you eyes on the electronic number board for your number. Sometimes they don't go by that number, so just be alert.
3.  Look at the menu board and try to decipher the menu in Spanish while you are waiting to be called.  They sell burritos, tacos, all kinds of freshly made tortillas without preservatives, pupusas, etc.  
4.  After your number is called, you  can tell them what you want in English.  They will be able to help you.
5.  Step aside while waiting and go people watching.  It's fascinating to watch the activities in the kitchen.  Wait patiently and be ready to wait for a long time depending on what you ordered. Going to this place is truly a culturally enriching experience.
6.  After you get your food, don't forget your tortillas, queso fresco, freshly made tortilla chips and/or chorizo.
7. Elbow your way back to the front of the store and pay at the register.
8. Head to Casa Lucas one block down to get the rest of your produce to make guacamole, salsa etc. for cheap!
9.  Or to La Victoria across the street for Spanish pastries.

Helpful Hints:

1.  Be polite at all times. Memorize at least these:
Con Permiso (excuse me) and Gracias (thank you)
2.  Bring plenty of quarters for parking
3.  Recommend:  La Palma is well known for great carnitas.
4. Skip: Their pupusas.  They were really hard and chewy.  Not good.  You are better off at Balompie or La Santaneca!

You HAVE to do this:  After you get your freshly made tortillas, get in your car or find a corner spot on the street, tear the bag open, eat a whole tortilla (or 2 or 3) while they are still piping hot, they will melt in your mouth. Just be careful that you are not to be mistaken that you are getting high on tortilla, not crack.

Note:  If you want to skip all of these, at least the waiting part, call in you order, skip the number, go straight to the counter to get your order.

Enjoy!!!!!!!!
author: Leah E.

description: This place rocks. Went this a.m. and got a chorizo and egg taco....to die for! The tortillas are so fresh  and the menudo on the weekend also super. The organization of how to pay is a mess, but so worth it!
author: Nancy M.

description: Oh My, they are in my backyard, which spells T-R-O-U-B-L-E with a capital TROUBLE. The toritillas are super fresh to die for and addicting. When I have dinner parties and Mexican food is on the menu - I just hop, skip and jump over to La Palma for my tortillas, guac (I spice it up at home) and salsa. A MUST for everyone.
author: NYCS F.

description: I love how this place looks like it's just a tiny Mexican supermarket but man, it is so much more than just that. Had the best chicken soft taco of my life here. 5 stars goes to the amazing homemade Mexican food. You can actually see the workers making all of the tortilla by hand in the back. If I lived in SF, I'd totally be in line with the rest of the Mexican mamas ordering bags of handmade tortillas to-go. I can't wait to come back and try everything else on the menu!
author: Michelle L.

description: I love love love mexican food and the tortillas are always the most important component.  La Palma makes authentic, delicious, fantastic tortillas and the bean and cheese burritos aren't too bad either!  "Not too bad" meaning fantastic.  I'm in love with La Palma; it's all about inexpensive, authentic food.
author: Katy P.

description: Best tortillas in the bay. They got little bitty ones, big ones, fat ones, skinny ones. No preservatives, no weird icky smell. I get stacks of their bean and cheese gorditas to keep on hand as homemade meal replacement bars. The salsas are slammin when you don't have time to make your own. I'm always partial to the salsa verde. Haven't tried much else, but I go out of my way to get their corn tortillas every other week!
author: Sita B.

description: My dad is a tortilla-hollic. Well everyone in my family is but none like my father. This is the ONLY place my mom buys tortillas from, so this means this must be the only place in SF that gets it right! Idk about their other things though, so I can only attest to the tortillas.
author: Peeta B.

description: The family ordered a massive amount of food from here for a birthday party-went to pick it up. Ordered tamales, enchiladas, menudo, salsa, guacamole, chips, rice and beans, black beans, refried beans, tortillas, the works.. Food was so yummy and tasted home made, very fresh and delicious. The menudo stood out the most, with so much tripe in it and very rich and creamy broth. I am ordering some ala carte items tomorrow for work for cinco de mayo-flan, bueullos, chips, salsa and guac...btw their guacamole is really really good and so are their salsas. $8.95 for a huge pint of chunky, rich salsa. Can't wait! I've never been to the actual place yet but we will see tomorrow! If its deep in the mission you know its going to be good mexican food!
author: Petri Y.

description: Best Tortillas in SF... seriously. The carnitas are amazing. You can't go wrong here!
author: Kim C.

description:
Based on a Yelp search for "carnitas" I stumbled across La Palma.  For our annual Cinco de Mayo party (this year on the 24th because I've been traveling and that's just how we roll), I had big plans of taking the time to slow cook carnitas to my family's secret recipe specifications.  
Now that I have two days left and have yet to do anything else in preparation for said fiesta grande, I've changed my tune and decided to let someone else do it for me.  I called La Palma, ordered my "small" tray of carnitas, and now having read all reviews containing the word carnitas, I am starving and cannot wait to hook in.
I wonder how many bottles of Mexicoke they'll let me buy while I'm there. . . . 
Thanks Yelp!!  Who knew you actually served as a food review and recommendation web site from time to time?!
**Update**
The carnitas did indeed kick some delicious porky behind.  Some folks complained that they were too dry, but back off you non Mexican blooded people.  What do El Salvadorians and Irish know about carnitas anyway?  Personally I think a little bit of crunch is in order, at home we fight over those pieces.  Mmm, bacony.  I would order these again in a heartbeat if I couldn't make it home for dinner.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
I love, love, love La Palma. I almost don't want to write this review because then you will go there! 
Best burritos in the city hands down. My two favorites are the regular old BRC. Refried beans, rice & cheese, it can always brighten up my day. My other favorite burrito here is the chicken, refried beans, rice, cheese, and salsa. It is so good. Their refried beans never taste peanut buttery (like many other places- Pancho Villa & La Cumbre to name a few). 
Here's what I can't leave the store without:
REFRIED BEANS
-because they taste like how refried beans are supposed to taste. I know that sounds redundant, but seriously no refried beans should taste like peanut butter. period.
PORK TAMALES
-they are never too dry, shredded pork to perfection.
-CORN TORTILLAS
they are handmade in the back, always fresh, I buy a huge bag and then eat them all week for lunch/dinner
-RICE
-always fresh & delicious
-CHORIZO
-so tasty for breakfast, might make your house smell like hot dogs, but worth it, every bite is so good 
-PUPUSAS
-also amazing, fresh, never left out sitting since everyone always comes in and buys them, they are constantly making them right there, so yummy. I liked the chicharron and mixed ones.
This place is like my equivalent to Trader Joes, instead of stocking up on healthy groceries there, I come here. I spend about $25 and the food lasts me all week. It's probably not the healthiest option, but is still my favorite food. 
I also did catering here for my sister's surprise birthday party. It was reasonably priced, and I had leftovers for days! The only challenge was, since I am not fluent in Spanish, it was hard to articulate to the lady what exactly I wanted and how many. All in all, I got what I wanted, and I didn't have to wait, it was all ready to go when I picked it up, nothing missing from my order. I will definitely use them again for catering a party and everyone loved the food.
author: Kristy H.

description: What Lucca Ravioli on Valencia is to Italian, this 24th Street gem is to Mexican. Fresh and homemade are the keywords here, and you can find everything you need for your next fiesta.
author: Gourmet G.

description: This place is the spot for burritos! they have carnitas that are tasty and fresh. in fact all of their food is fresh. this is not a taqueria but it has one of the top five burritos in the city. ther tortilla chips are good. and they have a variety of other foods that are tasty. Try them out you wont be dissatisfied!
author: Daniel C.

description: I've had many tamales in my life.  The tamales here are SUPERB, moist, dense, flavorful, fresh, they smell amazing, and I haven't had a tamale that compares in the bay area.  I've been here 6 years and have not had a tamale that even ebbs towards comparison.  Though these tamales are in the fight of their lives for best tamale with El Toro market in Santa Ana, CA - but that's a fight i don't mind being apart of.
author: Walrus C.

description: As a half-mexican, it has become a part of my adulthood traditions to take over the role of making tamales around christmas. La Palma is the only place I'll get masa now that I don't have to make any vegan or vegetarian tamales. Queso frescos are great and if you can get em hot, the handmade tortillas are bomb... it is by far the best Mexicatessen when it comes to anything corn dough related.
author: Niki M.

description: I love this place.  The best home-made corn tortillas I've ever bought in a store.  Their salsa is also excellent.  I only give it 4 stars because I haven't tried everything in there and their flour tortillas didn't necessarily thrill me.
author: cindy p.

description: My family has been coming here for over 25 years to get everything from a quick bite to eat to getting la masa to make authentic home-made tamales, tortillas, pupusas, sopes and so on.  This family owned and run mission institution has it all, from freshly made guac (the best in the city bar-none) to refried beens.  Feelin lazy, but want home made flavor? Having a bbq and want some mexi-inspired sides? come on down to the Lower 24th Street Neighborhood!
author: A P.

description: Word the F*ck up!   You can't make food taste bad when you come home from the Mexica-tessen with a tub of manteca..  I went over here to buy a torta, and wound up dropping about $20 on all kinds of tortillas, cheeses, refried beans, and just about  every other "oh and one of those"  in the place.  I'm only a block away, so I'll be shopping for new pants soon.
author: matthew w.

description:
This place is the BOMB with Carnitas, Fresh Tortillas and Chicharron........Etc.......
Highly recommended and yes bring a person that can speak spanish for you.
author: W P.

description: This Mexican food shop and taqueria grinds its own corn to make fresh masa for fresh and unbelievably delicious tortillas, which the are hand shaped and grilled on site behind the counter. The chili verde is to die for.  Don't miss it.
author: H.A. ..

description: Probably one of the best places to get a burrito in the mission.
author: Sean F.

description: We were having a Mission Saturday: took our car for new shoes down on 15th and S. Van Ness; went to Ritual Coffee for a bump, ate breaky at Boogaloos; then decided to walk over to La Palma to pick up some carnitas for lunch. OH MY BUDDHA! We bought a pound of carnitas, fresh and still warm tortillas, and a pint of guac and took it home. It was fantastic and I highly recommend it. My gf comes from a family of awesome Mexican cooks, so I KNOW good Mexican food--and this is the real deal. We will go back and work our way through the menu.
author: Deborah S.

description:
Growing up we use to hit La Palma every weekend with my pops..then the carnitas got greasy and we stopped going...

Over the past several years, La Palma has made the big comeback and now I order carnitas/frioles, etc. for big gatherings. They are ALWAYS a hit and for the amount of food you get, it is a great value..the best part is the place is genuine and owned by a Latino family. You don't see that  enough..I highly recommend!! Maria C.
author: Maria C.

description: Awesome Mexican food! The restaraunt itself is so confusing. You walk in and don't know where to order or what to do. Somehow we figured it out and got our food. There's nowhere to eat inside and only a few tables out around the corner. I got the cheese enchiladas with rice and refried beans. Rusty got the chicken flautas. The food was SO good! We both loved it.
author: Tanner W.

description: Looking for handmade tortillas? How about some awesome guacamole or fresh salsa? Look no further than La Palma Mexicatessen. From the exterior, it looks like any other corner market, but walk inside and you'll happen on one of the Mission's best kept secrets: a full-on Mexican deli. On holidays, this is where the locals line up to get their fresh masa and on any day of the week it's one of the best burritos/pupusas/breakfast burritos (if you're lucky -- they often sell out) in town. Only bummers are that they close early at 5:00pm and it's take away only.
author: Katie B.

description: Best chips IN THE WORLD. amazing fresh tortillas too, but don't get tempted to buy a ton because of how cheap they are - they don't keep even a day, nor do they freeze well. gotta chow 'em all down in one sitting.
author: Erica W.

description: This place is outstanding!  the tamales are so delicious and the gorditas are just are yummy!  I go out of my way just to go there for these tasty treats.  While you are there pick up some of their salsa as well to top the tamales and gorditas...you won't regret it!  It is always insanely busy, but they are very efficient and will get you anything that you need.
author: Hailey M.

description: I've never been here but my roommate keeps bringing home bags of chips and I can't stop eating them... and their salsa is spicy.
author: Susan L.

description: This place is all about the Salvadoran tamales...forget trying the regular ones.  $2.50 vs. $1.65...for 85 cents more you get a much better tasting tamale - much softer masa and much more tender pork.  But I must say they could add a bit more meat.  We also ordered a container of the guacamole which was very tasty....and this is coming from someone who hates the taste of avocados and never eats guac!  Will definitely go back to try some of the other items on the menu.
author: Tina L.

description: Avoid coming here during Christmas and New Years! The food is soooo darn good that practically every family in San Francisco has to come here to buy their party ingredients. Seriously this place is awesome! The carnitas are the best and I've never tasted anything better. If you only can make it during the weekend or holidays, be prepared for the long lines!
author: L P.

description: This is the best place on earth. They have everything you can freakin' ask for. They make their own corn chips and it's delicious and addicting. I would be afraid to live down the street from here or I would really get grande. The Avocado Salsa they make is very tasty and addicting too. I also ordered a Super Burrito which was Yummy (maybe not as good as El Farolito and Pancho Villa but it's still very tasty and they use Fresco cheese in their burritos instead of Mozarella). The Nacatamale was good and spicy but it's not as good as the NIcaraguan places they have on the Mission. Everything here is so cheap and I can always find something to get. I think I may be the only gringo that's obsessed with this place but it's soo worth it! One plus is that they take credit cards and ATM's :)
author: Nir B.

description: Five stars hands down, even though I don't speak Spanish. Restaurant quality food at burger king prices.
author: Mikey D.

description: The real deal. Got burritos and took them up to Bernal Heights for a picnic. Soooo good. My carnitas was decadent. Stocked up on corn tortillas to bring back to Santa Cruz. A very good decision.  Love 24th St.
author: Steven K.

description: A neighborhood treasure.  Worth seeking out for the hand made tortillas alone.
author: Mr. B.

description:
This review only pertains to the magic that is the fried cinnamon chips.  Let me just use a few lines to wax poetic.
I bought these on a whim after coming in for my usual bag of homemade thick and crispy crunchy chips with pico de gallo and guacamole to bring back to my gf while we studied.  While I was checking out I noticed a bag of chips that looked to be coated in cinnamon sugary goodness.  I thought "what the heck" and bought two to bring along.  Best decision of my SF grocery shopping experience so far!!!
When we got home that night I cracked it open and had a religious food experience; almost out of body even.
Crunchy, with just the right amount of oily fried mouth feel.  Then the delicate sweetness of the cinnamon and sugar.  It all came together in one taste to create the perfect sweet snack.  I finished one whole bag on my own!  With no regrets!
Alas, I went back today and no snack!  God is merciful because I am trying to drop pounds gained during the Bar, but give me a month and I'll be back!
author: Sheila Y.

description: My girlfriend wanted to kill me after I made her walk three miles to eat here. She is easily creeped out when she can't communicate to ensure her food truly is vegetarian. At a place where no one spoke English, that was an obstacle. Add to it that the line was out the door, and there's no room in the place at all, and she was ready to strangle me in line. However, she got over it when the food came out. Delicious! And, we are 99% sure it was actually vegetarian. As an added bonus, some schmuck that had a show on the Food Network was leading a tour of his favorite places, so we got to listen to him tell stories about himself the whole time. Very surreal.
author: Shawn B.

description: Walking past here on Sunday morning after a night of raging La Palma is an inspiration to keep going. The rythmic clapping sound of handmade tortillas and smell of cornmeal is the only sign of life on 24th Street at 4a.m. They don't open until later though it is always worth the trip. Everything I have ever ordered has been very satisfying and well worth it.
author: fuck you p.

description: get the crispy tacos with the carnitas. i also recommend the fresh cheeses and chicharones! this place is a must! and its conveniently close to 24th street bart.
author: Slo C.

description: La Palma has great tamales!!! My roommates got burritos and those were delicious, too. Definitely a must visit! Also, the staff there is fun.
author: Valerie P.

description: I finally made my way in here last Saturday afternoon and was pretty much the only non-Spanish speaking person (at least fluently). It was about 4 deep by the counter. That's a good sign in my book. I ordered a torta for comparison's sake to my fave place up the block but they had no rolls. Went with some tacos that weren't the best I've had BUT THE 5 STAR FOR THE CHIPS, SALSA AND TORTILLAS. All homemade and as authentic as you can get. I'll go back to try some of the other dishes but you should go for the chips and salsa. (The woman behind me had a 10 gallon bag of masa for tamales. I almost asked her where she lives.)
author: Sig N.

description:
if you need tubs of liquid lard, find out when they're making chicharones at la palma cus then you can come buy some freshly made manteca (lard) afterwards!  it has less saturated fats than butter :)
they have real good queso fresco and tortillas too...
author: charlotte s.

description:
go buy a bag of their homemade tortilla chips which are like manna from heaven. thick. crispy. salty. no preservatives. these are the chips you want when you're going for that big dip of guacamole. i even take la palma's chips to mexican restaurants and substitute them for the ones that are provided, but i'm crazy like that.

update: was back in s.f. for thanksgiving and got my chips again. made a new discovery, la palma's "chili x picante" salsa/hot sauce.  made out of cascabel chiles, it's a deep red color, and it's the most flavorful, hot salsa i've had in a long while. not for the faint of heart, but i highly recommend it to anyone who likes some mouth burn with some body to it.

update 7/2007: this is how much my mom loves me. she was coming out to visit me in nyc and asked if she could bring me anything. my only request was chips & salsa from la palma. she not only carried the chips without breaking them, but she also divvied up the salsa into a couple of 1 ounce containers so she could get it through airport security! they taste even better in new york because there's nothing else that compares here. mom, you're the best!
author: Right R.

description: Yummy fresh handmade tortillas - fresh masa by the pound - yummy takeaway food -
author: Robyn C.

description: The second best thing to eating these insanely delicious tortillas is running by this Mexicatessen in the morning right before the store opens, with the line of anxious and expectant shoppers curving around the corner, and having the smell of those insanely delicious tortillas make you reconsider why you are running instead of stopping and joining the throng.
author: amanda g.

description:
good cheap food and friendly service.  ridicously large bag of chips and killer pico degalo.  what else can you ask for? ummm maybe a chair and a table... take-out only. 

i didnt want to go through the awkward motion of asking for 1/4lb of carnitas.. but definetly will drag one of my spanish speaking coworkers to get some.
author: Doug ..

description: If you're looking for better than average tortillas (or if you're really hardcore and want to make your own) this is the place to go.  The handmade tortillas they crank out are unusually thick and delicious, and go wonderfully with the meats they serve from their "deli" counter (brilliant concept, BTW--taqueria as deli).  I agree with Courtney that their selection of groceries is a bit slimmer than I was expecting, but it sounds like their real speciality is providing raw materials for the various corn based Mexican dishes.
author: Buzz A.

description: My dad has been taking me here since I was a kid. I love the hand made tamales! The women are in the back clapping  the flour away! Everyone is so nice there! Ooh I am going to grab some this weekend!
author: Jennifer O.

description: I have been on a month-long 'healthy eating' binge and decided to break it with a nice 1000-calorie burrito.  Holy crap it was good.  I felt like a douche for walking up to the front of the line--didn't realize they had a ticket system until after ordering.  Don't be like me.  I'll be back.
author: S P.

description: 5 stars?  Oh boy, there is something wrong with the rating system when this "restaurant" gets 5 stars.  First of all, it is a grocery store with a food counter and no tables = not a restaurant.  Second of all, the food isn't all that amazing.  Don't get me wrong, because I think it is quaint and authentic neighborhood hotspot.  But other "restaurants" like Starbucks, (which has a pretty good egg muffin and... *gasp*, seating) should never deserve 5 stars.  Sorry hipsters.
author: Joe H.

description:
la palma, te amo.

i got carnitas, frijoles, queso, crema and tortillas to make tacos at home.  also got some chicharones and i ate too many and felt pretty gross.  i have no self control when it comes to pig.

how come all my reviews are motivated by pork?  prolly because it's so GOOD.  big ups to hernando de soto for bringing swine to north america.

anyway la palma is delish.  and not spendy.  no numbers anymore, you just order at the counter and pay in the front.  carnitasssssss
author: Barry S.

description: This is some great Mexican food. However, the service is very hit or miss. This is fantastic, and there are scores of people making tortillas behind the counter every day (which are sold fresh and hot at the store, and are delectable) which adds atmosphere. However, there are other fantastic restaurants in the area, also, so this is hard to rate a 5-star.
author: Samantha W.

description:
I should really hate this place, now before everyone starts gasping I have reasons. Reason number 1) I live all the way in Pittsburg so it's a trek for me to get out here 2) It seems like everyday I crave Mexican food so nothing will ever amount to their chicharon tacos 3) It makes me forget about factory farming when I see those deep fried pigs flesh shining brightly at me. SEEEEE! 
I finally found time where I was off and had nothing to do and I was in a good mood to go over to this place, and I am soo glad I did. First off it was very easy to find; we went on a weekday so parking was really easy. Now before going inside I informed the boyfriend (aka the chinese boy who failed spanish 1) that from previous yelp reviews there is a big language barrier, he told me to order haha. So I go into the store first thing I noticed was a big parrot coin bank on a shelf in red and pictures of Jesus everywhere (BONUS POINTS!!! In my house I have the exact same parrot but in BLUE and we are Jesus lovers too!!!). I fall in line not knowing you had to pull a number so needless to say I stood there for a good 10 minutes smiling, hoping the lady would be like "aww what a geniune smile I'm gonna help her", but that didn't happen. Finally found the number and waited. When I ordered the tacos it was pretty simple, on the counter it had it's picture there and it's menu number, #1, so it was simple. But get this, there is a wait...i know sucky. But come on you are waiting for delicious food. We decided to eat our delicious tacos in the car and oh my god it was amazing. It was such a simple taco chicharon, some mild sauce, jalapenos, onions, and cilantro, and DAMN it tasted sooo good. Maybe it was because of the home made tortilla, or becuase of the fried pig skin, but wow best taco yet. 


Oh and on another note.
I was like WOW this could be a great day if we also had MItchells too! Cause if anyone knows me, Mexican and Ice Cream is the greatest combo ever. But as we were driving up we saw that they were closed. I was sooo sad.

So I went back to las palmas and bought another taco to make me happy.
author: Cristelle J.

description: You want authentic mexican?  You cant get more authentic than this place.  Workers in the back hand making toritillas, menu in all spanish and some ridiculously good food, loon no further.  This is the place to be.  Its funny, experiences here make you wonder why you ever goto Chevys or Eltorito, especially if you live in SF or areas with the opportunity to each the most authentic mexican food out there.
author: Charles C.

description: I was here when on a kick for tamales. Good tamales are hard to find, and La Palma is dependable and authentic. They're not the best tamales I've had, but they're cheap and very, very quick. Less than $2 a pop. It's basically a small grocery store with a quick service restaurant in the back. Take a number, order, get your food in less than five minutes, and pay at the checkout counter at the door. Will go back to try out other menu items soon...
author: Hannah C.

description: Hot fresh delicious tortillas and other Mexican goodies.  This is my first choice for any and all Mexican cooking staples. Note: Cash only!  I'm noticing that others have said they take cards, but they sure didn't the day I was there last there in early January 2008 - there were big signs up, and I remember because I didn't have enough cash for my queso (even though my total was over $10).  Sadness!
author: Jess L.

description: The tacos caseros de chicharron & the pupusas are top-notch and worth the wait on Saturday afternoons.  SCIENCE EXPERIMENT:  Eat half a bag of blue-corn tortilla chips and see what happens.  It'll blow your mind.
author: Andrea U.

description: I've walked past this place for years, mistakenly thinking it was just a small market...  my oh my, how I've been missing out.  I've lived in the Mission for years now and my burrito favorites have yoyoed from Papalote to El Metate to La Cornetta to Vallarta... and now, La Palma.  Specifically the carnitas burrito and my new favorite, the breakfast burrito with scrambled eggs, chorizo, beans, hot sauce, and cheese.  Wow.  Ever since I mistakenly tried El Farolito's breakfast burrito (burned eggs + raw onions + beans = inedible) I've shied away from ordering them anywhere else but a recent romance with Red Cafe's breakfast burrito (fresh eggs, link sausage, salsa, refried black beans, cheese) sparked a renewed interest in the genre.  Huge, packed with pinto beans, cheese, eggs and dripping with chorizo grease, La Palma's breakfast burrito is the greatest breakfast burrito in the world.  Seriously.
author: Peter F.

description: yes please !!! the back of la palma is a tortilla factory. You can also by masa and carnitas by the pound. the tacos are amazing thanks to fresh and thick tortillas. They are a little bigger than what I like but still yummy!! there is no seating but on a nice day grabbing some tacos and a jaritos or even a negra modelo and sitting on a stoop is worth the delicousness.
author: Brandi B.

description: How I crave their flautas! This place has to have the best flauta's with the best toppings, like, anywhere. No one else can compare, honestly. The line can be long at times, but you've got groceries to keep you company. They make all the food right in front of you (as with most mexicatessens) and they put everything you want and nothing really costs extra. Yum yum yum.
author: Kelly Marie C.

description: This place makes awesome vege burritos, one of the best quick burr-eats I've had in the city. It helps to know some Spanish as sometimes it makes it easier to communicate with the staff. Plus if they call your number and you don't know that "veinticinco" means 25, you might have some trouble. It's not a place you can eat-in, but if you've got a destination in mind, possibly you've planned a picnic with your enemy in mosquito-ridden bernal heights park (still the view of the city is worth it), you're all set.
author: Michael M.

description: We ordered vegetarian Burrito, veg Huraches and cheese quesedilla. We them ordinary. Nothing special. May be their meat dishes are better.
author: V J.

description: A MUST try on the chicarrones, and, hands down, the BEST tortillas in the city!
author: John S.

description: Had 3 hard carnitas tacos, and my son had 1 soft chicken taco.  Not blown away by these items, but the freshly made tortilla making in the back looked good.  Anyone recommend what I *should* have there?
author: Rob P.

description: I live in DC and was in San Fran to host a couple's shower for 40+ people. Our theme was Mexican Fiesta and I was tasked to find tasty, authentic Mexican food for catering.  Thanks to all you yelpers, I picked La Palma due to the great reviews and ranking.  The ordering process (with Paco over the phone) was really simple and Paco was very helpful in helping me make selections. I went with Trays D & E and ordered some pupusas a la carte. The food was fantastic! The cheese enchiladas with salsa verde were my favorite.  I highly recommend La Palma for great service, great food and a great price.
author: Angie O.

description: I really like the food here especially the burritos. Every is mostly fresh and delicious. They offer a large variety of food and have all the fixings fresh too. I come here whenever Im in the area. Highly recommended.
author: SF N.

description: As that overexposed tart on the food network likes to say "YUMMO".  Awesome food and the best tortilla chips., albeit best mexi-deli in the city.  "Obilgation Free-Weekends" and no reason to leave the house, except to get chips, guacamole, salsa  from this place is WORTH IT!
author: erica u.

description:
tacos a mano or a macchina?
a mano por favor.
algo mas?
un libre de carnitas, un bolsa de chips, una chingadera de salsa, y una de crema.
gracias.

Go here and do this, then buy some tecate and bike, or walk up to DP and you are in heaven. One of the reasons I love this city.

The pupusas are also muy rico.
author: Burne D.

description: It was cold one morning in December, as I walked into  La Palma. I was introduced to the warmth of guarachas, fresh hand made tortillas and chicharon. The smell of the corn aroused my hunger and I became a slave to the corn goddess. If your ever in the mood for fresh hand made tortillas this is the place to come.
author: Eli R.

description: A great mexicatessen!  Shopping list - fresh masa, a meat marinade, cojita cheese, hot sauce, and chips we can eat with the hot sauce.  All that for about $5.00.  The next time I go back, I promised myself not to leave without at least one pupusa.
author: Christine S.

description: Delicous Mexican taco and tamales for real affordable price. I love the huaraches but it comes in a bag of eight and that's just too much for me. But it is always baked fresh....you can tell from the steam in the bag. Also, the corn tamales are the best, it's sweet not savory. Grab-the mexican Coca Cola sold in bottles that are a tad sweeter and has real sugar. (The U.S. Colas are made with high corn fructose). I had tacos, tamales and Mexican coca cola for under five dollars.  So forget about the taqueria go straight to Mexico via 24th street. Just a cultural experience, you'll love the idea of the Mexican women cooking in action behind the station. Also, eat your tacos at the church steps across the streets and looked at the surrounding murals all over 24th street. Muy rico!!!
author: girl e.

description: blue corn zucchini gorditas looked good. pretty sure we ordered the wrong thing here: tamales. they were dry and not too flavorful. however, the rest of the menu looked pretty awesome. next time I'll try sopes, gorditas, or huaraches AND i'll be sure to take some of their freshly made tortillas to go.
author: micaela r.

description: Great neighborhood store!  I miss the roast chicken, but the pupusas are some of the best!  Haven't tried the other restaurant items.
author: tom i.

description: the BEST carnitas in town! buy by the pound, take home some tortillas, handmade on the spot... grab some crema, some avocado, add your favorite salsa, a bit o' lime... and you got CrAzY good! I'm mexi... I know.
author: M V.

description: I first heard of La Palma while my husband was courting me back in college way way back in the day. He was trying to enthrall me with the wonders of San Francisco. He told me these grandmas would make these delicious papusas, slapping it with their hands, right in front of you. I was fascinated. I was a small town East Coast girl, I had no idea what papusas or burritos were. Fast forward to the present and I am now intimately familiar with La Palma and her offerings of papusas, tortas, quesadillas, chicharron and masa by the pound. They still make papusas by hand right in front of you. And they will make it without cheese if you ask, but you have to wait about ten minutes. They do take credit/debit because I've done it several times but there is a $10 limit I believe. A lot of things have changed on 24th Street. There is much whirring of expresso machines and clicking of lap tops, but  rhythm of slap slap slapping of papusas coming from La Palma has remain constant.
author: Kara P.

description: This is probably a case of ordering the wrong thing, but all I wanted was the Chicarron Taco in the pictures - it looks so good.  I wasn't expecting so many questions which were so difficult to understand/hear, due to the lady's strong accent and the music blaring in the background.  The first question was what meat - I'm pretty sure I said Chicarrons, which was also there in picture.  Second, she asked if I wanted homemade or factory made tortillas.  Of course I want homemade - well, the homemade is actually a gordita or something very bready - like a pupusa almost.  Not what I was wanting - I wanted a thin tortilla.  Finally, she asked me what kind of beans and if i wanted everything - I said black and yes.  Well, what I got was a sort of soupy red chicken that was overcooked in my homemade gordita/pupasa "tortilla".  Maybe if I come back and figure out a way to get what is in the pictures in the restaurant or in this review, I would be a 4-star happy camper.  But alas, hopefully my tragedy will be your gain.
author: Paul K.

description: After forcing myself to buy from them for 4 years, I've moved on. This place is over rated, the re-fried beans taste heavily like lard. The rice is greasy and tasteless and the rest of the menu is greasy bla, not worth talking about. The 2 stars are for the nopales tortillas, pretty ok.
author: Tapatia D.

description: the quesadilla suiza was  ok nothing special but what made it up is el pastor they had , A M A Z I N G best in the city so far .definetly going back for more love it
author: NAEL K.

description: ok i just stated that gordo's carnitas is the best. well la palma is right up there with them. i remember when my dad used to work in the mission and he would come home with a bag from la palma. it would be filled with a bag of carnitas and a container of chile verde, along with some of their fresh made tortillas. i would come home and jump for joy and start frying up some carnitas and make tiny tacos for myself and no one else. i realize i had other family members... but back off of my carnitas. i wish i lived in the city because i would always have a container of their meat in my fridge. mmm. carnitas.
author: Erin D.

description: if i lived closer to la palma id be up in that bitch daily. i cant really fuck with commercially made tortillas anymore. it just dont make sense. everything here is awesome. the green guacasalsa makes my eyes roll back in my head. i will cut a bitch who says anything bad about la palma and the green sauce. white people get learned. stop fucking with them bullshit taquerias get with the realness.
author: lydia p.

description: there is nothing better than a cup of coffee and a fresh thick handmade tortilla with fresh cheese on a sunday morning.  la palma has my favorite breakfast and a bunch of other really yummy treats but i have to get there early because they run out of stuff fast.  i can't remember the last time i had a potato taco.  the early birds always beat me to the punch.
author: Andrea B.

description: plantains!  oh plantains.  how i miss you and the way that you are cooked whole and i put you in a tortilla and eat you with cream.  oh plantains, yummy yellow goodness sold by the pound, shaped like phalluses but oh so much more tasty.
author: Nora B.

description: They've got everything you need and want: popusas, carnitas, chicharrones, chicken, tamales, sodas, cheeses, tortillas, mendudo, I can go on and on. But this is definetely the place everyone goes to get masa for those homemade tamales or tortillas. The lines during x-mas and New year is around the corner! You need to DEFINITELY try their CARNITA HUARACHES its a long oval tortilla stuffed with cheese and beans and topped with carnitas, cabbage, sour cream, and  green sauce YUUUUUMMMMMM!!!!
author: Maria H.

description: this place is the shit. you can get a dinner-- containers of rice, beans, guacamole, salsa, real mexican sour cream, and fresh tortillas-- for about $20. and about 4 people can comfortably FEAST.
author: Samantha G.

description: Great place to buy the thick, supple, hand-made tortillas (and a pound or two of carnitas).
author: Max D.

description: I hadn't been here in many years but my SO wanted some tamales and the only ones I really like are sold at La Tapatia in South San Francisco but I live in SF and was lazy and the review on Yelp was excellent. I bought both the Mexican & Salvadoren~ean - they were AWFUL, the chicken was STALE and the masa wasn't properly cooked - two bites and into the trash - AVOID! I will never ever come back. Geez, go to Trader Joe's their FROZEN TAMALES are a thousand times better.  A-W-F-U-L! I went at noon no wonder the joint was empty. Dumpy neighborhood with tough parking. Gotta say the handmade tortillas are good though but hardly worth a trip.
author: alex b.

description: This place makes the best tortillas ever.  They make them in the back. You can get them hand made if you want them a bit thicker or machine made if you want them thinner.  Their chips are also awesome.  If they're a bit soft  after a day or two, just stick them in the oven for 20 minutes at 225 F and they will be fine.  I don't know how the rest of the stuff is and I don't care.  I schlep my tortillas all the way to Oakland from this place because they are exactly like (and in some cases better than) the ones I used to get in Mexico when I was a little kid and I would go to the tortilla factory with my mom and sit with the other ladies and wait for a fresh kilo of tortillas. As for rating this place as a restaurant, anybody with an IQ higher than 60 can walk into this place and recognize it is not a restaurant.  It's basically a tortilla factory with a few other miscellaneous things.  The other things may not be as good as the tortillas but I refuse to give it less than 5 stars. The tortillas are that good.
author: cecilia g.

description: This place makes hand made tortillas and sells fresh masa and a few groceries. Their huaraches are amazing, even plain. On the tortillas: yes, I get that they're handmade, but well-made tortillas, even by hand, are not supposed to be 1/4 inch thick. But, the tacos that they make there are tasty.
author: kirin r.

description: if you like pupusas and have not had a pupusa from la palma you are missing alot. they are the best. i like the ones rellenas de frijoles con queso. my entire family loves them. i am given five stars for their pupusas. their hand made tortillas are also delicious, you cannot find any other tortilla as good as these.
author: papa c.

description: Used to live a couple of blocks away, and this was a regular Saturday stop.  The fresh tortillas are wonderful, and the tamales are also quite yummy. Sometimes you can find bags of home made potato chips - nice and greasy.  They also have an outstanding selection of pinatas.  The people who work there are very nice, and I really enjoy taking people there to watch the ladies in the back make tortillas!
author: g l.
